“Go tell Pharaoh, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews says to let his people go so they can serve him. 2If you keep holding them, 3he’ll bring a severe plague on your livestock in the pasture—horses, donkeys, camels, herds, and flocks. 4But he’ll distinguish Israel’s livestock from Egypt’s. Nothing will die that belongs to the Israelites.’”

5The LORD set a time, “I’ll do that in the country tomorrow.” 6The next day he did it. Livestock in Egypt died, but none of the Israelites’ livestock died. 7Pharaoh sent to find out that not a one of the Israelites’ livestock died, but he hardened his heart and wouldn’t let the people go. Ex 9:1-7

The Plague of Boils

8The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

“Take handfuls of ashes out of a kiln and throw them up in the air in front of Pharaoh. 9They’ll become fine dust all over Egypt, and make boils break out with sores on people and animals everywhere in the country.”

10They took ashes out of a kiln and stood in front of Pharaoh. Moses threw them up in the air, and they made boils break out in sores on people and animals. 11The magicians couldn’t withstand Moses because of the boils. They came on the magicians as well as all the Egyptians. 12The LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t listen. Ex 9:8-12

The Plague of Hail

13The LORD told Moses,

“Get up early, present yourselves to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews says, “Let my people go so they can serve me. 14This time I’ll send my plagues on you, your officers, and your people so you can know there’s nobody on earth like me. 15If I’d struck you and your people with a deadly plague, you wouldn’t be here 16 to see my power and to make myself known all over the world. 17You still rise up against my people and won’t let them go. 18About this time tomorrow, I’ll send heavy hail beyond anything Egypt has ever had. 19Bring inside whatever livestock you have in the pasture. People and animals will die that are not inside.”’”

20Pharaoh’s officers that respected the LORD made their servants and livestock get under shelter. 21Those who didn’t pay attention left them out in the open. Ex 9:13-21

22The LORD told Moses, “Hold your hand toward the sky so hail will fall on the people, animals, and plants out in the open everywhere in Egypt.” 23He pointed his staff at the sky, and the LORD sent thunder and hail, and lightning struck the ground. 24There was really severe hail and lightning flashing continually in the hail, like nothing that had ever happened in Egypt since it became a nation. 25The hail struck everything that was out in the open everywhere in Egypt—people, animals, plants in the field, and shattered the trees. 26Only in Goshen, where the Israelites lived, there wasn’t any hail. Ex 9:22-26

27Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron, “I’ve sinned this time. The LORD is right; my people and I are wrong. 28Pray to him. We’ve had enough of his thunder and hail. I’ll let you go for good.”

29Moses told him,

“As soon as I leave the city, I’ll spread out my hands to the LORD. The thunder and hail will stop, and you’ll know the world belongs to the LORD. 30But I’m sure you and your officers still won’t respect him.”

31(The hail ruined the flax and barley crops because the barley had headed out and the flax had budded. 32It didn’t ruin the wheat and spelt, which ripen later.) 33Moses left Pharaoh and the city and spread out his hands to the LORD. The thunder, hail, and rain quit pouring down. 34When Pharaoh saw it stop, he and his officers sinned again and hardened their hearts. 35He wouldn’t let the people go. Ex 9:27-35

The Plague of Locusts

10:1Then the LORD told Moses,

“Go to Pharaoh; I’ve hardened his and his officers’ hearts so I can perform these signs among them 2and you can tell your sons and grandsons how I mocked the Egyptians with my signs, and so you can know I’m the LORD.”

3Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh,

“The LORD God of the Hebrews says, ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself toward me? Let my people go so they can serve me. 4If you don’t, I’ll bring locusts to your realm tomorrow. 5They’ll cover the ground so thick you can’t see it. They’ll eat what the hail didn’t ruin, every tree that sprouts in your field. 6Your houses, your officers’ houses, every Egyptian’s house will be full of them—something your fathers and grandfathers have never seen.’”

He turned and left. 7Pharaoh’s officials said, “How long will that man hold us hostage? Let the men go so they can serve the LORD their God. Can’t you see that Egypt’s destroyed?”

8Pharaoh brought Moses and Aaron back, “Go serve the LORD your God! Who are going?”

9Moses said, “We’ll all go with our flocks and herds to hold a festival to the LORD.”

10-11Pharaoh said, “Oh, no! The LORD help you if I ever let you and your little ones go! Don’t tempt me; you have ulterior motives. The men among you can go serve the LORD. That’s what you’ve been asking for.”

Pharaoh drove them out. Ex 10:1-11

12Then the LORD told Moses, “Hold your hand out over Egypt; locusts will come up on the land and eat the plants the hail left.” 13He held his staff out over Egypt, and the LORD made an east wind blow all that day and night. In the morning, it brought the locusts, 14and they landed everywhere. There had never been so many, and there never would be again. 15They covered the ground till it was black. They ate every plant and fruit tree the hail had left. There wasn’t anything green on the trees or plants anywhere in Egypt.

16Pharaoh hurried and called for Moses and Aaron, “I’ve sinned against you and the LORD your God. 17Forgive me just this once and pray to him to remove this death from me.”

18Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD. 19He shifted the wind to a strong west wind that blew the locusts into the Red Sea. Not a one was left in Egypt. 20But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t let the people go. Ex 10:12-20

The Plague of Darkness

21Then he told Moses, “Lift your hand toward the sky; it’ll be so dark you can feel it.” 22Moses raised his hand toward the sky, and a dense darkness covered Egypt for three days. 23People couldn’t see each other, it was so dark. Nobody got up from where they were for three days, but the Israelites had light in their houses.

24Pharaoh called to Moses, “Go serve the LORD. Just leave your flocks and herds here. Even your little ones can go with you.”

25But Moses said,

“You need to let us have sacrifices and burnt offerings to the LORD our God. 26Our livestock has to go with us. Not a hoof will stay here. We’ll take some of them to serve the LORD. We don’t know what we’ll serve him with till we get there.”

27But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he wouldn’t let them go. 28He told Moses, “Get out of here! I’m warning you, don’t ever see me again. The day you do you’ll die!”

29“You’re right. I’ll never see you again.” Ex 10:21-29

Plague on the Firstborn

11:1The LORD told Moses,

“I’m going to bring one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that, he’ll let you go. When he does, he’ll drive you out completely. 2Tell each man and woman to ask their neighbors for silver and gold articles.”

3The LORD gave the Egyptians a favorable attitude toward the people. Furthermore, Pharaoh’s officers and the people in general respected Moses a lot. Ex 11:1-3

4Moses said, “The LORD says, ‘About midnight I’ll go out into Egypt, 5and all firstborn will die—the firstborn of Pharaoh on his throne, the firstborn of the slave girl behind the millstones, the firstborn among the livestock. 6There’ll be such an outcry everywhere in Egypt as has never been heard or will be. 7But among the Israelites, not even a dog will bark at people or animals. You’llsg see how the LORD distinguishes Israel from Egypt.

8‘Yoursg officials will come and bow to me and say, “Leave, you and your people.” Then I’ll leave.’”

He left Pharaoh really mad.

9The LORD told Moses, “Pharaoh won’t listen; so I’ll multiply my wonders in Egypt.” 10Moses and Aaron performed those wonders for him, but the LORD hardened his heart, and he wouldn’t let the people go. Ex 11:4-10

The Passover Instituted

12:1The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

2“This month will be the first month of your year. 3Tell the assembly of Israel that on the tenth of this month, each family is to take a lamb according to their families. 4If a family is too small for a lamb, that family and a nearby neighbor can take a lamb the size the number of people can eat. 5It needs to be an unblemished male a year old. Take it from the sheep or goats. 6Keep it till the fourteenth of the month.

“The whole community is to kill it in the evening. 7Put some of its blood on the doorposts and lintel of the house where you eat it. 8Eat the meat that same night, roasted with fire. Eat it with bitter herbs and bread without yeast. 9Don’t eat any of it raw or boiled. Roast the head, legs, and entrails. 10In the morning, burn what’s left over. 11Eat it in a hurry, dressed, with sandals on your feet and staff in hand. It’s the LORD’s Passover. 12I’ll go all over Egypt that night and strike down the firstborn people and animals. I’ll execute judgment on Egypt’s gods. I’m the LORD. 13The blood on your houses will be a sign. When I see it, I’ll ‘pass over’ you. No plague will fall on you when I strike Egypt. Ex 12:1-13

14“Today will serve as a memorial day for you. Celebrate it as a festival to the LORD, a permanent ordinance. 15Eat bread without yeast for a week. On the first day, take the yeast out of your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first till seventh day will be excluded from Israel. 16On the first day, hold a holy assembly. On the seventh day, hold another one. Don’t work on those days except for what needs to be eaten by each person that only you can fix. 17Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread throughout your generations; that’s the day I brought your hosts out of Egypt. 18In the first month, eat bread without yeast from the fourteenth in the evening till the twenty-first in the evening. 19For a week, no yeast can be in your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it will be excluded from the community of Israel, foreign or native. 20Eat bread without yeast in all your houses.” Ex 12:14-20

21Moses called Israel’s elders,

“Butcher a Passover lamb for each family. 22Dip a bunch of hyssop in the blood that’s in the basin and apply it to the lintel and doorposts. Don’t anyone go outside till morning. 23The LORD will pass through to strike down the Egyptians. When he sees the blood on the lintel and doorposts, he’ll pass over and not let the destroyer come in to strike you. [24] 25When you go into the land the LORD gives you, observe this rite. 26When your children ask you what it means, 27tell them it’s a Passover sacrifice to the LORD, who “passed over” the Israelites’ houses when he struck the Egyptians.”

The people bowed low in worship 28and did what the LORD commanded Moses and Aaron.

Ex 12:21-28

29At midnight the LORD struck the firstborn in Egypt—the firstborn of Pharaoh on the throne, the firstborn of captives in the dungeon, the firstborn livestock. 30Pharaoh, his officers, and all the Egyptians got up during the night. There was a great outcry in Egypt; every home had someone die.

The Exodus

31He called for Moses and Aaron during the night,

“Get up! Get away from my people, you and the Israelites! Go worship the LORD like you’ve said. 32Take your flocks and herds. Go and bless me too.”

33The Egyptians urged the people to leave right away, “We’ll all be dead!”

34The people took their dough before it had yeast put in it, together with their kneading bowls tied up in the cloaks on their shoulders. 35The Israelites had done what Moses said and asked the Egyptians for silver and gold articles, and for clothes. 36The LORD had given the Egyptians a favorable attitude toward them, so they let them have what they asked for. That’s how they “plundered” the Egyptians. Ex 12:29-36

37The Israelites traveled from Rameses to Succoth, about 600,000 men on foot plus women and children. 38A mixed crowd of non-Israelites went with them along with flocks and herds, a very large number of livestock. 39The dough they brought out of Egypt they baked into flat cakes of bread without yeast. It had no yeast in it because they were driven out and couldn’t delay. They hadn’t prepared supplies.

40The Israelites lived in Egypt 430 years. 41At the end of 430 years to the day, the hosts of the LORD left Egypt. 42It’s a night Israelites observe to him throughout their generations for bringing them out of Egypt. Ex 12:37-42

Instructions for Passover

43The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

“This is the ordinance about the Passover: no foreigner can eat it, 44but every man’s slave purchased with money can eat it after you’ve circumcised him. 45No hired hand can eat it. 46Eat it in a single house. Don’t take any of the meat out of the house or break any of its bones. 47The whole community of Israel is to celebrate it. 48If a foreigner that lives with you wants to celebrate it, all the males that belong to him need to be circumcised. Then he can come to celebrate it. He’ll become a citizen of the country, but no uncircumcised person can eat it. 49The same law applies to a native and foreigner among you.”

50The Israelites did what the LORD commanded Moses and Aaron. 51That same day, he brought them out of Egypt. Ex 12:43-51

Dedication of the Firstborn

13:1The LORD told Moses, 2“Set aside every firstborn human and animal.”

3Moses told the people,

“Think back to today to when you came out of slavery in Egypt. With a strong hand the LORD took you out of here. Don’t eat anything with yeast in it. 4Today in the month Abib, you’re about to leave. 5When the LORD takes you to the territory of the Canaanite, Hittite, Amorite, Hivite, and Jebusite—the land he swore to your ancestors he’d give you, a land flowing with milk and honey—observe this rite in this month. 6Eat bread without yeast for a week. The seventh day, observe a feast to the LORD. 7Don’t have anything with yeast in it among you or in your territory. 8Tell your son that day, ‘It’s because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.’ 9It will serve as a sign to you on your hand, a reminder on your forehead, that the Law of the LORD may be in your mouth, because he brought you out with a tremendous demonstration of power. 10Keep this ordinance every year at its scheduled time. Ex 13:1-10

11“When the LORD takes you to the territory of the Canaanites, 12devote to him every woman’s male firstborn and the first male firstborn male of every animal you own. They belong to himY. 13But use a lamb to redeem every firstborn donkey. If you don’t redeem it, break its neck. Redeem every firstborn son.

14“When your son asks what this means, tell him, ‘With a great demonstration of power, the LORD brought us out of slavery in Egypt. 15When Pharaoh was stubborn about letting us go, the LORD killed every firstborn male of people and animals in Egypt; so I sacrifice the firstborn males to the LORD, but I redeem every firstborn son.’ 16It will serve as a reminder on your hand and bands on your forehead that the LORD brought you out of Egypt with a tremendous demonstration of power.” Ex 13:11-16

Crossing the Sea

17When Pharaoh did let the people go, God didn’t lead them on the road toward the Philistines, even though it was closer. He said, “They may change their minds when they see war, and head back to Egypt.” 18He led them through open country to the Red Sea, and they went up in martial array from Egypt. 19Moses took Joseph’s bones with him because he’d made the Israelites solemnly swear, “It’s certain that God take care of you, so carry my bones with you when you leave.” 20They set out from Succoth and camped in Etham at the edge of open country. 21The LORD went ahead of them in a pillar of cloud during the day, and in a pillar of fire at night to give them light. That way they could travel day or night. 22He never took away the pillar of cloud or pillar of fire. Ex 13:17-22

14:1The LORD said to Moses,

2“Tell the Israelites to turn around and camp at Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea across from Baal-zephon. 3Pharaoh will say you’re wandering aimlessly; the open country has boxed you in. 4That’s how I’ll harden his heart, and he’ll chase you. He and his army will honor me, and the Egyptians will know I’m the LORD.”

That’s what they did.

5When the king found out they’d left, he and his officials changed their minds, “What have we done, letting them leave from serving us?” 6He got his chariot ready and took his troops: 7600 select chariots as well as all the rest of Egypt’s chariots and their officers. 8As the Israelites were leaving boldly, 9the Egyptians chased them with Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, cavalry, and troops. They caught up with them camping by the sea beside Pi-hahiroth across from Baal-zephon. Ex 14:1-9

10As Pharaoh got close, the Israelites saw the Egyptians marching after them. They panicked and cried out to the LORD. 11They asked Moses,

“Was it because there weren’t any graves in Egypt that you’ve brought us out to die in the desert? Why did you bring us out of Egypt? 12Didn’t we tell you to just let us serve the Egyptians? It would’ve been better to serve them than die in the desert.”

13But Moses told them,

“Don’t be afraid! Stand by and watch the LORD deliver you. The Egyptians you see today you’ll never see again. 14He’ll fight for you while you just watch.” Ex 14:10-14

15Then the LORD told Moses,

“Why call out to me? Tell the Israelites to go forward. 16Lift up your staff and hold your hand out over the sea to separate it. The Israelites will go through it on dry seabed. 17I’ll harden the Egyptians’ hearts so they’ll go in after you; Pharaoh, his army, chariots, and cavalry. 18The Egyptians will know I’m the LORD when Pharaoh, his chariots, and cavalry honor me.”

19God’s angel that had been going ahead of Israel, moved behind them. The pillar of cloud moved from in front to in back. 20The cloud and the darkness stood between the camps of Egypt and Israel; yet it gave light at night so they wouldn’t come close to each other all night.

Ex 14:15-20

21Then Moses held his hand out over the sea, and the LORD pushed it back with a strong east wind all night. He separated the water and dried up the seabed. 22The Israelites went through the sea on dry seabed with the water like a wall on their left and right. 23 Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, and cavalry went in after them. 24Just before dawn, the LORD looked down on the Egyptian army through the pillar of fire and cloud and threw them into confusion. 25He made their chariot wheels wobble so they were hard to drive. The Egyptians shouted, “Retreat! The LORD’s fighting for Israel!” Ex 14:21-25

26The LORD told Moses, “Hold your hand out over the sea so the water will wash back over the Egyptians, their chariots, and cavalry.” 27The sea washed back to its normal position at daybreak while the Egyptians were fleeing right into it. He overthrew them in the sea. 28The water washed back over the chariots and cavalry. Not a one in Pharaoh’s entire army remained who followed the Israelites into the sea. [29] 30Israel saw them dead on the shore. 31When they saw the great power the LORD had used against the Egyptians, they feared him and trusted him and Moses. Ex 14:26-31

Moses’ Song of Triumph

15:1Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the LORD:

“I’ll sing to the LORD because he’s triumphed gloriously;

he’s thrown the horse and its rider into the sea.

2The LORD is my strength and song;

he is my salvation.

He’s my God, and I’ll praise him,

my ancestors’ God, and I’ll honor him.

3He’s a soldier;

his name is the LORD.

4He has thrown Pharaoh’s chariots and army into the Red Sea;

his elite officers have drowned.

5The depths covered them;

they sank like rocks.

6Your right hand, LORD, was majestic in its power;

it shattered the enemy.

7In your extreme excellence, you overthrew your opponents.

You sent out your burning anger

that consumed them like chaff.

8At the blast of your nostrils, the water piled up;

liquid water stood in a heap;

the depths of the sea congealed.

9The enemy said, ‘I’ll pursue,

I’ll overtake, I’ll divide up spoil;

I’ll satisfy my desire against them;

I’ll draw out my sword and destroy them.’

10You blew with your wind; the sea covered them;

they sank like lead in deep water.

11Who is like you, majestic in holiness,

awesome in praises, working wonders?

12You reached out your hand,

and the earth swallowed them.

13In your kindness you led the people you redeemed;

in your strength you guided them to your sacred abode.

14The nations have heard and tremble;

anguish has gripped the people in Philistia.

15The chiefs in Edom are scared;

the leaders in Moab tremble;

the people in Canaan melt away.

16Panic and dread have fallen on them;

by your great power they’re as still as stone,

until your people pass over,

until the people pass over that you’ve bought out.

17You’ll take them and plant them in the mountain

in your permanent possession,

where you’ve made yourself a place to live.

18The LORD will reign forever.” Ex 15:1-18

19Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, and cavalry went into the sea, and the LORD washed the water back over them; but the Israelites walked through on dry seabed. 20Miriam the prophetess, Aaron’s sister, took a tambourine and went out with the women with tambourines and dancing.

21She lined out a song to them,

“Sing to the LORD because he has triumphed gloriously;

he threw the horse and its rider into the sea.” Ex 15:19-21

22Moses led the Israelites from the Red Sea to the Wilderness of Shur. They traveled three days without finding water. 23When they got to Marah, the water was too “brackish” to drink. That’s why it was called Marah. 24The people complained to Moses, “What are we going to drink?” 25He called out to the LORD, and he showed him a tree. Moses threw it in the water and made it drinkable. The LORD made a statute and regulation to test them.

26“If you sincerely pay attention to me, do what I consider right, listen to my commandments, and keep my statutes, I won’t put any disease on you that I put on the Egyptians, because I’m your healer.”

27They came to Elim with its 12 springs and 70 date palms, and camped there beside the water.

Ex 15:22-27

Manna and Quail

16:1The fifteenth day, second month after they left Egypt, they went from Elim to the Wilderness of Sin, between Elim and Sinai, 2They criticized Moses and Aaron in the desert, 3“If only the LORD had killed us in Egypt when we sat by pots of meat and ate bread till we were full. You’ve brought us out to this empty place to starve to death.” Ex 16:1-3

4The LORD told Moses,

“I’ll rain bread from the sky, and they can go out each day and pick up a day’s supply. That will test whether they’ll follow my law: 5On the sixth day, they’ll prepare twice as much as on other days.”

6Moses and Aaron told them,

“In the evening you’ll know the LORD brought you out of Egypt. 7In the morning you’ll see his glory. He hears you complaining about him. Why are you complaining to us? 8The LORD will give you bread in the morning and meat in the evening. You’re complaining to him more than to us.”

9Moses said to Aaron, “Tell the whole community to come into the LORD’s presence; he’s heard their complaining.” 10As Aaron spoke to them, they looked toward the open country, and the glory of the LORD appeared in the cloud. 11He told Moses, 12“I’ve heard them complaining. Tell them they’ll eat their fill of bread in the morning and meat in the evening. They’ll know I’m the LORD their God.” Ex 16:4-12

13That evening quail came and covered the camp. In the morning, there was a coating of dew around the camp. 14When it evaporated, a fine flakey residue like frost lay all over the countryside. 15When the Israelites saw it, they asked one another what it was.

Moses told them,

“It’s the bread the LORD has given you to eat. 16He has commanded everyone to gather as much as they’ll eat, .11 bushel 1 omer for each one in their tent.”

17Some gathered a lot, some a little. 18When they measured it with .11 bushel 1 omer, the ones that had gathered a lot didn’t have any left over. The ones that had gathered a little had enough. Everybody gathered enough to eat. 19Moses told them not to leave any of it till morning. 20But some did, and it bred maggots and spoiled. Moses was mad at them. 21They gathered it each morning. When the sun got hot, it evaporated. Ex 16:13-21

22On the sixth day, they gathered twice as much, .22 bushel 2 omers apiece. When the leaders of the community came and told Moses, 23he said,

“The LORD said, ‘Tomorrow is a Sabbath observance, a holy Sabbath to me. Bake what you’ll bake and boil what you’ll boil. What’s left over set aside till morning.’”

24They did that, and it didn’t spoil or breed maggots.

25Moses said, “Eat it today; it’s a Sabbath to the LORD. 26Gather it six days; there won’t be any the seventh day.”

27Some people did go out anyway, but they didn’t find any.

28“How long will you refuse to follow my instructions? 29The LORD gave you the Sabbath; he’ll provide bread for two days on the sixth day. Stay home the seventh day.”

30The people rested that day. Ex 16:22-30

31Israel called it manna. It was white like coriander seed and tasted like honey-flavored wafers. 32-33Moses told Aaron,

“The LORD has said to keep .11 bushel 1 omer of it in a jar so later generations can see what he fed us in the desert. Set it in front of the LORD.”

34Aaron put it in front of the Testimony. 35The Israelites ate it for 40 years, till they came to the border of Canaan, where people lived. (36An omer is .11 bushels .1 ephah.) Ex 16:31-36

Water from the Rock

17:1Then the LORD told the community to travel from the Wilderness of Sin and camp at Rephidim. They didn’t have any water and 2complained to Moses, “Give us some water.”

“Why are you complaining to me and testing the LORD?”

3But they were thirsty, “Why bring us up from Egypt to let us, our little ones, and our livestock die from thirst?”

4Moses called out to the LORD, “What am I going to do with them? They’re about ready to stone me.”

5“Go stand in front of them. Take some of the elders and the staff you used to strike the Nile. 6I’ll stand in front of you on the rock at Horeb/Sinai. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it for them to drink.”

Moses did that. 7He named the place Massah and Meribah, because the Israelites “quarreled” with him and put the LORD on trial, “Is the LORD among us or not?” Ex 17:1-7

Defeating the Amalekites

8Amalek came to attack Israel at Rephidim, 9so Moses told Joshua, “Choose men and go fight Amalek. Tomorrow, I’ll station myself on the hill with God’s staff in my hand.” 10Joshua did that; Moses, Aaron, and Hur went to the top of the hill. 11When Moses held up his hand, Israel prevailed; when he let it come down, Amalek prevailed. 12But his hands got heavy; so they put a boulder under him to sit on; Aaron and Hur supported his hands. His hands were steady till sundown. 13Joshua outfought Amalek and his people with the sword.

14Then the LORD told Moses, “Write this in a scroll to remember. Tell Joshua I’ll completely wipe out the memory of Amalek.” 15Moses built an altar and named it The LORD Is My Banner [Yahveh-nissi]. 16He said, “The LORD has sworn he’ll be at war with Amalek endlessly.” Ex 17:8-16

Jethro Visits Moses

18:1Jethro/Reuel, priest in Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard what all God had done for Moses and his people in bringing them out of Egypt. 2He’d taken Moses’ wife Zipporah after Moses sent her away 3with her two sons Gershom (because he said, “I’ve been a ‘foreigner’ in a foreign land”) 4and Eliezer (because he said, “My father’s ‘God helped’ me and delivered me from Pharaoh’s sword”). 5-6Jethro/Reuel came to Moses with his wife and two sons, where Moses camped at the mountain of God. He sent word that he was bringing them. 7Moses went out to meet him, bowed and kissed him. They asked each other how they were doing and went into the tent. 8Moses told him what all the LORD had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, the hardships they’d had on the journey, and how the LORD had delivered them. 9Jethro/Reuel was overjoyed at the LORD’s goodness to Israel. 10He said,

“Bless the LORD that delivered you from Pharaoh and the Egyptians’ control. 11Now I know he’s greater than all other gods. He proved it when they dealt arrogantly against the people.”

12Jethro/Reuel brought a burnt offering and sacrifices for God, and Aaron came with the elders to eat a meal with him in God’s presence. Ex 18:1-12

13The next day Moses sat judging the people. They stood around him from morning till evening. 14When Jethro/Reuel saw what he was doing, he asked,

“What are you doing? Why sit to judge so many people by yourself from morning to evening?”

15“They come to me to ask God. 16When they have a dispute, I decide between them and teach them God’s laws and statues.”

17“That’s not good. 18You and the people will both wear out. Your job’s too big. 19Here’s some advice and God be with you. Be the people’s representative to God and bring the disputes to him. 20Then teach them the laws and statutes, how they’re supposed to act and what they’re supposed to do. 21Select capable men that respect God, truthful men that hate dishonest gain. Make them leaders of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens. 22Let them judge lesser matters. They can bring major disputes to you. It’ll be easier on you; they’ll help you bear the burden. 23If you do that—and God agrees—you’ll hold up under the work, and the people will go home satisfied.”

24Moses took his advice 25and chose capable men to lead thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens. 26They judged on a regular basis and dealt with smaller issues. More difficult disputes they took to Moses. 27Moses said goodbye to Jethro/Reuel, and he went back home. Ex 18:13-27

At Mount Sinai

19:1The same day of the third month after Israel left Egypt, they came to the Wilderness of Sinai. 2They’d set out from Rephidim and came to camp at the mountain. 3Moses went up to God, and the LORD called to him from the mountain,

“Tell Jacob’s house, 4‘You’vepl seen what I did to the Egyptians, how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to me. 5If you’ll obey me and keep my covenant, you’ll be my special possession among the nations. The whole world belongs to me, 6but you’ll be a kingdom of priests, a holy nation.’” Ex 19:1-6

7Moses called the elders and told them. 8They answered together, “We’ll do everything the LORD said.” Moses went back to tell him.

9He told Moses, “I’ll come to you in a dark cloud so the people can hear when I speak to you and believe in you permanently.

10“Go consecrate them today and tomorrow. Have them wash their clothes 11and be ready on the third day. That day I’ll come down on Mount Sinai where they can see. 12Set upf boundaries and say, ‘Don’t go up on the mountain or touch it. Executef whoever touches it. 13Don’t touchf them; stonef them or shootf them. Human or animal won’t live.’ When the ram’s horn sounds a long blast, the people are to come to the mountain.”

14Moses came down from the mountain, consecrated the people, and they washed their clothes. 15He told them to be ready the third day and not to have relations with women. Ex 19:7-15

16The third morning, thunder and lightning came. A dark cloud came over the mountain accompanied by a loud bugle blast. The people in the camp trembled. 17Moses brought them out of the camp to meet God at the foot of the mountain. 18Smoke covered Mount Sinai because the LORD came down on it in fire. Its smoke went up like from a furnace, and the whole mountain shook violently. 19When the bugle blast got louder and louder, Moses spoke to God, and he answered him with thunder. 20He came down on Mount Sinai and called Moses up to the top of it.

21“Go down and warn the people not to break through to stare and many of them perish. 22Have the priests that come near to me consecrate themselves so I don’t flare out against them.”

23Moses told the LORD, “The people can’t come up to Mount Sinai, because you warned us to set boundaries around it and consecrate it.”

24The LORD said, “Go down and bring Aaron up. Don’t let the priests or the people break through to come up to me, or I’ll flare out against them.”

25Moses went down and told them. Ex 19:16-25

The Ten Commandments

20:1Then God spoke,

2I am the LORD your God who brought you out of slavery in Egypt.

3Do not havef any god but me.

4Do not makef any carved image, any likeness of what is in the sky, on the ground, or in the water 5to worship or serve. I am an exclusive God. I visit the consequences of parents’ sins on their descendants for three or four generations that hate me. 6I am kind to thousands who love me and obey me. Ex 20:1-6

7Do not usef my name LORD as a byword. I will punish whoever does that.

8Remember to set the Sabbath day aside. 9Workf six days, 10but on the seventh day rest to me, the LORD your God. Do not workf that day—you, your son or daughter, male or female servant, livestock, or foreigner living among you. 11In six days I made earth and sky, the ocean and everything in them, and rested the seventh day. I have blessed the Sabbath day and set it apart.

12Honor your parents so you will live a long time in the land I give you.

13Do not commit murderf.

14Do not commit adulteryf.

15Do not stealf.

16Do not lief about other people.

17Do not covetf someone else’s house, his wife, male or female servant, ox or donkey—anything that is his.” Ex 20:7-17

18When people witnessed the thunder and lightning, the bugle sound and smoking mountain, they trembled and stood back a long way. 19They told Moses, “You speak to us, and we’ll listen. Don’t have God speak to us—so we won’t die.” 20Moses told them, “Don’t be afraid. God has come to test you, to make you respect him and not sin.” 21They stood a long way off while Moses approached the dark cloud where God was. Ex 20:18-21

The Proper Use of Altars

22The LORD told him to tell Israel,

“You’ve seen that I’ve spoken to you from the sky. 23Don’t makef other gods, silver or gold. 24Makef an altar out of dirt for me for sacrificing your burnt offerings, peace offerings, sheep and cattle. Everywhere I make my name remembered, I’ll come to you and bless you. 25If you build a stone altar for me, don’t buildf it with cut stones. You’ll desecrate it if you use a tool on it. 26Don’t climbf steps to my altar so you won’t show your nakedness on it. Ex 20:22-26

Laws About Slaves

21:1“Present these ordinances to the people.

2“If you buy a Hebrew slave, he’ll serve six years and go free on the seventh without pay. 3If he came alone, he’ll go out alone. If he has a wife, they’ll go out together. 4If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children belong to her master, and the slave will go out alone. 5But if the slave says he loves his master, his wife and children, and won’t leave them to be a free man, 6his master is to take him to the judges—to the door or doorpost—and pierce his ear with an awl. Then he’ll serve him permanently. Ex 21:1-6

7“If a man sells his daughter as a female slave, she’s not to go free as the male slaves do. 8If she’s not pleasing to her master who designated her for himself, he is to let her be bought back. He can’t sell her to a foreigner; he’d be treating her unfairly. 10If he marries another woman, he can’t reduce her food, clothing, or conjugal rights. 11If he won’t do these things for her, she’ll go out without being paid for. 9If he designates her for his son, he is to treat her like a daughter. Ex 21:7-11

12“Execute anyone that assaults and kills someone. 13If it was an accident, I’ll designate a safe place the slayer can flee to. 14But take even from the horns of my altar anyone that does premeditated murder.

15“Executef anybody that hits father or mother.

16“Executef kidnappers whether they hold in possession or sell the one they kidnapped.

17“Executef anybody that cusses at father or mother. Ex 21:12-17

18“If men are fighting and one strikes the other with a stone or his fist and he doesn’t die, but is laid up, 19if he gets up and walks around outside with his staff, then don’t punishf the one that hit him. He’ll pay for the man’s loss of time and take care of him till he fully recovers.

20“If a man beats his male or female slave with a rod and the slave dies, punish him. 21If the slave survives a day or so, there’s no punishment; he’s his property.

22“If men are fighting and hit a pregnant woman and she miscarries without further injury, fine him as her husband requires and the judges determine. 23But if there’s further harm, punishf life for life, 24eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, 25burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.

Ex 21:18-25

26“If a man hits his male or female slave in the eye and puts it out, he’ll free the slave for the eye. 27If he knocks out his male or female slave’s tooth, he’ll free the slave for the tooth.

28“If an ox gores a man or woman to death, stone it, don’t eat it, and don’t punish the owner. 29But if it has gored before and its owner knew it and didn’t pen it up, if it kills somebody, stone the ox and execute the owner. 30If a ransom is demanded from him, he’ll give whatever the relatives demand for loss of life. 31If it gores a son or daughter, the same rule applies. 32If it gores a male or female slave, the owner has to give the slave’s master 12 oz 30 shekels of silver. Stone the ox.

Ex 21:26-32

Laws About Restitution

33“If someone digs a pit without covering it up and an ox or donkey falls in it, 34the pit’s owner has to pay the animal’s owner for the loss, and the dead animal becomes his.

35“If one man’s ox kills another man’s ox, sell the live ox, divide the sale price, and divide the dead ox between them. 36If it was previously known to gore and its owner didn’t pen it up, the owner will pay ox for ox, and the dead animal will be his. Ex 21:33-36

22:1“If someone steals a cow or sheep, slaughters it or sells it, he has to pay five cows for one cow and four sheep for one sheep. 3bIf he doesn’t have anything, sell the thief for the theft. 4If what was stolen is found alive in the thief’s possession—cow, donkey, or sheep—the thief will pay double.

2If a thief gets caught breaking in at night and is struck and dies, the slayer won’t be held guilty of murder. 3aIf the theft happens during the day, the slayer will be guilty of murder.

5“If you overgraze a field or vineyard and let an animal loose that grazes in someone else’s field, you’ll pay compensation from the best of your own field and vineyard.

6“If your fire gets away from you and spreads to someone else’s thorn bushes, stacked grain, standing grain, or field, you’ll pay for damages. Ex 22:1-6

7“If you give someone money or goods for safekeeping, and it’s stolen from that person’s house, if caught, the thief will pay double. 8If no thief is caught, the judges will investigate if the other person took it.

9“For any breach of trust—for cow, donkey, sheep, clothing, or anything else a person owns—both parties will go to the judges. The one the judges find guilty will pay double to the other.

10“If you give someone a donkey, cow, sheep, or other animal for safekeeping and it dies, gets hurt, or wanders off unnoticed, 11the two of you will swear in the LORD’s presence that neither has taken it. You’ll accept the judge’s verdict, no compensation required. 12But if it was stolen, the thief will pay its owner for it. 13If wild animals got it, the remains are evidence, no compensation required. Ex 22:7-13

14“If you borrow something that gets injured or dies while its owner’s absent, you’ll make full compensation. 15If its owner’s present, you won’t make compensation. If you rented it, it came for the rent.

Laws About Social Justice

16“If a man seduces a virgin that’s not engaged and lies with her, he has to pay a dowry for her to be his wife. 17If her father refuses to give her to him, he’ll still pay money equal to the dowry for virgins.

18“Don’t let a sorceress live.

19“Execute whoever has sexual relations with an animal.

20“Execute whoever sacrifices to any god but the LORD.

21“Don’t wrong or mistreat a foreigner; you were foreigners in Egypt.

Ex 22:14-21

22“Don’t abuse a widow or orphan in any way. 23If you do and the person cries out to me, 24my anger will flare. I’ll kill you with the sword and make yoursg wives widows and your children orphans.

25“If you lend money to the poor among my people, don’t charge interest.

26If you take your neighbor’s cloak as a pledge, give it back before sundown. 27That may be the only covering your neighbor has to sleep in. When your neighbor cries out to me, I’ll listen because I’m gracious.

28“Don’t curse God or a ruler of your people.

29“Don’t put off giving your offerings from your crops or vintage.

“Give me your firstborn sons. 30Do the same with your cattle and sheep. After it’s with its mother for a week, give it to me on the eighth day.

31“You’ll be holy people to me; so don’t eat any animal torn to pieces in the pasture by wild animals. Feed it to the dogs. Ex 22:22-31

23:1“Don’t pass on false rumors, join sinners in giving malicious testimony, 2or follow the crowd in doing something bad. In a dispute, don’t join other people to pervert justice. 3Don’t be partial toward a poor person in a dispute.

4“If you run onto your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering around, return it. 5If you see a donkey that belongs to someone that hates you lying helpless under its load, free it. Ex 23:1-5

6“Don’t pervert justice for your needy neighbor in a dispute.

7“Avoid making false charges. Don’t execute an innocent or good person. I won’t acquit you.

8“Don’t take a bribe; it blinds the clear-sighted and undercuts what good people are trying to do.

9“Don’t oppress a foreigner; you know what it’s like to be one; you were foreigners in Egypt.

Laws About Sabbaths and Festivals

10“Plant and harvest your ground for six years. 11Let it lie fallow the seventh year so the needy among your people can eat what grows volunteer. Whatever they leave, the wild animals can have. Do the same thing with your vineyard and olive trees.

12“Work six days. On the seventh, stop working so your ox and donkey can rest, so the son of your female slave and the foreigner that’s with you can refresh themselves. 13Pay attention to everything I’ve told you.

“Don’t even say the names of other gods. Ex 23:6-13

14“Celebrate three festivals to me each year. 15Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread. Eat bread without yeast for a week at the scheduled time in the month Abib, the month you came out of Egypt. Nobody is to come to me empty-handed. 16Observe the Festival of the Harvest, the first part of the harvest from what you sow. Observe the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year at harvest time. 17Three times a year all males are to appear in front of the Lord GOD.

18“Don’t offer the blood of my sacrifice with bread containing yeast. The fat from my feast is not to remain till morning. 19Bring the best of the first harvest from your ground to the house of the LORD your God.

“Don’t boil a kid in its mother’s milk. Ex 23:14-19

Conquest of Canaan Promised

20“I’ll send an angel to take you safely to the place I’ve designated. 21Be sure to obey him. He won’t pardon your sins because he wears my name. 22If you sincerely obey him in everything I say, I’ll be an enemy to your enemies, an adversary to your adversaries. 23My angel will take you to the Amorite, Hittite, Perizzite, Canaanite, Hivite, and Jebusite; and I’ll destroy them. Ex 23:20-23

24“Don’t worship and serve other gods or do what they do. Overthrow them completely and break their sacred pillars to pieces. 25Serve the LORD your God, and he’ll bless your bread and water, and keep you from getting sick. 26There won’t be any miscarriages or barrenness in your country, and you’ll have long lives. 27I’ll spread fear in front of you, and throw into confusion the people you invade, and make your enemies flee. 28I’ll send hornets ahead of you to drive out the Hivites, Canaanites, and Hittites. 29I won’t drive them out in a single year; the land would grow wild and wild animals would take over. 30I’ll drive them out little by little till you gain possession of it all and make it productive.

31“I’ll set your boundary from the Red Sea to the sea beside the Philistines, from the desert to the River Euphrates. I’ll deliver the people to you to drive out. 32Don’t make any treaty with them or their gods. 33Don’t let them live in your country and end up making you sin against me. If you serve their gods, they’ll be a snare to you.” Ex 23:24-33

The Covenant Confirmed

24:1Then the LORD told Moses, “Come up to me and worship at a distance—you, Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and the 70 elders. 2Yousg alone will approach me; the others and the community can’t approach me.”

3Moses recounted to the people the LORD’s ordinances, and they answered together, “We’ll do what he’s said.”

4Moses wrote them down. Then he got up early and built an altar at the foot of the mountain with 12 pillars for the 12 tribes. 5He sent young men to offer burnt offerings and sacrifice young bulls as peace offerings. 6Moses put half of the blood in basins and sprinkled the other half on the altar. 7He read the covenant to the people. They said, “We’ll do what the LORD has said.” 8Moses sprinkled the blood on them, “This is the blood of the covenant the LORD has made with you.” Ex 24:1-8

9Then Moses went up with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and the 70 elders; 10and they saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was what looked like an expanse of sapphire as clear as the sky. 11Yet he didn’t reach out against the nobles of Israel; they looked at him and ate and drank.

12The LORD told Moses, “Come up to me on the mountain and stay here. I’ll give you the stone tablets with the Law I’ve commanded and written to instruct them.” 13Moses and Joshua his assistant went up on the mountain of God. 14But he told the elders, “Wait here till we get back. Aaron and Hur are with you. If anybody has a legal problem, go to them.” 15Then he went up on the mountain, and the cloud covered it. 16The LORD’s brightness rested on Mount Sinai for six days. On the seventh day, he called to Moses out of the cloud. 17To the people of Israel the LORD’s brightness looked like a flagrant fire on the mountain. 18Moses went into the cloud as he climbed the mountain and was there for 40 days. Ex 24:9-18

Contributions for the Tabernacle

25:1The LORD said to him,

2“Tell the Israelites to take up an offering for me as their hearts move them: 3gold, silver, and bronze; 4blue, purple, and scarlet material; fine linen, goat hair, 5rams’ skins dyed red, dolphin skins, acacia wood, 6olive oil for lighting, spices for anointing oil and fragrant incense, 7onyx stones and setting stones for the ephod and pouch. 8Have them build a sanctuary so I can live among them. 9Build the Tabernacle and its furniture like I show you. Ex 25:1-9

The Ark of the Covenant

10“Have them build an Ark out of acacia wood 45 x 27 x 27ins high. 11Overlay it with pure gold inside and out and make a gold molding around it. 12Cast four gold rings for it and fasten them to its four bottom corners.

13“Make poles out of acacia wood overlaid with gold. 14Put them into the rings on each side of the Ark for carrying it, 15and leave them in the rings.

16“The Testimony I’m going to give you, put in the Ark.

17“Make a mercy seat out of pure gold 45 x 27 x 27ins.

18“Make two cherubs out of hammered gold for the two ends of the mercy seat. 19Make each of them one piece 20with wings spread upward and facing each other. 21Put the mercy seat on top of the Ark. 22I’ll meet you above the mercy seat. From between the two cherubs, I’ll tell you the commandments to give Israel.

Ex 25:10-22

The Table for the Bread of Presence

23“Make a table out of acacia wood 36 x 18 x 27ins high. 24Overlay it with pure gold and put a gold border around it. 25Make a rim around it a hand’s width and a gold border for the rim. 26Make four gold rings and put them on the four bottom corners. 27Put the rings close to the rim to hold the poles that carry the table. 28Make the poles out of acacia wood overlaid with gold.

29“Make for it pure-gold dishes, jars, and bowls for pouring liquid offerings.

30“Keep the Bread of the Presence in front of me on the table at all times.

Ex 25:23-30

The Golden Lampstand

31“Make a lampstand out of pure gold with a base and shaft. Its cups, bulbs, and flowers will be one piece. 32It’ll have 6 branches, 3 on a side. 333 cups shaped like almond blossoms will be on one branch—a bulb and flower, and 3 cups shaped like almond blossoms on the other branch—a bulb and flower, 34and on the lampstand 4 cups shaped like almond blossoms—its bulbs and flowers. 35Put a bulb under each of the three pairs of branches—coming out of it. That makes 6 branches coming out of the lampstand. 36The whole thing will be one piece of hammered pure gold. 37Make its lamps so they shine forward. 38Its snuffers and their trays will be pure gold. 39Make it from 75½ lbs a talent of pure gold, with all its utensils. 40Be sure to make them in the design I showed you on the mountain. Ex 25:31-40

The Tabernacle

26:1“Make the Tabernacle with 10 curtains of finely twined linen and blue, purple, and scarlet material. Make them with cherubs, a skilled weaver’s work. 2All the curtains will be 42 x 6ft. 3Make 2 sets of 5 joined curtains. 4Make blue loops on the edge of the outer curtain in the first set; do the same with the second set. 5Make 50 loops in the one curtain, and 50 loops on the edge of the second set. Put the loops across from each other. 6Make 50 gold clasps and join the curtains together with them so the Tabernacle makes a unit. Ex 26:1-6

7-8“Make 11 curtains out of goats’ hair for a covering over the Tabernacle. Make them 45 x 6ft. 9Join 5 curtains in one set, and 6 curtains in another set. Double the sixth curtain at the front of the tent. 10Make 50 loops on the edge of the outside curtain in the two sets. 11Make 50 bronze clasps, put them into the loops, and join the tent together to make one unit. 12The overlapping part that’s left over in the curtains of the tent—the half curtain—will lap over the back of the Tabernacle. 13The 18ins on each side of what’s left over in the length of the curtain, will lap over the back of the sides of the Tabernacle to cover each side. 14Make a covering for the tent out of rams’ and dolphin skins dyed red. Ex 26:7-14

15“Make vertical boards out of acacia wood for the Tabernacle. 16Make them 15ft x 27in. 17With all the boards, make a mortise and tenon on each board, so they fit together. 18Make 20 boards for the south side of the Tabernacle. 19Make 40 silver bases under the 20 boards, 2 bases under each board for its mortise and tenon. 20-21Do the north side of the Tabernacle the same as the south side. 22For the back of the Tabernacle, the west end, make 6 boards. 23For the two back corners make 2 boards. 24They’ll double on top of each other; together they’ll be complete to the top to the first ring. Make both corners alike. 25There will be 8 boards with their 16 silver bases, 2 bases under each board. Ex 26:15-25

26“Make 5 braces out of acacia wood for the boards on one side of the Tabernacle, 275 braces for the boards on the other side, and 5 braces for the rear, west end. 28The middle brace in the center of the boards will go from one end to the other. 29Overlay the boards with gold and make their gold rings into holders for the braces. Overlay the braces with gold too. 30Build the Tabernacle by the plan I showed you on the mountain.” Ex 26:26-30

31“Make a curtain out of blue, purple, and scarlet material and finely twined linen. Put cherubs on it, a skilled weaver’s work. 32Hang it on four posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, having gold hooks, and set on four silver sockets. 33Hang the curtain under the clasps and bring the Ark of Testimony inside the curtain that separates the Holy Place from the Holy of Holies. 34Mount the mercy seat on the Ark. 35Outside the curtain, set the table on the north side of the Tabernacle and the lampstand on the south side. 36For the doorway of the tent, make a screen out of blue, purple, and scarlet material and fine linen, a weaver’s work. 37For the screen, make five posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, having gold hooks, and set on 5 bronze sockets. Ex 26:31-37

The Bronze Altar

27:1“Make an altar out of acacia wood, 7½ x 7½ x 4½ft high 2with a horn on each corner. Make them one piece with the altar and overlaid with bronze.

3“Make bronze pails for removing the ashes, bronze shovels, basins, forks, and fire pans.

4“Make a network of bronze grating for it, and on the network put four bronze rings at the corners. 5Put the grating under the ledge of the altar so it reaches halfway up the altar.

6“For the altar make acacia poles overlaid with bronze. 7Insert the poles into the rings on the two sides of the altar for carrying it. 8Make it hollow with planks like you saw on the mountain. Ex 27:1-8

The Court of the Tabernacle

9“Make a court for the Tabernacle. Its south side will have curtains made out of finely twined linen 150ft long for one side. 10It’ll have 20 posts with 20 bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts will be silver. 11Make the north side of the court the same way. 12The west end of the court will have 75ft of curtains with 10 posts with their 10 bases. 13The east end of the court will be 75ft wide. 14The curtains for one side of the entrance will be 22½ft long with 3 posts and their 3 bases. 15Make the other side of the entrance the same way. 16The entrance to the court will be a screen 30ft wide woven out of blue, purple, and scarlet material with finely twined linen; with 4 posts and their 4 bases. 17The posts around the court will have silver bands with silver hooks and bronze bases. 18The court will be 150 x 75ft with curtains 7½ft high and bronze bases under its posts. 19Make out of bronze the Tabernacle’s utensils of service, its pegs, and the pegs in the court. Ex 27:9-19

Oil for the Lamp

20“Charge the people to bring pure oil from pressed olives for a continually burning light in the lamp. 21In the Tent of Meeting, outside the curtain in front of the Testimony, Aaron and his sons will keep the light burning from evening to morning in front of the LORD—a permanent statute for Israel’s descendants. Ex 27:20-21

The Priestly Garments

28:1“From the Israelites, have your brother Aaron and his sons Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar come to you to serve as priests. 2Make holy vestments for Aaron, glorious and beautiful. 3Talk to skilled artisans that I’ve given wisdom for making them and consecrate them for performing service to me. 4Make these vestments for Aaron and his sons: a pouch, ephod, robe, tunic made out of checkered work, a turban, and a sash. 5The artisans are to use gold; blue, purple, and scarlet material; and fine linen. Ex 28:1-5

6“They’re to make the ephod out of gold; blue, purple, and scarlet material; and finely twined linen. 7It will have 2 shoulder pieces joined to its 2 ends. 8The skillfully woven band on it will have the same design and material. 9Take 2 onyx stones and engrave the names of Israel’s sons on them, 106 per stone in their birth order. 11Like a jeweler engraves a signet, engrave the 2 stones with their names, and set them in delicate gold settings. 12Put the 2 stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod. Aaron will carry them on his two shoulders as a memorial of the people of Israel. 13Make delicate gold settings 14and 2 pure gold chains. Make them out of twined cordage and put the corded chains on the delicate settings. Ex 28:6-14

15“Make a Pouch of Judgment, an artisan’s work. Make its design match the ephod—with blue, purple, scarlet material, and finely twined linen. 16It will be 9ins 1 span square and folded double. 17Mount four rows of gemstones on it: a ruby, topaz, and emerald on the first row; 18a turquoise, sapphire, and diamond on the second; 19a jacinth, agate, and amethyst on the third; 20and a beryl, onyx, and jasper on the fourth—all set in delicate gold decorations. 21Set the precious stones in the birth order of Israel’s 12 sons. Engrave their names as on a seal. 22On the pouch put pure gold chains of twined cordage. 23Put 2 gold rings on the 2 ends of the pouch, 24and put the 2 gold cords on the rings. 25Put the other 2 ends of the cords on the 2 decorative settings and attach them to the shoulder pieces at the front of the ephod. 26Make 2 gold rings and put them on the 2 ends of the pouch, on the edge of the inner side of the ephod. 27Make 2 gold rings and put them at the bottom of the 2 shoulder pieces of the ephod, on the front close to where it joins together, above the skillfully woven band. 28Use a blue cord to tie the rings of the pouch to the ephod rings, so it will be on the woven band of the ephod, and the pouch won’t come loose from the ephod. 29Aaron will carry the names of Israel’s sons in the Pouch of Judgment over his heart when he goes into the Holy Place, for a memorial in front of the LORD continually. 30Put the Urim and Thummim in the pouch. Ex 28:15-30

31“Make the whole ephod robe blue 32with an opening for the head in the middle. Around the opening put an edging made of woven work—as with a coat of mail—so it won’t tear. 33-34All around the hem, put pomegranates made out of blue, purple, and scarlet material; and alternate gold bells with them. 35Aaron will wear it when he performs service, and other people can hear it tinkling when he goes in and leaves the Holy Place in case he dies while he’s in front of the LORD. Ex 28:31-35

36“Make a pure gold plate and engrave it ‘Holy to the LORD’—as on a seal. 37Use a blue cord to fasten it to the front of the turban. 38Aaron will always wear it on his forehead to take away the sin from all holy gifts the Israelites consecrate, to make them acceptable to the LORD. 39Weave the tunic out of checkered work of fine linen and make a turban and sash out of fine linen.

Ex 28:36-39

40“For Aaron’s sons make tunics, sashes, and caps, bright and beautiful. 41Put them on him and his sons; anoint, ordain, and consecrate them to serve me as priests. 42Make linen pants to cover their bare skin, pants that reach from their waist to their thighs. 43They’ll wear them in the Tent of Meeting and when they go to the altar to perform service in the Holy Place so they won’t incur guilt and die—a permanent statute for Aaron and his descendants. Ex 28:40-43

Consecration of the Priests

29:1“This is how you’re to consecrate them as priests to me: take a young bull, two rams without blemish, 2bread without yeast, and cakes mixed with olive oil, wafers without yeast anointed with oil and made out of fine wheat flour. 3Put them in a basket and bring them with the bull and two rams. 4Take Aaron and his sons to the door and give them a bath. 5Put on Aaron the tunic, ephod robe, ephod, chest pouch, and skillfully woven band of the ephod. 6Put the turban on his head, and the holy crown on the turban. 7Then pour the anointing oil on his head. 8Put tunics on his sons. 9Put sashes around him and his sons and tie the caps on them. They’ll exercise the priesthood by permanent statute. Ex 29:1-9

10“Then take the bull to the LORD at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting 11and slaughter it. 12Put some of its blood on the horns of the altar with your finger. Pour out the rest at the base of the altar. 13Take the fat that covers the entrails and the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys and the fat that’s on them, and offer them up in smoke on the altar. 14Burn the meat, hide, and manure outside the camp as a sin offering. Ex 29:10-14

15“Have Aaron and his sons put their hands on one ram’s head. 16Slaughter it and sprinkle its blood around the altar. 17Then butcher it, wash its entrails and legs, and put them on the altar with the pieces and head. 18Offer up in smoke the whole ram on the altar—a burnt offering to the LORD, a pleasing aroma.

19“Have Aaron and his sons put their hands on the other ram’s head. 20Slaughter it, put some of its blood on Aaron and his sons’ right earlobes, right thumbs, and right big toes. Sprinkle the rest around on the altar. 21Take some of the blood on the altar and some of the anointing oil, and sprinkle it on Aaron, his sons, and their vestments. That will consecrate them and their vestments. 22Take the fat from the ram—fat from its tail, fat that covers the entrails and the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys and the fat on them, and the right thigh (it’s a ram for ordination)—23one cake of bread, one cake of bread mixed with olive oil, and one wafer from the basket of bread without yeast that sits in front of the LORD. 24Put them in the hands of Aaron and his sons, and wave them as a wave offering in front of the LORD. 25Take them and offer them up in smoke on the altar as a burnt offering for an aroma pleasing to the LORD. Ex 29:15-25

26“Then take the breast of Aaron’s ram for the ordination, and wave it as a wave offering; it will be your portion. 27Consecrate the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the heave offering that was waved and offered from the ram of ordination, from the one that was for Aaron and the one that was for his sons. 28It will be for Aaron and his sons their permanent portion from the Israelites. It’s a heave offering from the Israelites’ peace offerings, that is, their heave offering to the LORD.

29“Aaron’s holy vestments will go to his descendants so they can be anointed and ordained in them. 30For one week his descendant that succeeds him as priest will wear them when he enters the Tent of Meeting to perform service in the Holy Place. Ex 29:26-30

31“Take the ram for the ordination and boil its meat in a holy place. 32At the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, Aaron and his sons will eat the ram’s meat and the bread in the basket. 33They’ll eat those things by which atonement was made at their ordination and consecration. A layman can’t eat them because they’re holy. 34Burn any meat or bread that’s left over till morning. Ex 29:31-34

35“This is how you’ll ordain Aaron and his sons over the course of a week. 36Each day offer a bull as a sin offering for atonement, to purify the altar when you atone for it. Anoint it to consecrate it. 37For 7 days atone for the altar to consecrate it. Then it will be most holy; whoever touches it will be holy.

Ex 29:35-37

38“Offer on the altar two one-year-old lambs each day, 39one in the morning and another in the evening. 40Mix 4½ pecks 1 ephah of fine flour with 3pts ¼ hin of pressed olive oil and 3pts ¼ hin of wine for a liquid offering for the lamb. 41Offer the other lamb in the evening, like the grain offering in the morning, with its liquid offering for a pleasing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD. 42It will be a continual burnt offering throughout your generations at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting in front of me. I’ll meet you there and speak to you. 43I’ll meet there with the descendants of Israel, and it will be consecrated by my glory. 44I’ll consecrate the Tent of Meeting and the altar, as well as Aaron and his sons to minster as priests to me. 45I’ll live among the descendants of Israel and be their God. 46They’ll know I’m the LORD their God who brought them out of Egypt to live among them. Ex 29:38-46

The Altar of Incense

30:1“Make an altar out of acacia wood as a place to burn incense: 218 x 18 x 36in with horns in one piece with it. 3Overlay it with pure gold on its sides, top, and horns; make a molding around it. 4On two sides put two gold rings under its molding on opposite ends for carrying it. 5Make the poles out of acacia wood overlaid with gold. 6Put the altar in front of the curtain that’s near the Ark of Testimony—in front of the mercy seat that’s on top of the Ark—where I’ll meet you. 7-8Aaron will burn fragrant incense on it every morning and evening and trim the lamps. Burn incense to me continuously throughout your generations. 9Don’t offer foreign incense, burnt offering, or meal offering on this altar. Don’t pour any liquid offering on it. 10Throughout your generations, Aaron will make atonement on its horns once a year with the blood of the sin offering. It’s most holy to me. Ex 30:1-10

Atonement Money

[11] 12“When you take a census of the Israelites, each one will give a ransom for himself to the LORD so there won’t be any plague among them. 13-14Each person that’s counted from 20 years up will give .2 oz a half-shekel of the sanctuary as a contribution to the LORD (20 gerahs to a shekel). 15Rich and poor will contribute the same .2 oz a half-shekel of to make atonement. 16Give it for the service of the Tent of Meeting as a memorial to the LORD. Ex 30:11-16

Bronze Basin for Washing

[17] 18“Make a bronze laver with a bronze base, put it between the Tent of Meeting and the altar, and put water in it. 19Aaron and his sons will wash their hands and feet from it 20when they go into the Tent of Meeting so they won’t die when they approach the altar to offer up in smoke a sacrifice by fire to me. 21That will be an ongoing statute for Aaron and his descendants. Ex 30:17-21

Anointing Oil

[22] 23“Take the finest spices: 12½ lbs 500 shekels of liquid myrrh, 6¼ lbs 250 shekels of fragrant cinnamon, 6¼ lbs 250 shekels of fragrant cane, 2412½ lbs 500 shekels of cassia, and 1½ gallons hin of olive oil. 25From them, make a holy anointing oil, a perfume mixture, a perfumer’s work. 26With it, anoint the Tent of Meeting, the Ark of Testimony, 27the table and its utensils, the lampstand and its utensils, the altar of incense, 28the altar of burnt offering and its instruments, and the laver and its stand. 29Consecrate them so they’ll be holy. Whatever touches them will be holy. 30Anoint Aaron and his sons to consecrate them for performing service to me as priests. 31Tell the Israelites, ‘This will be an anointing oil holy to me throughout your generations. 32Don’t make any oil in the same proportions or pour it on anybody else. It’s holy, reserved for you. 33Whoever mixes any oil like it or puts any of it on a layman, will be excluded from the community.’” Ex 30:22-33

Anointing Oil

34“Take the spices stacte, onycha, galbanum, and pure frankincense in equal amounts 35to make incense, a perfumer’s work—salted, pure, and holy. 36Beat some of it very fine and put part of it in front of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting, where I’ll meet you. It will be most holy to you. 37Any incense you make for yourselves can’t have the same proportions. My incense will be exclusively for the LORD. 38Whoever makes any perfume like it will be excluded from the community. Ex 30:34-38

Bezalel and Oholiab

31[:1] 2“I’ve specifically called Bezalel son of Uri son of Hur, from the tribe of Judah. 3I’ve filled him with my spirit in wisdom, understanding, and knowledge in all kinds of craftsmanship

4to make artistic designs for work in gold, silver, and bronze,

5in cutting stones for settings and

carving in wood.

6I’ve appointed with him Oholiab son of Ahisamach from the tribe of Dan. In the hearts of everybody that’s skilled, I’ve put the skill to make everything:

7the Tent of Meeting,

the Ark of Testimony,

the mercy seat on top of it,

the furniture in the tent,

8the table and its utensils,

the pure gold lampstand with its utensils,

the altar of incense,

9the altar of burnt offering with its utensils,

the laver with its stand,

10the holy woven vestments for Aaron and his sons for carrying out

their priesthood,

11the anointing oil,

and the fragrant incense for the Holy Place.

They’re to make them the way I told you. Ex 31:1-11

The Sabbath

[12] 13“Tell the Israelites to observe my Sabbaths. They’re a sign between you and me throughout your generations so you can know I’m the LORD who sanctifies you. 14The Sabbath is set aside for you. Execute anybody that profanes it. Exclude from the community whoever works on it. 15Work for six days, but the seventh day will be a complete rest set aside to me. 16Israelites will observe the Sabbath throughout their generations as a continuing covenant. 17It’s a permanent sign between them and me, because I made earth and sky in six days, but stopped working on the seventh day and was refreshed.”

18When God finished speaking to him on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two stone tablets of the Testimony that God wrote with his own finger. Ex 31:12-18

The Golden Calf

32:1When Moses hadn’t come down from the mountain for a long time, the people gathered around Aaron and said, “Make us a god to go ahead of us. We don’t know what’s happened to this Moses that brought us out of Egypt.”

2Aaron said, “Take the gold earrings off of your wives, sons, and daughters, and bring them to me.” [3] 4He took them, and with a graving tool shaped a molten calf.

They said, “This is your god, Israel, that brought you out of Egypt!”

5When Aaron saw it, he built an altar in front of it and made a proclamation, “Tomorrow will be a feast to the LORD.” 6They got up early, offered burnt offerings, and brought peace offerings. The people sat down to gluttony and got up to revelry. Ex 32:1-6

7The LORD told Moses,

“Go down right now. The people have corrupted themselves. 8They’ve turned aside so soon from what I commanded them. They’ve made a molten calf and worshiped it, sacrificed to it, and said, ‘This is your god, Israel, that brought you out of Egypt!’ 9These are stubborn people. 10Let me alone so my anger can burn against them and destroy them. I’ll make a great nation out of you.”

11Moses asked the LORD his God,

“Why does your anger burn against the people you brought out of Egypt with such power? 12Why should the Egyptians be able to say you brought them out to kill them in the mountains and destroy them from the earth? Turn from your furious anger and change your mind about harming them. 13Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, the servants you swore to by yourself, ‘I’ll multiply your descendants like stars in the sky, and this land I’ve talked about I’ll give your descendants as a permanent inheritance.’”

14So the LORD changed his mind about harming them. Ex 32:7-14

15Moses went down the mountain, carrying the two tablets of the Testimony, engraved on both sides 16with God’s writing. 17When Joshua heard the people shouting, he told Moses it sounded like war in the camp.

18But Moses said, “That’s not the shout of triumph or defeat. I hear singing.”

19As soon as he got close to the camp, he saw the calf and the dancing, and his anger flared. He threw the tablets down and shattered them at the foot of the mountain. 20He took the calf they’d made, burned it, and ground it to powder. He scattered it on the water and made the people drink it. Ex 32:15-20

21Moses asked Aaron, “What did these people do to get you to bring such a great sin on them?”

22“Don’t be furious with me. You know they’re prone to evil. 23They told me, ‘Make us a god to go ahead of us. We don’t know what’s happened to this Moses who brought us out of Egypt.’ 24I told them, ‘Whoever has gold, take it off.’ They gave it to me; I threw it into the fire, and this calf came out.” Ex 32:21-24

25Moses saw that the people were out of control (Aaron had let them get out of control to be ridiculed by their enemies). 26So he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me!” Levi’s descendants went to him,

27He said,

“The LORD God of Israel, says, ‘Every one of you, put a sword on your thigh, and go back and forth from gate to gate in the camp. Each man, slay your brother, friend, or neighbor.’”

28The Levites did that and slew about 3,000 men that day. 29Then Moses said, “Dedicate yourselves to the LORD (because every man has been against his son and brother) so he can bless you today.” Ex 32:25-29

30The next day, Moses told the people, “You’ve committed a serious sin. I’m going up to the LORD. Maybe I can atone for you.” 31He went back to the LORD, and said,

“The people have committed a serious sin by making a god out of gold. 32But if you will, forgive them. If not, erase me out of your scroll!”

33The LORD told him,

“The ones that have sinned against me are the ones I’ll erase out of my scroll. 34Go lead them where I said. My angel will go ahead of you. When I punish, I’ll punish them for their sin.”

35The LORD struck the people because of what they’d done with the calf Aaron made.

Ex 32:30-35

33:1The LORD told Moses,

“Leave here and go to the land I swore I’d give the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. 2I’ll send an angel ahead of you to drive out the Canaanite, Amorite, Hittite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite. 3Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. I won’t go up with you, because you’re stubborn, so I won’t destroy you on the way.”

4When the people heard that discouraging word, they went into mourning; nobody put on jewelry. 5The LORD had told Moses, “Tell them, ‘You’re being stubborn. If I’d go up among you for a moment, I’d destroy you. So take off your jewelry so I’ll know what I’m to do with you.’” 6They didn’t wear jewelry from Mount Horeb/Sinai on. Ex 33:1-6

The Tent of Meeting

7Moses would pitch a tent a good distance outside the camp—what he called The Tent of Meeting. Anybody that wanted to consult the LORD would go out to it. 8Whenever Moses went out, everybody would stand at the entrance of his tent and watch him till he went into the tent. 9Then the pillar of cloud would come down and stand at the entrance, and the LORD would talk to him. 10When people saw the pillar, they would worship at their own tents. 11The LORD would speak to Moses directly, the way you talk to a friend. When Moses would come back to the camp, his assistant Joshua son of Nun, a young man, would stay behind at the tent. Ex 33:7-11

Moses Sees the Glory of the LORD

12Then Moses told the LORD,

“You tell me to bring the people up, but you haven’t let me know who you’ll send with me. You’ve said you knew me by name, and you’ve been gracious to me. 13Let me know your ways so I can know you and please you. Consider this nation your people.

14“My presence will go with yousg, and I’ll give you rest.”

15“If you don’t go with us, don’t take us away from here. 16How can your people and I know we’re being pleasing to you? Isn’t it by having you with us so we can tell the difference between ourselves and other people?” Ex 33:12-16

17“I’ll do what you’ve asked, because you’re pleasing to me, and I know you by name.”

18“Show me your glory.”

19“I’ll make my goodness pass by in front of you, and show you who I am. I’ll decide who to give grace to and who to show mercy to. 20But you can’t see my face. Nobody can see me and live! 21Here’s a place beside me; stand on that rock. 22While my glory is passing by, I’ll put you in a crevice in the rock and cover you with my hand till I’m past. 23Then I’ll take my hand away, and you can see my back; but you won’t see my face.” Ex 33:17-23

The New Stone Tablets

34:1The LORD told Moses,

“Carve out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I’ll write on them what was on the tablets you shattered. 2Be ready by morning. Come up to the top of Mount Sinai and present yourself 3alone. Nobody can be on the mountain. Flocks and herds can’t graze by it.”

4He carved two stone tablets like the first ones, got up early, and took them up to Mount Sinai. 5The LORD came down in a cloud and stood there with him as he called on the LORD. 6He passed by Moses and proclaimed,

“The LORD, the LORD God, merciful and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in kindness and faithfulness;7who shows kindness to thousands; forgives iniquity, transgression, and sin; yet doesn’t leave guilty people unpunished, and visits the consequences of parents’ sins on their descendants for three or four generations!”

8Moses immediately bowed to the ground in worship.

9“LORD, if I’m pleasing to you, go along with us, even though we’ve been so stubborn. Pardon our sin and take us as your own.” Ex 34:1-9

10God said,

“I’ll make a covenant. I’ll perform miracles for the people that haven’t been done in any nation. The people you live with will see my working; it’ll be terrifying. 11Be sure to observe what I’m commanding you today; and I’ll drive out the Amorite, Canaanite, Hittite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite in front of you.

12“Don’t make any treaty with the people where you’re going. That would be a snare among you. 13Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, cut down their Asherah poles. 14(Don’t worship any other god, because I am an ‘exclusive’ God. Exclusive is my name.) 15Destroy those things so you won’t be making treaties with them, carrying on prostitution with their gods, sacrificing to them, eating their sacrifices with them—16so you won’t be taking their daughters for your sons, and their daughters carry on prostitution with their gods and get your sons to do it.

17“Don’t make molten gods.” Ex 34:10-17

18“Observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread. For a week at the specified time in the month Abib, eat bread without yeast like I told you. That’s the month you came out of Egypt.

19“The first male offspring belongs to me, including the first male offspring of your cattle and sheep. 20With a lamb, redeem the first offspring of a donkey. If you don’t redeem it, break its neck. Redeem firstborn sons. None of them are to appear in front me empty-handed.” Ex 34:18-20

21“Work six days, but rest on the seventh, even during plowing time and harvest.

22“At year’s end, celebrate the Festival of Weeks, that is, the first part of the wheat harvest, the Festival of Ingathering.

23“Three times a year, males are to appear in my presence. 24I’ll drive out nations in front of you and enlarge your territory. Nobody is to covet your land when you go up three times a year to appear in my presence.

25“Don’t offer the blood of my sacrifice with bread containing yeast or leave the Passover sacrifice over till morning.

26“Bring the first of your ground’s produce to my house.

“Don’t boil a kid in its mother’s milk.

27“Write those things down; with them I’m making a covenant with you and Israel.”

28Moses was there with the LORD for 40 days and didn’t eat bread or drink water. The LORD wrote the terms of the covenant on the tablets: The Ten Commandments. Ex 34:21-28

The Glowing Face of Moses

29When Moses was coming down from Mount Sinai (with the tablets in hand), he didn’t realize his face was glowing because he’d been speaking with the LORD. 30When Aaron and the Israelites saw his face glowing, they were afraid to get close to him. 31He called out to them, and Aaron and the rulers in the community came back to him. 32He told them to do everything the LORD had told him on Mount Sinai. 33When he finished talking, he put on a veil. 34Whenever he went to speak to the LORD, he’d take it off till he came out to report what the LORD had said. 35The people would see his face glowing, and he’d put the veil back on till he went in to speak to the LORD again. Ex 34:29-35

Sabbath Regulations

35:1Moses gathered the community and said,

“The LORD has commanded these things: 2‘You can work for six days, but set the seventh day aside to him as a complete rest. Whoever works on it will be executed. 3Don’t start a fire in your houses on the Sabbath.’” Ex 35:1-3

Materials for the Tabernacle

4Moses told them,

“The LORD has commanded 5to take an offering for him from everybody that’s willing to contribute:

gold, silver, and bronze;

6blue, purple, and scarlet material;

fine linen;
