10“A high priest—the one that’s anointed and consecrated to wear the vestments—will not uncover his head or tear his clothes, 11approach any dead person or defile himself even for his father or mother. 12He’s not to leave the sanctuary or profane it, because he has on him God’s consecrating oil. 13He has to marry a virgin from his own people. 14He can’t marry a widow, divorced woman, or prostitute; 15he would profane his offspring among his people. I’m the LORD that sanctifies him.” eHe

Lev 21:10-15

16-17The LORD told Moses to tell Aaron,

“None of your offspring with a defect can offer the bread of his God: 18a blind or lame man, one with a disfigured face or deformed limb, 19a man with a broken foot or hand, 20a hunchback or dwarf, one with a defect in his eye, one with eczema, scabs, or crushed testicles. 21None of your descendants that has a defect can offer the LORD’s offerings by fire. 22He can eat the bread of his God, holy and most holy, 23but he can’t go in to the curtain or approach the altar. He’s not to profane my sanctuary. I’m the LORD that sanctifies him.”

24That’s what Moses told Aaron, his sons, and all Israel. Lev 21:16-24

22:1-2The LORD told Moses to tell Aaron and his sons,

“Handle the holy gifts carefully that the Israelites dedicate to me so you don’t profane my name. 3Don’t approach the holy gifts while you’re ceremonially unclean. I’ll remove you from me. 4If you’re a leper or have a discharge, you can’t eat the holy gifts till you’re clean. Touching anything made ceremonially unclean by a corpse or seminal emission, 5or touching any teeming thing that makes any person unclean, 6makes you unclean till evening. You can’t eat the sacred gifts till you take a bath. 7When the sun sets, you’ll be clean and can eat them. 8You can’t eat an animal that dies or is torn to pieces by wild animals; that makes you ceremonially unclean. 9Keep my charge so you won’t be considered defiled and die for profaning my name. I’m the LORD that sanctifies them.

Lev 22:1-9

10“No layman, visitor with a priest, or hired hand can eat the sacred gifts. 11But a slave that a priest buys with his own money can eat them; so can slaves born in his house. 12If a priest’s daughter marries a layman, she can’t continue to eat the gifts. 13But if she becomes a widow or is divorced, doesn’t have any children, and goes back to her father’s family, she can eat her father’s food. 14If any of you laymen unintentionally eat a sacred gift, add a fifth to it and give it to the priest. 15Laymen are not to profane the sacred gift Israelites offer to the LORD; 16so they’re fined for it. I’m the LORD that sanctifies them.’” Lev 22:10-16

Unacceptable Sacrifices

17-18The LORD told Moses to tell Aaron, his sons, and all Israel:

“When an Israelite or foreigner presents a burnt offering, an offering for fulfilling a vow, or a freewill offering, 19for God to accept it, it must be a male without defect from the cattle, sheep, or goats. 20Don’t offer anything that has a defect. 21When anyone sacrifices a peace offering to the LORD to fulfill a special vow or for a freewill offering from the herd or flock, it must be perfect. 22Don’t offer a blind, crippled, or injured animal, or one with a running sore, eczema, or scab. Don’t make it an offering by fire on the altar to the LORD. 23An ox or lamb that has an enlarged or undersized member, you can present for a freewill offering, but not for a vow. 24Don’t offer anything that has its testicles bruised, crushed, torn to pieces by wild animals, or castrated. 25Don’t accept anything like that from a foreigner for an offering as the food of your God. It has a defect; he won’t accept it.” Lev 22:17-25

26The LORD told Moses,

27“A newborn ox, sheep, or goat will remain with its mother for a week. After that it’s acceptable as an offering by fire to the LORD. 28But don’t slaughter an ox or sheep and its young the same day. 29When you offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving to the LORD, do it so he will accept you. 30Eat it the same day; don’t leave any till morning. 31Keep my commandments that way. 32Don’t profane my holy name; treat me as holy in Israel. I’m the LORD that sanctifies you, 33who brought you out of Egypt to be your God.” Lev 22:26-33

Sabbaths and Festivals

23:1-2The LORD told Moses to tell Israel,

Sabbaths

“The LORD has appointed these times: 3six days you can work, but the seventh day is a Sabbath for complete rest, a holy convocation. It’s a Sabbath to the LORD wherever you live.

4“These are his appointed times, holy convocations that you’ll declare at their appointed times. 5The fourteenth day, first month at twilight is the LORD’s Passover. 6Then on the fifteenth, there’s a Festival of Unleavened Bread to him. Eat bread without yeast for a week. 7The first day, hold a holy convocation; don’t work. 8Present an offering by fire to the LORD for a week. On the seventh day, hold a holy convocation; don’t work.” Lev 23:1-8

Firstfruits

9-10The LORD told Moses to say to Israel,

“When you harvest the land I’m giving you, take a bundle of the first part of the harvest to the priest. 11The day after Sabbath he’ll wave it back and forth in front of the LORD for you to be accepted. 12When you wave it, offer a male lamb a year old without defect for a burnt offering. 13Its grain offering will be .22 bushel .2 ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil, an offering by fire to the LORD for a pleasing aroma, with its liquid offering, 3pts ¼ hin of wine. 14Before you take the offering to your God, don’t eat bread or roasted grain from the new growth. It’s an ongoing permanent statute wherever you live. Lev 23:9-14

Feast of Weeks

15“Count seven Sabbaths from the day after the Sabbath when you brought the bundle for the wave offering. 16Count 50 days to the day after the seventh Sabbath. Then present a new grain offering to the LORD. 17Take in 2 loaves of bread for a wave offering, made from .22 bushel .2 ephah. They’ll consist of fine flour baked with yeast as the first of the harvest to the LORD.

18Along with the bread, present 7 year-old male lambs without defect, a bull from the herd, and 2 rams. They’ll be a burnt offering along with their grain offering and liquid offerings. It’s an offering by fire of an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 19Also offer 1 male goat for a sin offering and 2 yearling male lambs for a peace offering. 20The priest will wave them with the bread from the first part of the harvest for a wave offering with 2 lambs in front of the LORD. They’re holy to the LORD for the priest. 21On that same day, make a proclamation. Hold a holy convocation. Don’t work. It’s an ongoing permanent statute wherever you live.

22“When you harvest, don’t harvest the corners of your field or gather the gleanings from your harvest. Leave them for the poor and foreigners. I’m the LORD your God.” Lev 23:15-22

Feast of Trumpets

23-24Again the LORD told Moses to tell Israel,

“The first day, seventh month, hold a complete rest, a reminder by blowing bugles, a holy convocation. 25Don’t work but present an offering by fire to the LORD.” Lev 23:23-25

Day of Atonement

26The LORD told Moses,

27-28“The tenth day, seventh month, is The Day of Atonement, a holy convocation. Fast and don’t work; present an offering by fire to the LORD to atone for yourselves to the LORD your God. 29Any of you that won’t fast 30and refrain from working that day, I’ll destroy from among the people. 31It’s a permanent statute wherever you live. 32On the ninth of the month at evening, rest till the next evening.” Lev 23:26-32

Feast of Tabernacles

33-34Again the LORD told Moses to tell Israel,

“The fifteenth day, seventh month is the Festival of Booths to the LORD for a week. 35The first day is a holy convocation. Don’t do any kind of work. 36For a week, present an offering by fire to the LORD. On the eighth day, hold a holy convocation and present an offering by fire to the LORD.

37“These are the LORD’s scheduled holidays that you’re to declare as holy convocations, to present burnt offerings to the LORD, grain offerings, sacrifices, and liquid offerings, each day’s matter as prescribed. 38They’re in addition to the ones on the LORD’s Sabbaths. Lev 23:33-38

39“The fifteenth day, seventh month, when you’ve gathered your crops, celebrate the LORD’s festival for a week. Rest on the first and eighth days. 40-41On the first day, take the foliage from beautiful trees, palm branches and boughs of leafy trees and willows by the stream. Every year celebrate a festival to the LORD your God for a week. It’s an ongoing permanent statute for the seventh month. 42The native-born in Israel will live in booths for a week 43to remind your generations that I had the Israelites live in booths when I brought them out of Egypt. I’m the LORD your God.”

44Moses declared to Israel the LORD’s specified holidays. Lev 23:39-44

Pure Oil and Holy Bread

24:1The LORD said to Moses,

2“Tell the people to bring you clear oil from pressed olives that can keep a lamp burning continually. 3-4Outside the curtain of Testimony in the Tent of Meeting, Aaron will keep the lamps on the lampstand in order from evening to morning continually. It’s an ongoing permanent statute.

5“Take fine flour and bake 12 cakes. Put .22 bushels .2 ephah in each one. 6Set them in two stacks, six to a stack on the pure gold table. 7Put pure frankincense beside each stack for the bread as God’s portion, an offering by fire to the LORD. 8Every Sabbath Aaron will set this bread in order in front of the LORD, a permanent covenant for Israel. 9It’ll be for Aaron and his sons to eat in a sacred place. It’s the most sacred to them from the LORD’s offerings by fire, their permanent portion.” Lev 24:1-9

A Blasphemer Stoned

10The son of an Israelite woman and Egyptian father went out among the people and got into a fight with an Israelite man in the camp. 11The woman’s son blasphemed the Name and cursed; so they brought him to Moses. (His mother was Shelomith, daughter of Dibri, tribe of Dan.) 12They put him in custody till the LORD made his commandment clear to Moses.

13The LORD told Moses,

14“Take him outside the camp. The ones who heard him will put their hands on his head and the community will stone him. 15Tell the people, ‘If anybody curses God, he’s considered guilty. 16The community is to stone anybody that blasphemes the LORD.

17“Execute a murderer, 18but anybody that kills an animal will make it good, life for life. 19If one person injures another, do the same thing to that person: 20fracture for fracture, eye for eye, tooth for tooth. [21] 22There’ll be one standard for you and a foreigner. I’m the LORD your God.”

23Moses told the people, and they took outside the camp the one that had cursed, and stoned him.

Lev 24:10-23

The Sabbath Year

25:1-2The LORD told Moses at Mount Sinai to tell Israel,

“When you go into the land I’m giving you, the ground will have a rest to the LORD. 3Plant your fields, prune your vineyards, harvest your crops for six years. 4But the seventh year, the ground will rest to the LORD. Don’t plant your fields or prune your vineyards. 5Don’t store up volunteer growth or gather grapes from untrimmed vines. Let the ground lie feral for a year. 6You’ll have for food what the ground grows on its own during its sabbath year—yourselves, your male and female slaves, hired hands, and foreigners living with you. 7Your livestock and the wild animals on your land will have its produce to eat directly. Lev 25:1-7

The Year of Jubilee

8“Count off 7 weeks of years (49 years). 9Then blow the ram’s horn all over the country on the tenth day, seventh month, the Day of Atonement. 10Consecrate the fiftieth year as a nation-wide release for its people, a jubilee. You’ll go back to your own property and family. 11Don’t plant, store up volunteer growth, or pick clean the untrimmed vines. 12It’s a Year of Jubilee, set aside for you. Eat its produce directly out of the field. Lev 25:8-12

13“In the Year of Jubilee, each of you may go back to your own property. 14If you sell or buy something from one another, don’t wrong one another. 15Corresponding to the number of years since the last Year of Jubilee, you’ll buy and sell it based on the number of crops. 16Calculate its price by the number of crops you’re buying or selling. 17Don’t cheat one another; respect God. I’m the LORD your God. Lev 25:13-17

18“In that way, observe my statutes and obey my regulations so you can live securely on the land. 19Then the ground will yield its produce so you can eat your fill. 20But if you wonder what you’re going to eat in the seventh year if you don’t plant or harvest crops, 21I’ll order my blessing for you in the sixth year so the ground will produce a crop sufficient for three years. 22When you’re planting the eighth year, you’ll still be eating from the old crops till the ninth year’s crop comes in. Lev 25:18-22

23“You can’t sell land permanently because it’s mine. You’re foreigners that live temporarily with me. 24So provide for the redemption of every piece of property. 25If you become so poor you have to sell some of your property, your nearest relative can buy it back. 26If you don’t have any relatives but accumulate enough, you have the right to buy it back yourself. 27To reclaim it, calculate the years since its sale and refund the balance. 28If you don’t accumulate enough to buy it back, it remains with the buyer till the Year of Jubilee and then reverts to you. Lev 25:23-28

29“If you sell a house in a walled city, you have a right to buy it back for a full year. 30If you don’t buy it back within a year, it passes permanently to the buyer; it doesn’t go back to you in the Year of Jubilee. 31Houses in villages without walls, however, are like property in the open country; you can buy them back, and they revert to you in the Year of Jubilee. 32In Levitical towns, Levites have an ongoing right to buy back their houses, 33and their houses revert to them in the Year of Jubilee. Their houses are their possessions among the Israelites, 34but they can’t sell pastures attached to their towns; they’re permanent possessions. Lev 25:29-34

35“If citizens become poor, sustain them like foreigners or temporary residents so they can keep living with you. 36Don’t charge them interest; respect God. 37Don’t lend them your silver or food at interest. 38I’m the LORD your God that brought you out of Egypt to give you Canaan and be your God. Lev 25:35-38

39“If citizens become so poor that they sell themselves to you, don’t subject them to slavery. 40Till the Year of Jubilee, treat them like hired hands or foreigners with you. 41Then they and their offspring will go back to their family and ancestors’ property. 42They’re my servants that I brought out of Egypt. Don’t sell them in the slave trade. 43Don’t rule them harshly; respect me. 44You can acquire male and female slaves from pagan nations,

45from foreigners living among you;

you can acquire possessions from the families they produce in your country; 46you can will them to your heirs and

use them as permanent slaves.

But with Israelites, don’t mistreat one another that way. Lev 25:39-46

47“If foreigners’ or temporary residents’ means become sufficient and any fellow citizens become so poor as to sell themselves to a foreigner or descendant living among you, 48-49they’ll have redemption rights. A brother, uncle, nephew, or other blood relative has a right to buy them back. If they prosper, they can redeem themselves. 50Then they and their purchaser will calculate from the year they sold yourselves up to the Year of jubilee. The price of their sale will correspond to that number of years. Their case will be like the time of a hired hand. 51If many years still remain for their redemption, they’ll refund their purchase price corresponding to their remaining years. 52If few years remain till the Year of Jubilee, they’ll calculate with their purchaser. In proportion to their years, they’ll refund the amount for their redemption. 53They’ll be with the purchaser like someone hired year by year, not like slaves. 54If you’re not bought back, you and your offspring will still go back free in the Year of Jubilee, 55because Israelites are my servants that I brought out of Egypt. I’m the LORD your God.” Lev 25:47-55

Blessings for Obedience

26:1“Don’t make idols, set up images or sacred pillars, or put stone figurines in your country to bow to. 2Keep my Sabbaths and reverence my sanctuary. 3If you follow my statutes and keep my commandments, 4I’ll give you rain in its season so the ground will grow crops and the trees will bear fruit. 5Threshing time will last till grape harvest, and grape harvest will last till planting season. You’ll have plenty to eat, and you’ll live securely in your country. 6I’ll grant peace so you can lie down without feeling afraid. I’ll eliminate dangerous wild animals from the land, and no sword will pass through your land. 7You’ll chase your enemies, and they’ll fall by your sword. 8Five of you will chase 100, and 100 will chase 10,000. 9I’ll favor you, multiply you, and confirm my covenant with you. 10You’ll eat the old supply and clear out the old because of the new. 11I’ll live among you 12and be your God, and you’ll be my people. 13I’m the LORD your God that brought you out of Egypt so you wouldn’t be their slaves. I broke the bars of your yoke and made you walk erect. Lev 26:1-13

Punishment for Disobedience

14“If you don’t carry out these commandments, 15if you reject my statutes, abhor my ordinances, and break my covenant, 16I’ll bring panic over you. Consumption and fever will make your eyes sink in and depress you. You’ll plant your seed for nothing because your enemies will eat it. 17I’ll oppose you, and your enemies will strike you down. The ones that hate you will rule you. You’ll run when nobody’s chasing.

18“If you still don’t obey me, I’ll punish you seven times over 19and break your strong pride. I’ll make your sky like iron and your ground like bronze. 20You’ll spend your strength for nothing, because the ground won’t grow crops and the trees won’t bear fruit.

21“If you’re still hostile toward me and refuse to obey, I’ll strike you with plague seven times over. 22I’ll let wild animals loose among you to terrorize your children, destroy your livestock, and decimate your population till your roads are deserted.

23“If you’re still hostile toward me and don’t return to me, 24I’ll be hostile toward you and strike you seven times over. 25I’ll bring on you a sword to avenge the covenant. When you retreat to your towns, I’ll send a plague and deliver you to your enemies. 26When I break your staff of bread, ten women will bake your bread in one oven and bring it to you in rations. You’ll eat and not be satisfied.

27“If you still don’t obey me, but act hostile toward me, 28I’ll act hostile toward you and punish you seven times over. 29You’ll eat your sons and daughters. 30I’ll destroy your high places, cut down your incense altars, and heap your remains on the remains of your idols because I’ll abhor you. 31I’ll lay waste your towns too, and make your sanctuaries desolate. I won’t smell your pleasing aromas. 32I’ll make the land so desolate it will appall your enemies that settle in it. 33I’ll scatter you among the nations and draw out a sword after you as your land grows desolate and your towns become ruins.

34“The land will enjoy its Sabbaths during its desolation while you’re in your enemies’ country. 35It will get the rest it didn’t get on the Sabbaths while you were living in it. 36You that are left, I’ll make lose heart in your enemies’ countries. The sound of a blown leaf will chase you. You’ll run when nobody’s chasing you. 37You’ll stumble over each other and fall like you’re running from the sword, even though nobody’s chasing you. You won’t have the strength to stand up to your enemies. 38You’ll perish among the nations that consume you. 39You that are left will rot away in your enemies’ countries because of your ancestors’ sin. Lev 26:14-39

Future Restoration

40“If you confess your and your ancestors’ sin in your unfaithfulness and hostility toward me—41if your uncircumcised heart becomes humble and you make amends for your sin, 42I’ll remember my covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as well, and I’ll remember the land. [43] 44I won’t reject you so completely that I destroy you and break my covenant with you. 45I’ll remember the covenant with your ancestors that I brought out of Egypt in front of the nations so I could be your God. I’m the LORD.”

46The LORD established those statutes, ordinances, and laws for Israel through Moses at Mount Sinai. Lev 26:40-46

Laws About Vows

27:1-2Again the LORD told Moses,

“When people make difficult vows, appraise them before the LORD. 3Appraise a male that’s 20 to 60 years old at 20 oz of silver 50 shekels of the sanctuary 4and a female at 12 oz 30 shekels of silver. 5Appraise a male that’s 5 to 20 years old at 8 oz 20 shekels and a female at 4 oz 10 shekels. 6Appraise a male that’s a month to 5 years old at 2 oz 5 shekels of silver and a female at 1⅕ oz 3 shekels. 7Your appraisal for males above 60 will be 6 oz 15 shekels and 4 oz 10 shekels for females. 8But if you can’t afford that appraisal, you can have the priest appraise you according to your means. 9If it’s an animal you can offer to the LORD, it will be holy. 10You won’t exchange it good for bad or vice versa. If you do exchange it, both it and the substitute become holy. 11-12But if it’s a ceremonially unclean animal, which people don’t offer to the LORD, the priest will appraise it. His appraisal is final. 13But if you ever want to buy it back, add a fifth to the appraisal. Lev 27:1-13

14“If you consecrate your house to the LORD, the priest will appraise it. His appraisal is final. 15But if you want to buy it back, add a fifth to the appraisal.

Lev 27:14-15

16“If you consecrate part of your field to the LORD, the priest’s appraisal will be in proportion to the seed for sowing it: 11 bushels 1 homer of barley at 20 oz 50 shekels of silver. 17If you consecrate your field in relation to the Year of Jubilee, it will stand according to the priest’s appraisal. 18If you consecrate your field after the Year of Jubilee, the priest will calculate the price in proportion to the years till the next Year of Jubilee and deduct it from its appraisal. 19If you ever want to buy it back, add a fifth to the appraisal. 20If you sell it, you can’t buy it back. 21When it reverts in the Year of Jubilee, it will be holy to the LORD like a field set apart and will belong to the priest. 22If you consecrate a field to the LORD that you’ve bought—not a part of your own property—23then the priest will calculate for it the amount of your valuation as holy to the LORD. 24In the Year of Jubilee, the field will go back to its original owner. 25Appraisals will be in shekels of the sanctuary (20 gerahs per shekel). Lev 27:16-25

26“However, you can’t consecrate firstborn animals—ox or sheep; they already belong to the LORD. 27But if it’s a ceremonially unclean animal, you can buy it back according to its appraised value plus a fifth. If you don’t buy it back, the priest will sell it for its appraised value.

28“Nevertheless, nothing devoted to the LORD —man, animal, or field—can be sold or bought back. It’s most holy. 29No one that’s been sentenced to death can be ransomed. Execute that person. Lev 27:26-29

Laws About Tithes

30“Set apart to the LORD a tenth of the land, produce of the ground and fruit of the trees. 31If you want to buy back part of that tenth, add a fifth to it. 32Set apart to the LORD every tenth member of a herd and flock. 33Whether it’s good or bad, you don’t need to substitute for it. If you do, both it and the substitute become holy, and you can’t buy them back.”

34Those are commandments the LORD gave Moses for Israel at Mount Sinai. Lev 27:30-34

NUMBERS

Census of Israel’s Troops

1:1On the first day, second month, second year after they left Egypt, the LORD told Moses at Sinai in the Tent of Meeting,

2“Take a census by families. Count the men 320 years old and up that can go to war. You and Aaron count them by armies. 4To help you, appoint one man from each tribe as head of his ancestor’s house. 5They’ll stand with you:

from Reuben, Elizur son of Shedeur;

6from Simeon, Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai;

7from Judah, Nahshon son of Amminadab;

8from Issachar, Nethanel son of Zuar;

9from Zebulun, Eliab son of Helon;

10from Joseph’s son Ephraim, Elishama son of Ammihud;

from Joseph’s son Manasseh, Gamaliel son of Pedahzur;

11from Benjamin, Abidan son of Gideoni;

12from Dan, Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai;

13from Asher, Pagiel son of Ochran;

14from Gad, Eliasaph son of Deuel;

15from Naphtali, Ahira son of Enan.

16Those are the appointed leaders by tribes, the heads of clans in Israel.” Num 1:1-16

17Moses and Aaron took the men God had designated 18and gathered the community on the first day, second month. [19]

20The count came out as follows:

2146,500 from Reuben, Israel’s firstborn;

22-2359,300 from Simeon,

24-2545,650 from Gad,

26-2774,600 from Judah,

28-2954,400 from Issachar,

30-3157,400 from Zebulun,

32-3340,500 from Ephraim,

34-3532,300 from Manasseh,

36-3735,400 from Benjamin,

38-3962,700 from Dan

40-4141,500 from Asher,

42-4353,400 from Naphtali,

44-46The total was 603,550. Num 1:17-46

47They didn’t count the Levites in the military census. 48The LORD told Moses,

49“Don’t count the Levites. 50Put them in charge of the Tabernacle and everything associated with it. They’ll transport it and its furnishings, take care of it, and camp around it. 51When it sets out, they’ll dismantle it. When it camps, they’ll assemble it. Execute any layman that comes near. 52The Israelites will camp in groups by their standard in their armies. 53But the Levites will camp around the Tabernacle so there won’t be any wrath on the Israelites. [54a]

Israel did everything the LORD commanded Moses. Num 1:47-54

The Layout of Israel’s Camp

2:[1] 2“The Israelites will camp with the banners of their families facing the Tent of Meeting. 3-4On the east side of the Tabernacle, Judah will camp by its standard—the army of Nahshon (74,600). 5-6Issachar will camp next to him—the army of Nethanel (54,400). 7-8Zebulun will camp with its leader Eliab (57,400). 9The Judah camp totals 186,400. It will move out first. Num 2:1-9

10-11“On the south side of the Tabernacle, Reuben will camp by its standard—the army of Elizur (46,500). 12-13Simeon will camp next to him—the army of Shelumiel (59,300). 14-15Gad will camp with its leader Eliasaph (45,650). 16The Reuben camp totals 151,450. It will move out second.

17“Then the Tent of Meeting will move out with the Levites in the middle of the camps.

18-19“On the west side of the Tabernacle, Ephraim will camp by its standard—the army of Elishama (40,500). 20-21Manasseh will camp next to him—with its leader Gamaliel (32,200). 22-23Benjamin camps next—the army of Abidan (35,400). 24The Ephraim camp totals 108,100. It will move out third. Num 2:10-24

25-26“On the north side of the Tabernacle, Dan will camp by its standard—the army of Ahiezer (62,700). 27-28Asher will camp next to him—with its leader Pagiel (41,500). 29-30Naphtali camps next—with its leader Ahira (53,400). 31The Dan camp totals 157,600. It will move out last.”

32The total men numbered 603,550, 33not including the Levites. 34The Israelites did everything the LORD told Moses. They camped by their standards and went out in that order, each by family and ancestral house. Num 2:25-34

3:1The Generations of Aaron and Moses

When the LORD Spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai

Duties of Levites

2The sons of Aaron were Nadab, the firstborn, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar—3anointed and ordained as priests. 4In the Wilderness of Sinai, Nadab and Abihu died from offering before the LORD, fire different from what he’d commanded. They didn’t have any children, so Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests during Aaron’s lifetime. Num 3:1-4

5The LORD told Moses,

6“Set the tribe of Levi aside to serve Aaron. 7They’ll perform duties for him and the whole community at the Tent of Meeting. They’ll service the Tabernacle 8and keep the furnishings of the Tent of Meeting in assisting with the duties of the people. 9Give the Levites to Aaron and his sons. 10Appoint Aaron and his sons to carry out the duties of the priesthood; execute any layman that tries to come near.”

11Again the LORD told Moses,

12“I’ve taken the Levites from the people in place of the firstborn. 13The firstborn belong to me. When I struck down the firstborn in Egypt, I set apart to myself the firstborn people and animals in Israel. The Levites belong to me; I’m the LORD.” Num 3:5-13

14The LORD told Moses in the Wilderness of Sinai, 15“Count the descendants of Levi by families—every male a month old and up.” 16Moses counted them:

17the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.

18 the clans descended from Gershon: Libni and Shimei.

19the clans descended from Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.

20the clans descended from Merari: Mahli and Mushi. Num 3:14-20

21The Libnites and Shimeites descended from Gershon. 22Their males a month old and up numbered 7,500. 23They camped west of the Tabernacle, behind it. 24Eliasaph son of Lael was family leader among the Gershonites. 25The sons of Gershon serviced the Tent of Meeting, including the Tabernacle and tent, its covering, the screen for the door to the Tent of Meeting, 26the hangings around the court, and the screen for the door to the court around the Tabernacle, the altar, and its cords. Num 3:21-26

27The Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites, and Uzzielites descended from Kohath. 28Their males a month old and up numbered 8,600; they serviced the sanctuary. 29They camped south of the Tabernacle. 30Elizaphan son of Uzziel was family leader among the Kohathites. 31The sons of Kohath serviced the Ark, the table, the lampstand, the altars, the utensils of the sanctuary they perform service with, and the screen.

32Eleazar son of Aaron, the chief leader from Levi, oversaw the ones that performed duties in the sanctuary. Num 3:27-32

33The Mahlites and Mushites descended from Merari. 34Their males a month old and up numbered 6,200. 35Zuriel son of Abihail was family of Merari. They camped north of the Tabernacle. 36The sons of Merari serviced the frames of the Tabernacle, its bars, posts, bases, equipment, 37together with the posts around the court with their bases, pegs, and cords.

38 Moses, Aaron, and his sons camped east of the Tabernacle and performed duties in the sanctuary for the obligation of Israel. Any layman that would come near was to be executed. 39The Levites that Moses and Aaron counted a month old and up numbered 22,000. Num 3:33-39

Redemption of the Firstborn

40The LORD told Moses,

“Count by name every male firstborn in Israel a month old and up. 41Take the Levites for me in place of Israel’s firstborn sons, and take the Levites’ livestock in place of the nation’s firstborn livestock.”

42Moses counted Israel’s firstborn: 4322,273 males a month old and up.

44The LORD told Moses,

45“The Levites belong to me; I’m the LORD. 46For the ransom of the 273 firstborn in Israel above the number of Levites, 47take 2 oz 5 shekels per head, shekels of the sanctuary (20 gerahs to a shekel). 48Give the ransom money to Aaron and his sons.”

49Moses took the ransom money from the ones above the number ransomed by the Levites. 50From the firstborn he took the money in shekels of the sanctuary (1,365 shekels 34 lbs) 51and gave it to Aaron and his sons. Num 3:40-51

Duties of the Kohathites

4:1The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

2“Count the descendants of Kohath by families 330-50 years old who serve in the Tent of Meeting. 4This is the work of Kohath’s descendants with the most holy objects. 5When the camp sets out, Aaron and his sons will go in and take down the screen and cover the Ark of Testimony with it. 6They’ll lay a dolphin-skin covering over it, spread a pure blue cloth over it, and insert its poles. 7Over the table for the Bread of the Presence, they’ll spread a pure blue cloth and put on it the dishes, spoons, sacrificial bowls, liquid offering jars, and the continual bread that’s on it. 8They’ll spread a scarlet cloth over them, cover it with a dolphin-skin covering, and insert its poles. 9Then they’ll take a blue cloth and cover the lampstand, its lamps, snuffers, trays, and oil jars. 10They’ll put it and its utensils in a dolphin-skin covering and put it on the carrying bars. 11They’ll spread a blue cloth over the gold altar, and cover it with a dolphin-skin covering, and insert its bars. 12They’ll take the utensils for service in the sanctuary, put them in a blue cloth, cover them with a dolphin-skin covering, and put them on the carrying bars. 13Then they’ll take away the ashes from the altar and spread a purple cloth over it. 14They’ll put its utensils on it: the firepans, forks, shovels, and basins. They’ll spread a dolphin-skin covering over it and insert its poles.

Num 4:1-14

15“After Aaron and his sons cover the holy objects and furnishings, the Kohathites will come to carry them so they won’t touch the holy objects and die.

16“Eleazar is responsible for the olive oil for the light, the fragrant incense, the daily grain offering, and anointing oil—the Tabernacle and everything in it, the sanctuary and its furnishings.”

17The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

18“Don’t let the clans of Kohath get eliminated from the Levites. 19Do this so they won’t die when they approach the most holy objects. Have Aaron and his sons go in and assign each of them his work and his load, 20but they won’t go in to see the holy objects even for a moment; they’ll die.” Num 4:15-20

21The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

22“Count the clans of Gershon by families 2330-50 years old who serve in the Tent of Meeting. 24The Gershonites 25will carry the curtains of the Tabernacle, the Tent of Meeting with its covering and the dolphin-skin covering that’s on top of it, the screen for the door to the Tent of Meeting, 26the hangings for the court, the screen for the door to the court that’s around the Tabernacle and the altar, their cords, and the equipment for their service and everything that’s to be done. 27The Gershonites will serve under Aaron and his sons. You’ll assign them their loads. 28Ithamar son of Aaron will direct the Gershonites’ service. Num 4:21-28

29“Count the descendants of Merari by families 3030-50 years old who serve with the Tent of Meeting. 31They’ll carry the boards of the Tabernacle, its bars, posts, and bases; 32the posts around the court, their bases, pegs, and cords, with their equipment and service. 33Assign each man by name what he’s supposed to carry. Ithamar will direct their service.” Num 4:29-33

34Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of the community counted the Kohathites 3530-50 years old who served with the Tent of Meeting: 362,750. [37]

38-41The Gershonites 30-50 years old by family, numbered 2,630.

42The men counted from the families of Merari 4330-50 years old who served in the Tent of Meeting, numbered 443,200. [45]

46The Levites that Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of Israel counted 4730-50 years old who carried the Tent of Meeting, numbered 488,580. 49Moses counted them. Num 4:34-49

Purity in Israel’s Camp

5:1The LORD told Moses,

2“Tell Israel to send outside the camp any leper, anybody with a discharge, anyone ceremonially unclean because of a dead person. 3Send out male or female so they won’t defile their camp where I live.”

4They did that. Num 5:1-4

5-6The LORD told Moses to say to Israel,

6“When a man or woman sins against the LORD by sinning against another person, 7the offender will confess and pay restitution plus a fifth to the one that was wronged. 8If there’s no relative to receive the restitution, it goes to the LORD for the priest in addition to the ram offered for the atonement. 9The priest will also receive every contribution associated with the holy gifts the people offer. 10Everybody’s holy gifts belong to the priest.” Num 5:5-10

The Test for Adultery

[11] 12-13“If a husband suspects his wife has been unfaithful, 14-15he can take her to the priest. He’s to take .11 bushels .1 ephah of barley meal as an offering for her. He won’t pour olive oil on it or put frankincense on it because it’s a grain offering of jealousy, a reminder of sin.

16“The priest will have her stand in the LORD’s presence. 17He’ll take holy water in a clay jar, take some dust from the floor of the Tabernacle, and put it in the water. 18He’ll let her hair down loose and place the memorial grain offering in her hands. The priest will have in his hand the bitter water that brings a curse. 19He’ll have her take an oath, ‘If no man has had intercourse with you while under your husband’s authority, be immune to this bitter water that brings a curse. 20But if you’ve defiled yourself with another man,’ [21then he’ll have her swear the oath] ‘may the LORD make you a curse among your people. 22This water will make your abdomen swell and your thigh shrivel’ She’ll say, ‘True. True.’

Num 5:11-22

23“The priest will write these curses on a scroll and wash them off into the water. 24Then he’ll have her drink the water. 25The priest will take the grain offering of jealousy from her, wave it in front of the LORD, and take it to the altar. 26He’ll take a handful of the memorial grain offering and offer it up in smoke on the altar. Afterward he’ll have her drink the water. 27If she has been unfaithful, the water will cause bitterness. Her abdomen will swell, her thigh will waste away, and she’ll become a curse among her people. 28If she hasn’t defiled herself, she’ll be free and can conceive children.

29“That’s the law of jealousy 30when a husband suspects his wife has gone astray. 31He won’t be responsible, but she’ll be held guilty.” Num 5:23-31

The Nazirite Vow

6:1-2The LORD told Moses to say to Israel,

“When men or women take a Nazarite vow to dedicate themselves to the LORD, 3they must abstain from wine, alcohol, and from vinegar made from them. They can’t drink grape juice or eat fresh grapes or raisins. 4They’re not to eat anything a grapevine produces from seeds to skin.

5“During that time, they have to let their hair grow. 6-7They can’t make themselves ceremonially unclean by going near a dead body even for a parent or sibling that dies. [8] Num 6:1-8

9“If someone dies suddenly beside them and defiles their dedicated head, they’ll shave it the same day and on the seventh day. 10The eighth day, they’ll take two turtledoves or young pigeons to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. 11The priest will offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering; that will purify them from their defilement. That same day they’ll re-consecrate their head, 12dedicate to the LORD their days as a Nazirite, and take a male lamb a year old for a guilt offering. Their previous days of separation are void. Num 6:9-12

13“When Nazirites finish their time of separation, they’ll take an offering to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting 14and present it to the LORD:

one male lamb a year old without defect for a burnt offering,

one ewe lamb a year old without defect for a sin offering,

one ram without defect for a peace offering, 15and

a basket of cakes of fine flour without yeast mixed with olive oil and

wafers without yeast basted with olive oil, along with

their grain offering and liquid offerings.

16The priest will present them all to the LORD. [17] 18Then the Nazirites will shave their head and put the dedicated hair on the fire that’s under the peace offering. 19The priest will take the ram’s boiled shoulder and one cake and wafer without yeast from the basket, and put them in the Nazirites’ hands. 20The priest will wave them in front of the LORD. They’re set apart for the priest, together with the chest offered by waving and the thigh offered by lifting up. Afterward Nazirites can drink wine again.

21“That’s the law for Nazirites that vow their offering to the LORD for their separation in addition to what else they can afford.” Num 6:13-21

Aaron’s Blessing

22The LORD told Moses to have Aaron and his sons 23pronounce this blessing on Israel:

24“The LORD bless you and keep you.

25The LORD smile on you

and be gracious to you.

26The LORD lift up his countenance on you

and give you peace.”

27“In that way they’ll invoke my name on the people, and I’ll bless them.”

Num 6:22-27

Offerings of Dedication

7:1The day Moses finished setting up the Tabernacle, he anointed and consecrated its furnishings, the altar, and its utensils. 2The leaders in Israel (besides the numbered men) made an offering 3and brought it to the Tabernacle: 6 covered carts and 12 cattle, a cart for each pair of leaders and an ox for each leader. 4The LORD told Moses, 5“Accept these things for use in the Tent of Meeting. Give them to each Levite according to his service.” 6Moses accepted the carts and cattle and gave them to the Levites: 72 carts and 4 cattle to Gershon’s descendants to match their service, 8and 4 carts and 8 cattle to Merari’s descendants to match their service—as directed by Ithamar son of Aaron. 9He didn’t give any to Kohath’s descendants because their service was with the holy objects, which they carried on their shoulders. 10The leaders offered the dedication offering for the altar when it was anointed; they offered it in front of the altar. Num 7:1-10

11Then the LORD told Moses, “Have them present their offering, one leader a day, for the dedication of the altar.” [Each leader presented the same offering as follows:]

13one silver platter that weighed 3¼ lbs 130 shekels,

one silver bowl that weighed 28 oz 70 shekels of the sanctuary—

both full of fine flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering;

14one gold pan weighing 4 oz 10 shekels, full of incense;

15one bull, one ram, one male lamb a year old, for a burnt offering;

16one male goat for a sin offering;

17two oxen, five rams, five male goats, five male lambs a year old for peace

offerings.

12The first day, Nahshon son of Amminadab, from Judah, presented his offering.

18The second day, Nethanel son of Zuar, leader of Issachar, presented his offering.

24The third day, Eliab son of Helon, leader of Zebulun, presented.

30The fourth day, Elizur son of Shedeur, leader of Reuben, presented.

36The fifth day, Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai, leader of Simeon, presented.

42The sixth day, Eliasaph son of Deuel, leader of Gad, presented.

48The seventh day, Elishama son of Ammihud, leader of Ephraim, presented.

54The eighth day, Gamaliel son of Pedahzur, leader of Manasseh, presented.

60The ninth day, Abidan son of Gideoni, leader of Benjamin, presented.

66The tenth day, Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai, leader of Benjamin, presented.

72The eleventh day, Pagiel son of Ochran, leader of Asher, presented.

78The twelfth day, Ahira son of Enan, leader of Naphtali, presented.

[19-23] = [25-29] = [31-35] = [37-41] = [43-47] = [49-53] = [55-59] = [61-65] = [67-71] =

[73-77] = [79-83] repeats of 13-17. Num 7:11-83

84That was the dedication offering for the altar from the leaders of Israel when it was anointed: 12 silver platters, 12 silver bowls, 12 gold pans, 85each silver platter weighing 3¼ lbs 130 shekels and each bowl weighing 28 oz 70 shekels. The silver of the utensils weighed 60 lbs 2,400 shekels of the sanctuary. 86The 12 gold saucers full of incense weighed 4 oz 10 shekels apiece—3 lbs 120 shekels altogether. 87For the burnt offerings there were 12 bulls, 12 rams, 12 male lambs a year old with their grain offerings, and 12 male goats for a sin offering. 88For the peace offerings there were 24 bulls, 60 rams, 60 male goats, 60 male lambs a year old. That was the dedication offering for the altar after it was anointed.

89Whenever Moses went into the Tent of Meeting to speak to the LORD, he’d hear a voice speaking to him from between the two cherubs above the mercy seat on the Ark of Testimony.

Num 7:84-89

The Seven Lamps

8:1The LORD told Moses 2to have Aaron put up the 7 lamps to shine in front of the lampstand. 3Aaron did that. 4The lampstand was hammered gold from its base to its flowers in the pattern the LORD showed Moses. Num 8:1-4

The Levites Dedicated

5Again the LORD told Moses,

6“Take the Levites from among the Israelites and cleanse them. 7For their cleansing, sprinkle purifying water on them, have them shave their whole bodies and wash their clothes. 8Then have them take a bull with its grain offering—fine flour mixed with olive oil. Take a second bull for a sin offering. 9Present the Levites at the Tent of Meeting and gather the community. 10Have them put their hands on the Levites. 11Then Aaron will present the Levites to the LORD as a wave offering from the people to qualify them to perform service to the LORD. 12The Levites will put their hands on the bulls’ heads. They’ll offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, to atone for the Levites. 13Have the Levites stand in the presence of Aaron and his sons to present them as a wave offering to the LORD. Num 8:5-13

14“In that way, set the Levites apart from among the Israelites. The Levites will belong to me. 15Then they can serve in the Tent of Meeting. But you’ll cleanse them and present them as a wave offering, 16because I’ve dedicated them to myself in place of every firstborn in Israel. 17Every firstborn belongs to me among people and animals. The day I struck down the firstborn in Egypt, I sanctified them to myself. [18] 19I’ve given the Levites to Aaron and his sons to perform the service for the Israelites at the Tent of Meeting, and to atone for them so there won’t be a plague on Israel from coming near the sanctuary.”

20That’s what Moses, Aaron, and the community did with the Levites. 21The Levites purified themselves and washed their clothes. Aaron presented them as a wave offering and atoned for them. 22Afterwards they went into the Tent of Meeting to perform their service with Aaron and his sons. Num 8:14-22

23The LORD told Moses,

24“The Levites will serve in the Tent of Meeting from age 25 to 50 25and then retire. 26They can, however, help their relatives in the Tent of Meeting in keeping an obligation, but they themselves can’t work.” Num 8:23-26

The Second Passover

9:1In the first month, second year after the Israelites left Egypt, the LORD told Moses in the Wilderness of Sinai, 2-3“Have Israel observe Passover as directed at its scheduled time: the fourteenth day of this month in the evening.” 4Moses told the Israelites to observe it. 5They did so in the Wilderness of Sinai the way the LORD commanded Moses. Num 9:1-5

6Some men were ceremonially unclean because of a corpse, so they couldn’t observe it that day. They came to Moses and Aaron that day, 7“Although we’re unclean, why can’t we present the offering to the LORD at the scheduled time with the rest of Israel?”

8Moses said, “I’ll listen to what the LORD says.”

9-10The LORD told him to tell Israel,

“If any of you becomes ceremonially unclean because of a dead person or being on a long trip, go ahead and observe the Passover to the LORD. 11Observe it on the fourteenth day, second month in the evening. Eat it with bitter herbs and bread without yeast. 12Don’t leave any of it till morning or break a bone of it. 13But any of you that’s clean and not on a trip and doesn’t observe it, will be excluded from Israel. You didn’t present the offering to the LORD as scheduled. You’ll be held guilty. 14Any foreigner living among you may observe Passover as directed. You’ll have one statute for foreigners and citizens.” Num 9:6-14

The Cloud over the Tabernacle

15The day they set up the Tabernacle (the Tent of Testimony), the cloud covered it. In the evening, what looked like fire appeared over it till morning. 16That became the pattern: the cloud covered it during the day and what looked like fire covered it at night. 17Whenever the cloud lifted, the Israelites would set out. Where it settled, they’d camp. 18As the LORD directed Moses, they’d set out or camp. As long as the cloud stayed over the Tabernacle, they stayed at that camp 19even if it was for a long time. [20] 21If the cloud stayed all night and lifted in the morning, they’d move out in the morning. If it stayed all day and lifted at night, they’d move out in the evening. 22Whether it was two days, a month, or a year, they wouldn’t move till the cloud lifted. [23] Num 9:15-23

The Silver Trumpets

10:1The LORD told Moses,

2“Make two bugles out of hammered silver. Use them to gather the community or move the camp out. 3Blow both bugles to gather the community at the Tent of Meeting. 4Blow one bugle to gather just the leaders of thousands there.

5“When you blow the signal, the camps pitched on the east side will set out. 6When you blow the signal again, the camps pitched on the south side will set out. 7When assembling the community, however, blow without sounding an alarm. 8By permanent statute the priestly descendants of Aaron will blow the bugles. 9When you go to war in your country against an attacker, blow the signal with the bugle, so the LORD will remember you and save you from your enemies. 10At celebrations, at scheduled festivals, and on the first day of the month, blow the bugles over your burnt offerings and peace offerings to remind your God about you. I’m the LORD your God.” Num 10:1-10

Israel Leaves Sinai

11On the twentieth day, second month, second year, the cloud lifted from the Tabernacle. 12The Israelites set out from the Wilderness of Sinai and came to rest in the Wilderness of Paran. 13That was the first time they moved at the LORD’s directive through Moses. 14The standard of Judah’s camp set out first, with Nahshon over its army, 15Nethanel over Issachar’s tribal army, 16and Eliab over Zebulun’s tribal army. Num 10:11-16

17The Levites dismantled the Tabernacle; the descendants of Gershon and Merari set out carrying it. 18Next, Reuben’s standard set out with Elizur over its army, 19Shelumiel over Simeon’s tribal army, 20and Eliasaph over Gad’s tribal army.

21Then the Kohathites set out, carrying the holy objects, and the Tabernacle would already be set up before they arrived. 22Next, Ephraim’s standard set out with Elishama over its army, 23Gamaliel over Manasseh’s army, 24and Abidan over Benjamin’s army.

25Then Dan’s standard, the rear guard for the camps, set out with Ahiezer over its army, 26Pagiel over Asher’s army, 27and Ahira over Naphtali’s army. 28That was the order of the Israelite’s tribal armies. Num 10:17-28

29Moses told Hobab son of Reuel/Jethro from Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, “We’re setting out to the place the LORD said he’d give us. Go with us and we’ll do you good because he has promised good for Israel.”

30But he said, “No; I’ll go to my own territory and relatives.”

31Moses said,

“Don’t leave. You know where to camp in the open country. You can be our eyes. 32If you go with us, whatever good the LORD does for us we’ll do for you.” Num 10:29-32

33They set out from the mountain of the LORD on a three-day journey, with the Ark of the Covenant in front, to find a resting place. 34The cloud of the LORD was over them during the day when they set out from the camp.

35When the Ark set out, Moses would say,

“Rise up, LORD!

Scatter your enemies;

make the ones that hate you flee.”

36When the Ark came to rest, he’d say,

“Come back, LORD,

to the countless thousands in Israel.” Num 10:33-36

The People Complain

11:1The people started complaining about their hardships. The LORD’s anger flared. It burned among them and burned up the outskirts of the camp. 2The people cried out to Moses, and he prayed to the LORD, and the fire died down. 3The name of that place became Taberah, because the LORD’s fire “burned” among them.

4Some riffraff among them had selfish interests and cried out again,

“Who’s going to feed us? 5We remember the fish we used to eat free in Egypt, the cucumbers, melons, leeks, onions, and garlic. 6Now our appetite’s gone. There’s nothing to look at except this manna.”

7The manna was like coriander seed and looked like bdellium. 8The people would go around and gather it up, grind it between millstones, mash it in mortars, or boil it in pots and make cakes. The cakes tasted like they were baked with olive oil. 9Manna fell with the dew at night.

Num 11:1-9

10Moses heard the families whining at the entrance to their tents. The LORD’s anger kindled greatly, and Moses wasn’t pleased. 11He asked the LORD,

“Why be so hard on me? How have I displeased you that you’ve laid the responsibility for all these people on me? 12Was I the one that conceived them and had them, that you should tell me to carry them in my arms like a nurse carries a nursing infant to the land you swore to their ancestors? 13Where can I get meat for all these people? They’re crying to me for something to eat! 14I can’t carry them; they’re too heavy. 15If you’re going to deal with me this way, take my life now if I’m pleasing to you. Spare me the misery.” Num 11:10-15

Elders Appointed to Help Moses

16The LORD told Moses,

“Gather the 70 elders and their officers at the Tent of Meeting. Have them stand there with you. 17I’ll come down and speak to you and take the Spirit that’s on you and put on them. They’ll bear responsibility for the people, too, so you won’t be bearing it by yourself. 18Tell them, ‘Consecrate yourselves for tomorrow, and you’ll eat meat because you’ve cried, “Oh that someone would feed us! We were well-off in Egypt.” The LORD will give you meat and you’ll eat it—19not 1 day, 2 days, 5, 10, or 20 days, 20but for a whole month, till it comes out your nostrils and you sick of it. That’s because you’ve rejected the LORD that’s among you and whined to his face, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?”’”

21But Moses said,

“There are 600,000 people around me; yet you’ve said you’d give them meat for a month. 22Should they butcher flocks and herds to get enough or try to catch all the fish in the sea?”

23The LORD said, “Am I limited? You’ll see if what I said comes true.” Num 11:16-23

24Moses told the people what the LORD said. He gathered the 70 elders and stationed them around the tent. 25The LORD came down in the cloud and spoke to him. The Spirit that was on Moses he put on them. When the Spirit rested on them, they prophesied. But they never did it again.

26Two men had remained in the camp, Eldad and Medad. The Spirit rested on them, and they kept on prophesying. (They were among the ones that had been registered but hadn’t gone out to the Tent.) 27A young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”

Num 11:24-27

28Joshua son of Nun, Moses’ assistant from his youth, said, “Moses, my lord, stop them.”

29“Are you jealous for me? Oh that all the LORD’s people were prophets, and he would put his Spirit on them.”

30Moses and the elders went back to the camp.

The LORD Sends Quail

31The LORD made a wind blow from the sea to bring quail. They fell about a day’s walk away all around the camp—about 3ft deep all over the ground. 32The people spent all day, all night, and the next day picking them up and spreading them out all around the camp. The least anybody gathered was 62.5 bushels. 33While they chewed the meat, the LORD’s anger flared at them; he struck them with a severe plague. 34So they called the place Kibroth-hattaavah because they put in “graves” the people that had been “greedy.” 35From Kibroth-hattaavah they set out for Hazaroth and stayed there. Num 11:28-35

Miriam and Aaron Oppose Moses

12:1Miriam and Aaron criticized Moses for the Nubian woman he’d married. 2“Has the LORD indeed only spoken through you? Hasn’t he spoken through us too?” The LORD heard it. (3Moses was the most humble man in the world.) 4At once, the LORD told Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, “Come out to the Tent of Meeting.” 5He came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance to the Tent to call Aaron and Miriam. When they’d come forward, 6he said,

“Listen to what I’m saying:

if there’s a prophet among you,

I’ll show myself to him in a vision

or speak to him in a dream.

7Not so with Moses;

he’s faithful in my house.

8I speak to him directly, clearly,

not in dark sayings;

he sees my form.

Why then weren’t you afraid

to criticize him?” Num 12:1-8

9The LORD’s anger burned against them, and he left. 10When the cloud withdrew from over the Tent, Miriam had leprosy as white as snow. When Aaron turned and saw it, 11he told Moses, “Don’t hold that foolish sin against us. 12Don’t leave her like somebody dead, with flesh half eaten away at birth.”

13Moses cried out to the LORD, “God, heal her!”

14The LORD said,

“If her father had only spit in her face, wouldn’t she have borne her disgrace for a week? Quarantine her outside the camp for a week. Then she can come back.”

15So they did; the people didn’t move on till she returned. 16Then they moved out from Hazeroth to the Wilderness of Paran. Num 12:9-16

Spies Sent into Canaan

13:1The LORD told Moses, 2“Send one leader from each tribe to spy out Canaan that I’m giving to Israel.”

3Moses sent out these leaders from Paran:

4from Reuben, Shammua son of Zaccur;

5from Simeon, Shaphat son of Hori;

6from Judah, Caleb son of Jephunneh;

7from Issachar, Igal son of Joseph;

8from Ephraim, Hoshea son of Nun, (16bthat Moses called Joshua);

9from Benjamin, Palti son of Raphu;

10from Zebulun, Gaddiel son of Sodi;

11from Joseph, tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi son of Susi;

12from Dan, Ammiel son of Gemalli;

13from Asher, Sethur son of Michael;

14from Naphtali, Nahbi son of Vophsi;

15from Gad, Geuel son of Machi. Num 13:1-15

16aMoses sent them to spy out the land.

17He told them,

“Go up into the Negev, then to the hill country. 18See what the land is like, how strong the people are, how many there are. 19See if the land is good or bad. See if the towns are like open camps or if they’re fortified. 20Is the ground lush or with little vegetation? Do they have trees? Bring back some fruit.”

It was the season for the first-ripe grapes.

21They spied out the land from the Wilderness of Zin as far as Rehob to Lebo-hamath. 22After they’d gone up to the Negev, they went to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, descendants of Anak, lived. (Hebron was built 7 years before Zoan in Egypt.) 23They went to the Valley of Eshcol and cut off a branch with a single cluster of grapes. They carried it on a pole between two men along with some pomegranates and figs. 24They called that place The Valley of Eshcol because of the “cluster” of grapes they cut off there. Num 13:16-24

The Report of the Spies

25When they came back after 40 days, 26they went to Moses, Aaron, and the whole community in the Wilderness of Paran, at Kadesh. They brought back their report and showed them the fruit from the land:

27“We went into the land, and it does flow with milk and honey. Here’s some of its fruit. 28But the people are strong, and the towns are fortified and big. Besides, we saw descendants of Anak there. 29Amalek lives in the Negev; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites live in the hill country; and the Canaanites live by the sea and along the Jordan.”

30Caleb quieted the people in front of Moses, “We should certainly go up and take possession of it. We can conquer it.”

31But the men that had gone up with him said, “We can’t go up against the people. They’re too strong for us.”

32They gave the people a discouraging report,

“The land overruns its people. They’re big people. 33We saw the Nephilim [Descendants of Anak are one part of the Nephilim.]; we felt like grasshoppers, and that’s what we looked like to them.” Num 13:25-33

The People Rebel

14:1The community cried out loud that night 2and complained to Moses and Aaron,

“We should’ve died in Egypt! We should’ve died in the desert! 3Why is the LORD taking us to this land to fall by the sword? Our wives and little ones will become spoils of war. Wouldn’t we be better off to go back to Egypt?”

4They said to one another, “Let’s appoint a leader and go back.”

5Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in front of the assembly. 6Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh tore their clothes 7and told them,

“The land we passed through is really good land. 8If the LORD is pleased with us, he’ll take us in and give it to us, a land flowing with milk and honey. 9Don’t rebel against him or be afraid of them; they’ll be our prey. Their protection has been removed, and the LORD is with us.”

10But the community said to stone them. Then the glory of the LORD appeared in the Tent of Meeting to the Israelites, 11and he told Moses,

“How long will these people spurn me? How long will they not trust me despite all the signs I’ve performed among them? 12I’ll hit them with a plague and disinherit them, and I’ll make you into a nation bigger and stronger than them.”

Num 14:1-12

Moses Intercedes for the People

13But Moses told him,

“The Egyptians will hear about it, because by your strength you brought these people up from among them, 14and they’ll tell the people in this land. They’ve heard you’re among the people. You’re seen eye to eye while your cloud stands over them, and you lead them in a pillar of cloud in the daytime and a pillar of fire at night. 15If you kill this whole nation, the nations that have heard of your fame will say 16you couldn’t take them to the land you promised them with an oath; so you killed them in the desert. 17Let your power be great like you’ve said, 18‘You’re slow to get angry, you abound in kindness, and forgive sin. But you won’t by any means acquit the guilty. You visit the consequences of parents’ sin on their descendants for three or four generations.’ 19Pardon these people in keeping with your great kindness—like you’ve done from Egypt till now.”

God Measures Out Judgment

20The LORD said,

“I’ll pardon them; 21but as I live, I’ll fill the whole world with my glory. 22The people saw my glory and signs in Egypt and in the desert, but they’ve tested me ten times and ignored me. 23None of them that spurned me will see the land I swore to their ancestors. 24I’ll take my servant Caleb in. He’s had a different spirit and followed me faithfully. His descendants will take possession of it. 25The Amalekites and Canaanites live in the valleys. Turn around tomorrow and set out to the open country by the Red Sea.” Num 14:13-25

26The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

27“How long do I have to put up with this evil community and their complaints against me. 26-28Tell them, ‘As I live,’ the LORD says, ‘as you’ve said what I can hear, I’ll say what you can hear. 29Your corpses will fall in this desert—everyone 20 years old and up that’s criticized me. 30You won’t come into the land I swore to settle you in—except Caleb and Joshua. 31I’ll take in the little ones you said would be prey. They’ll experience the land you rejected. [32] 33Your offspring will be shepherds in the desert for 40 years. Because of your unfaithfulness, they’ll suffer till your corpses lie in the desert. 34So you’ll realize how displeased I am, you’ll suffer for your guilt one year for every day you spied out the land. 35I’ve spoken, and I’ll do it to this community that has united against me: you’ll die in this desert.”

36-37The men that got the community to criticize Moses because of their bad report, died by a plague in the LORD’s presence. 38But Joshua and Caleb remained alive. Num 14:26-38

Israel Defeated in Battle

39When Moses told that to the people, they mourned greatly. 40But in the morning, they got up early and went up to the ridge of the hill country, “Here we are. We’ve indeed sinned, but we’ll go up to the place the LORD promised.”

41But Moses said,

“Why sin against his command? It won’t work. 42Don’t go; your enemies will strike you down. The LORD’s not with you. 43The Amalekites and Canaanites will confront you, and you’ll fall by the sword because you rejected him.”

44But they went up anyway to the ridge of the hill country. Moses and the Ark stayed in camp. 45The Amalekites and Canaanites attacked them and beat them back to Hormah. Num 14:39-45

Laws About Sacrifices

15:1The LORD told Moses to tell Israel,

2“When you go into the land I’m giving you, 3make a burnt offering to me—a sacrifice to fulfill a special vow, a free-will offering, at your scheduled times. Make a pleasing aroma from the herd or flock.

4“When you present your offering, present a grain offering made from .11 bushel .1 ephah of fine flour mixed with 3 pints ¼ hin of olive oil. 5Prepare wine for the liquid offering, 3 pints ¼ hin, with the burnt offering or sacrifice, for each lamb.

6“For a ram, prepare as a grain offering .22 bushel .2 ephah of fine flour mixed with ⅓⅓ him of olive oil. 7For a liquid offering, offer ⅓ gallon ⅓ hin of wine as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. Num 15:1-7

8“When you prepare a bull as a burnt offering or sacrifice—to fulfill a special vow or for peace offerings to the LORD —9offer it with a grain offering made from .33 bushel .3 ephah of fine flour mixed with 3 quarts ½ hin of olive oil. 10Offer as the liquid offering 3 quarts ½ hin of wine as an offering by fire, as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 11That’s the way it’s to be done for each ox, ram, male lamb, or goat, 12the same for each sacrifice.

13“Every citizen of you will do those things when you present an offering by fire, as an aroma pleasing to the LORD. 14If foreigners staying with you—temporarily or permanently—want to make an offering by fire, they’ll do it the same way you do. 15-16There’ll be one statute, one law, one ordinance for you and for foreigners among you throughout your generations.” Num 15:8-16

17-18The LORD told Moses to tell Israel,

“When you go into the land where I’m taking you 19and you eat the food that’s there, lift up an offering to the LORD. 20-21From the first of your dough, lift up a cake as an offering from the threshing floor. Num 15:17-21

Unintentional Sins

22-23“When the whole community unintentionally fails to observe any commandment, 24they’ll offer 1 bull for a burnt offering (as an aroma pleasing to the LORD, with its grain offering and liquid offering) and 1 male goat for a sin offering. 25The priest will atone for the whole community because they brought the offering to the LORD for their error. 26He’ll forgive the community, including any foreigner among them, since it wasn’t intentional. Num 15:22-26

27“If one of you sins unintentionally, offer a year-old female goat for a sin offering. 28The priest will atone for you in front of the LORD. 29For doing something unintentionally, there’ll be one law for a native and a foreigner.

30“But if you do something intentionally, native or foreign, you’re blaspheming the LORD. You’ll be excluded from the community. 31Your guilt will remain because you’ve disregarded the LORD’s message and broken his commandment.”

Execution of a Sabbath Breaker

32When Israel was in the desert, they found a fellow gathering wood on the Sabbath. 33They brought him to Moses, Aaron, and the community. 34They put him in custody because it hadn’t been specified what should happen to him. 35The LORD told Moses, “Execute him. Have the community stone him outside the camp.” 36The community took him outside the camp and stoned him. Num 15:27-36

Tassels on Clothing

37The LORD also said to Moses,

38“Tell Israel to make tassels for the hems of their cloaks throughout their generations. Put a blue cord on the tassel for each corner. 39When you see it, remember to do everything the LORD commands instead of doing what’s in your own mind and thereby becoming a prostitute. 40Set yourselves apart to your God. 41I’m the LORD who brought you out of Egypt to be your God.” Num 15:37-41

Korah’s Rebellion

16:1Korah son of Izhar son of Kohath son of Levi, along with Dathan and Abiram sons of Eliab and On son of Peleth (descendants of Reuben)—2rebelled together with 250 prominent, chosen leaders of the community. 3They gathered against Moses and Aaron, and said,

“You’ve gone far enough. The whole community is holy, every one of them, and the LORD’s among them. Why place yourselves above the LORD’s assembly?” Num 16:1-3

4When Moses heard it, he fell on his face. 5Then he told Korah and his company,

“Tomorrow morning the LORD will show who’s his and who’s holy. He’ll bring near the one he chooses. 6You and your company take censers 7tomorrow and put fire in them and incense on them in the LORD’s presence. The man he designates will be the one that’s holy. You’ve gone far enough, you descendants of Levi. [8] 9Aren’t you satisfied that God has set you apart from the community, and brought you near to service the Tabernacle and perform service to the community? 10Isn’t it enough that he’s brought you near? Are you trying to usurp the priesthood too? 11You and your company have gathered against the LORD. Why criticize Aaron?” Num 16:4-11

12Moses sent for Dathan and Abiram, but they said,

“We’re not coming. 13Isn’t it enough that you’ve brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to have us die in a desert? You also want to lord it over us. 14You haven’t brought us to a land flowing with milk and honey. You haven’t given us fields and vineyards to inherit. Do you want to put out these men’s eyes? We’re not coming!”

15Moses was really mad and said to the LORD, “Don’t regard their offering! I haven’t taken a single donkey of theirs or harmed any of them.” 16Moses told Korah,

“You and your company, along with Aaron, present yourselves to the LORD tomorrow. 17Each of you 250 and Aaron, take your firepans, put incense on them, and bring them to the LORD.”

18They took their censers and put fire and incense on them. They stood at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting with Moses and Aaron. 19Korah gathered the community against them there. The glory of the LORD appeared to the whole community. Num 16:12-19

20He told Moses and Aaron, 21“Get away from the community so I can consume them instantly.”

22But they fell on their faces and said, “God, God of everyone’s spirit, when one person sins, will you direct your anger at the whole community?”

23He said to Moses and Aaron, 24“Tell them to get away from where Korah, Dathan, and Abiram live.” Num 16:20-24

25Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the elders followed him. 26He told the community, “Get away from these men’s tents. Don’t touch anything that’s theirs or you’ll get swept away in their sin.” 27They got away from where Korah, Dathan, and Abiram lived. Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrance to their tents with their wives, sons, and little ones. 28Moses said,

“This is how you’ll know the LORD has sent me to do this; it’s not my idea. 29If these men die naturally or suffer a typical fate, the LORD hasn’t sent me. 30But if he causes something entirely new and the ground opens up and swallows them and what’s theirs, you’ll understand that they’ve rejected the LORD.” Num 16:25-30

31Just as he finished speaking, the ground under them gaped open. 32It swallowed them, their families, the people that belonged to Korah, and their possessions. 33They all went down to Sheol alive, and the ground closed back over them. 34Everybody around them fled at their outcry, “The ground may swallow us!” 35Fire from the LORD also consumed the 250 men that were offering incense.

36The LORD said to Moses,

37“Tell Eleazar to pick up the censers from the blaze and scatter the embers. 38Hammer the censors into sheets for plating the altar, since they did present them to the LORD and they’re holy. They’ll serve as a sign for Israel.”

39Eleazar took the bronze censers and hammered them out as plating for the altar. 40That was to remind Israel that no layman—someone not descended from Aaron—should come to burn incense to the LORD; he’d end up like Korah and his company. Num 16:31-40

41But the next day the community criticized Moses and Aaron, “You made the LORD’s people die.” 42However, Moses and Aaron turned toward the Tent of Meeting, and the cloud covered it, and the glory of the LORD appeared. 43They went to the front of the Tent, 44and the LORD told Moses, 45“Get away from the community so I can consume them all at once.” They fell on their faces. 46Moses told Aaron,

“Take your censer, put fire in it from the altar, and add incense to it. Hurry and take it to the community and atone for them. The LORD’s anger has gone out and started a plague!”

47Aaron did that and ran into the assembly and put on the incense and atoned for them. 48He stood between the dead and living, and the plague stopped. 49But 14,700 died from it besides the ones that died because of Korah. 50Aaron went back to Moses at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting because the plague had stopped. Num 16:41-50

Aaron’s Rod That Budded

17:1The LORD said to Moses,

2“Tell the Israelites to get a rod from each family leader. Write each man’s name on his rod 3and write Aaron’s name on Levi’s rod. 4Then put them in the Tent of Meeting in front of the Testimony where I meet you. 5The rod of the man I choose will sprout. I’ll stifle the criticism of your critics.

6Moses told the Israelites to give him a rod for each family leader (12 rods) with Aaron’s rod among them. 7Moses put the rods in front of the LORD in the Tent of Testimony. Num 17:1-7

8The next day Moses went into the Tent, and Aaron’s rod had sprouted, put out buds, produced blossoms, and bore ripe almonds. 9Moses brought out the rods as the Israelites watched and each man took his rod. 10But the LORD told Moses,

“Put Aaron’s rod back in front of the Testimony to keep as a sign against the rebels so you can stop their complaining against me and they don’t die.”

11Moses did that.

12The Israelites said to Moses, “We’re perishing! We’re all dying! 13Everybody that goes near the Tabernacle dies. Are we all going to perish?” Num 17:8-13

Duties of Priests and Levites

18:1So the LORD told Aaron,

“You, your sons, and your father’s family will be responsible for the sanctuary. You and your sons will be responsible for the priesthood. 2But take your relatives from the tribe of Levi to help you while you and your sons serve in the Tent of Testimony. 3They’ll make preparations throughout the Tent, but they can’t approach the sanctuary furnishings or the altar, or they and you will die. 4An outsider can’t come near you. 5They’ll tend to preparations for the sanctuary and the altar so there won’t be any more anger on Israel. 6I’ll give your fellow Levites to you, dedicated to the LORD, to service the Tent of Meeting. 7But you and your sons will tend to everything around the altar and inside the curtain. I’m giving you the priesthood as a service; execute any outsider that comes near.”

Num 18:1-7

8Then the LORD told Aaron,

“I’ve put you in charge of my heave offerings. 9As a permanent allotment, I’ve given you and your sons the holy gifts the Israelites bring. That will be yours from the most holy things, reserved from the fire. Every grain offering, sin offering, and gift offering will be most holy for you and your sons. 10Every male of yours will eat them.

11Their wave offerings are yours too. I’ve given them to you and your sons and daughters as an ongoing allotment. Anybody in your family that’s ceremonially clean can eat them.

12I’ve given you the best of the fresh olive oil, fresh wine, and grain— the first part of the harvest that the people bring to me. 13They belong to you. Anybody in your family that’s ceremonially clean can eat them.

14Devoted things in Israel are yours. 15You’ll have the first issue of the womb of people and animals that’s offered to me. Nevertheless, you’ll redeem firstborn people and ceremonially unclean animals. 16The redemption price from a month old will be 2 oz of silver 5 shekels of the sanctuary (20 gerahs a shekel). 17But you can’t redeem a firstborn ox, sheep, or goat; they’re holy. Sprinkle their blood on the altar and offer up their fat in smoke as a burnt offering, for an aroma pleasing to me. 18All their meat will be yours like the breast of a wave offering and the right thigh. 19The holy gifts are a permanent allotment to you, your sons, and daughters—a permanent covenant of salt with me for you and your descendants.” Num 18:8-19

20The LORD told Aaron,

“You won’t own or inherit land. I’m your portion, service in the Tent of Meeting. 21I’ve given the Levites a tithe from Israel as payment for their service. 22Israelites can’t approach the Tent of Meeting anymore, or they’ll be held guilty and die. 23Only Levites will perform service there. They’ll bear that responsibility as an ongoing statute throughout your generations. [24]” Num 18:20-24

25The LORD told Moses to tell the Levites,

26“When you receive the tithe from Israel, present a tenth of it to the LORD. 27It will be considered equivalent to the grain from the threshing floor or the wine from the wine vat. 28You, too, will present an offering to the LORD—from the tithes you receive. Present it to Aaron the priest 29from the best of the tithes, their sacred portion. 30Tell them, ‘When you’ve offered the best of it, the rest will be considered equivalent to the Levites as the product of the threshing floor or the wine vat. 31You and your families can eat it anywhere; it’s your compensation for service in the Tent of Meeting. 32You won’t be held guilty when you’ve offered the best of it. Don’t profane the Israelites’ sacred gifts, or you’ll die.’” Num 18:25-32

Water of Purification

19:1The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

2“This is a statute of the LORD, ‘Tell the Israelites to bring you an unblemished red heifer that’s never worn a yoke. 3Give it to Eleazar to take outside the camp and slaughter in his presence. 4He’ll take some of its blood with his finger and sprinkle it toward the front of the Tent of Meeting seven times. 5Then the heifer will be burned in front of him—hide, meat, blood, and refuse. 6The priest will take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet material, and throw it onto the burning heifer. 7Then he’ll wash his clothes, take a bath, and afterward come into the camp, but he’ll be ceremonially unclean till evening. 8The one that burns it will also wash his clothes, take a bath, and be unclean till evening. 9A man that’s clean will gather the heifer’s ashes and deposit them outside the camp in a clean place, and the community will keep it as water for removing impurity from sin. 10The one that gathers the ashes will wash his clothes and be unclean till evening. A permanent statute for Israelites and foreigners living among them. Num 19:1-10

11‘Anyone of you that touches a human corpse will be ceremonially unclean for a week. 12Purify yourself with the water on the third and seventh days, and you’ll be clean. If you don’t, you’re still unclean; 13you’re defiling the LORD’s Tabernacle, and you’re excluded from Israel.

14‘If someone dies in your tent, all of you in it will be ceremonially unclean for a week. 15Every open container will be unclean. Num 19:11-15

16‘Anybody that touches a body out in the open, slain with a sword or dead from natural causes, will be ceremonially unclean for a week. 17Then for the unclean person they’ll take some ashes from the burnt purification from sin and add flowing water in a basin. 18A clean person will dip hyssop in the water and sprinkle it on the tent, its furnishings, the people that were there, and the one that touched the bone, the one slain, the one dead of natural causes, or the grave. 19Then the clean person will sprinkle the unclean persons on the third and seventh days. On the seventh day the clean purify the unclean. Then they’ll wash their clothes, take a bath, and be ceremonially clean by evening. Num 19:16-19
