21“This is what the LORD says about Ahab son of Kolaiah and Zedekiah son of Maaseiah, who are prophesying to you falsely in my name: ‘I’ll deliver them to Nebuchadnezzar; he’ll execute them in your presence. 22The exiles from Judah in Babylon will use this curse, “The LORD make you like Zedekiah and Ahab that the king of Babylon roasted in fire.” 23They acted foolishly in Israel and committed adultery with their neighbors’ wives. They lied in my name. I’m the One who knows; I see everything that happens.’” Jer 29:15-23

A Message for Shemaiah

24Tell Shemaiah the Nehelamite,

25“Because you’ve sent letters in your own name to the people in Jerusalem, to Zephaniah son of Maaseiah the priest and all the other priests, and said, 26‘The LORD has made you priests in place of Jehoiada, to oversee his Temple over every mad man that prophesies, to put him in stocks and an iron collar. 27Why haven’t you rebuked Jeremiah of Anathoth, who prophesies to you? 28He sent to us in Babylon and said, “It will be a long exile. Build houses and live in them; plant gardens and eat what they grow.”’” Jer 29:24-28

29Zephaniah the priest read that letter to Jeremiah, 30and a message came from the LORD to Jeremiah, 31“Send to all the exiles:

‘The LORD says this about Shemaiah because he’s prophesied to you though I didn’t send him and made you believe a lie: 32“I’m about to punish him. He won’t have any descendants or see the good I’m going to do for my people, because he incited rebellion against me.”’” Jer 29:29-32

30:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

A Promise to Restore Israel

2“The LORD God of Israel says, ‘Write in a scroll everything I’ve told you, 3because the time’s coming when I’ll restore the fortunes of Israel and Judah. I’ll bring my people back to take over the land I gave their ancestors.’”

4This is what the LORD said about Israel and Judah:

5“I’ve heard the sound of terror and dread;

there’s no peace.

6Ask and see if a man can have a baby.

Why do I see every man

with his hands on his crotch

like a woman in childbirth?

Why have their faces turned pale?

7That day will be like no other,

a time of Jacob’s distress,

but I’ll deliver him from it.

8I’ll break the yoke off his neck and tear off its straps. Foreigners won’t enslave him anymore. 9He’ll serve the LORD his God and David his king that I’ll raise up for him.” Jer 30:1-9

10“Don’t be afraid, Jacob my servant;

don’t be distressed, Israel.

From a long way off, I’ll save you and your offspring

from the land where you’re captive.

Jacob will come back and be at ease;

nobody will terrorize him.

11‘I’m with you to save you,

to destroy the nations where I’ve scattered you.

You’re the one I won’t destroy completely.

I’ll discipline you justly

and certainly not let you go unpunished. Jer 30:10-11

12“Your wound can’t heal;

you’re too seriously injured.

13There’s nobody to argue your case,

no healing for your sore,

no recovery for you.

14All your lovers have forgotten about you;

they’re not looking for you.

I’ve wounded you like a cruel enemy would

because your sins were severe and numerous.

15Why cry out because of your injury?

Your pain can’t be relieved.

I’ve done that to you

because of your great iniquity,

your many sins.

16So everybody that devours you will be devoured;

your captors will go into captivity.

Your plunderers will become plunder;

those who prey on you I’ll make prey.

17I’ll restore you to health and heal your wounds,

because they’ve called you an outcast and said,

‘That’s Zion; nobody cares about it.’ Jer 30:12-17

18“The LORD says,

‘I’ll restore the fortunes of Jacob’s tents

and have mercy on where he’s living.

The city will be rebuilt on its ruins;

the palace will stand in its rightful place.

19Thanksgiving will go out from them,

and the sound of people having fun.

I’ll multiply them, not decrease them;

I’ll honor them; they’ll be significant.

20They’ll have children like before;

their community will be safe with me;

I’ll punish their oppressors. Jer 30:18-20

21One of their own will lead them;

their ruler will come from among themselves.

I’ll bring him near, and he’ll approach me;

who would dare risking his life to approach me on his own?

22You’ll be my people,

and I’ll be your God.’” Jer 30:21-22

23The LORD’s storm!

His anger has gone out like a tornado;

it will burst down on the heads of sinners.

24The LORD’s fierce anger won’t relent

till he’s accomplished his purpose.

Later you’ll understand. Jer 30:23-24

31:1“At that time,” the LORD says,

“I’ll be the God of every family in Israel,

and they’ll be my people.

2The people that survived the sword

found grace in the desert

when Israel was looking for rest.”

3The LORD appeared to him from afar and said,

“I’ve loved you with enduring love;

so I’ve drawn you with lovingkindness.

4I’ll rebuild you, virgin of Israel!

You’ll pick up your tambourines again

and join the dance.

5You’ll plant your vineyards on Samaria’s hills again;

you that plant them will enjoy them.

6There’ll be a time when watchmen

on the hilltops in Ephraim will call out,

‘Let’s go up to Zion to the LORD our God.’” Jer 31:1-6

7The LORD says,

“Sing out loud with happiness for Jacob;

shout among the chiefs of the nations.

Proclaim, give praise, and say,

‘LORD, save the remnant of Israel.’

8I’ll bring them from the north country;

I’ll gather them from the remote parts of the world,

the blind and lame among them,

the pregnant,

and those in labor—

that large company will come back here.

9They’ll come weeping,

and I’ll be leading them with consolation;

I’ll make them walk by streams

on a straight path where they won’t stumble;

I’m Israel’s father;

Ephraim’s my firstborn.” Jer 31:7-9

10Nations, listen to a message from the LORD

and announce it in distant lands:

“The One that scattered Israel will gather him

and keep him like a shepherd keeps his flock.”

11The LORD has ransomed Jacob,

redeemed him from someone stronger than he is.

12“They’ll come and shout for joy on Zion’s hill,

and be radiant over the bounty from the LORD—

the grain, new wine, and olive oil;

the young in the flock and herd;

they’ll thrive like a watered garden

and never wilt again.

13The virgins will celebrate in the dance;

the young men and old will celebrate together.

I’ll turn your mourning into joy,

comfort you, and replace sorrow with happiness.

14I’ll fill the soul of the priests with abundance;

my goodness will be satisfying to my people.” Jer 31:10-14

15The LORD says,

“A sound was heard in Ramah,

weeping and bitter crying,

Rachel weeping for her children;

she couldn’t be consoled,

because they were gone.” Jer 31:15

16The LORD says,

“Don’t cry or shed tears;

your work will be rewarded.

They’ll come back from their enemy’s land.

17There’s hope for your future;

your children will return to their own land.

18I’ve heard Ephraim moaning,

‘You’ve disciplined me like an untrained calf.

Bring me back so I can be restored

because you’re the LORD my God.

19After I turned around, I repented;

after I was instructed, I struck my thigh.

I was ashamed and humiliated

because I carried the disgrace of my youth.’

20Is Ephraim my dear son,

my delightful child?

As often as I’ve spoken against him,

I’ll still remember him.

My heart yearns to have mercy on him. Jer 31:16-20

21“Set up road signs, erect guideposts;

look at the highway you used when you left.

Come, virgin of Israel;

come back to your cities.

22How long will you wander around,

unfaithful daughter?

The LORD has created a new thing in the world—

a woman protecting a man.” Jer 31:21-22

23The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says, “They’ll speak this message again in Judah’s towns when I restore their fortunes:

‘The LORD bless you, righteous home, holy hill!’

24Judah’s townspeople, farmers and herdsmen will live in harmony. 25I’ll satisfy the weary and refresh the fainting.” Jer 31:23-25

26Then I woke up; my sleep was pleasant.

27“The time’s coming when I’ll sow Israel and Judah with people and animals. 28As I’ve watched over them to pull up, tear down, overthrow, destroy, and bring disaster; so I’ll watch over them to plant and build. 29They won’t say anymore,

‘The parents ate sour grapes,

and the children’s mouths puckered.’

30Everybody will die for their own sin. Those who eat sour grapes will be the ones whose mouths pucker.

31“The time’s coming,” the LORD says, “when I’ll make a new covenant with Israel and Judah. 32It won’t be like the one I made with their ancestors when I brought them out of Egypt. They broke that covenant even though I was a husband to them. 33I’ll make this kind of covenant with them: I’ll put my Law inside them; I’ll write it on their heart. I’ll be their God and they’ll be my people. 34No one will be teaching their brother and fellow citizen to know the LORD, because they’ll all know me from least to greatest. I’ll forgive their sin; I won’t keep it in mind anymore.” Jer 31:26-34

35The LORD says—

who provides the sun to light the day

and the moon and stars for light at night,

who makes the sea roar,

whose name is Yahveh of Hosts—

36“If this fixed order can disappear,

then Israel’s offspring can disappear

from being a nation that serves me.

37If the sky above can be measured

and the earth’s foundations can be explored,

then I can throw away Israel’s offspring

for everything they’ve done. Jer 31:35-37

38“The time’s coming,” the LORD says, “when the city will be rebuilt for me from the Tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate. 39The measuring line will go out farther straight ahead to the hill Gareb and then turn to Goah. 40The whole valley of dead bodies and ashes, the fields over to the Brook Kidron to the corner of the Horse Gate on the east—will be sacred to me, never again uprooted or thrown down.” Jer 31:38-40

32:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

in the Tenth Year of Zedekiah, King of Judah

(Eighteenth Year of Nebuchadnezzar)

Jeremiah Buys a Field

2-3Babylon’s army was laying siege to Jerusalem. Zedekiah had shut Jeremiah up in the courtyard of the guard in the royal palace, and said,

“Why do you prophesy that the LORD says, ‘I’m about to give the city to the king of Babylon. 4Zedekiah won’t escape; the king of Babylon will speak to him face to face. 5He’ll take him to Babylon till I visit him. If you fight the Babylonians, you’ll lose’?”

6Jeremiah said,

“A message from the LORD came to me, 7‘Hanamel son of Shallum your uncle is coming to tell you to buy his field in Anathoth; you have first-right to redeem it.’”

8He did come to me in the courtyard of the guard like the LORD said, and told me, “Buy my field at Anathoth in Benjamin. It’s yours to redeem.” Jer 32:1-8a

Then I knew it was a message from the LORD. 9I bought the field from my cousin and weighed out 6.8 oz 17 shekels of silver for him. 10I called in witnesses, signed and sealed the deed, and weighed out the silver on the scales. 11I took the sealed copy containing the terms and conditions, and the unsealed copy, 12and gave them to Baruch son of Neriah son of Mahseiah in front of Hanamel and the witnesses who signed it in the presence of the Jews sitting in the courtyard of the guard. 13In front of them I told Baruch, Jer 32:18b-13

14“The LORD of Hosts says, ‘Take the sealed deed of purchase and the unsealed copy and put them in a clay jar to preserve them a long time. 15People will buy houses, fields, and vineyards in this land again.’”

16After I gave Baruch the deed, I prayed, 17“Lord GOD, you made earth and sky by your great power! There’s nothing’s you can’t do. 18You show enduring love to thousands, but pay the consequences of one generations’ sins on the next, great powerful God. Your name is Yahveh of Hosts. 19You’re great in counsel and powerful in deed. You see everything people do and repay them accordingly. 20You showed signs and wonders in Egypt, in our time in Israel, and elsewhere. You’ve made a name for yourself. 21You brought your people out of Egypt with signs and wonders, with a strong hand, outstretched arm, and great terror. 22You gave them this land you swore to their ancestors you’d give them, a land flowing with milk and honey. 23They took possession of it, but they didn’t obey your Law; so you brought this catastrophe on them. 24Siege mounds have come up to take it by sword, famine, and disease. You’ll give it to the Babylonians. What you said has happened. 25Lord GOD, you told me to buy the field and call witnesses, even though you’re giving the city to the Babylonians.’”

Jer 32:14-25

26A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

27“I’m the LORD God of all people. Is there anything I can’t do? 28I’m about to give this city to the Babylonians, to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. 29They’ll come in and set it on fire and burn down the houses where people made me angry by offering incense to Baal on the roofs and pouring out liquid offerings to other gods. 30From the beginning, Israel and Judah have been doing everything I’ve forbidden. 31This city has been provoking me ever since they built it. I’m going to put it out of my sight 32because of the sinful things the kings, leaders, priests, prophets, and people in Judah and Jerusalem have done. 33They turned their back on me. Though I taught them over and over, they wouldn’t accept my instruction. 34With the detestable things they put in it, they defiled the Temple that wears my name. 35They built high places to Baal in the Valley of (Ben)Hinnom and sacrificed their sons and daughters as burnt offerings to Molech. I didn’t command that! It never entered my mind that they would do something so detestable. Jer 32:26-35

36So this is what the LORD God of Israel says about this city he has given over to sword, famine, and disease: 37“I’ll gather them out of the lands where I drive them in my anger, wrath, and great indignation, and bring them back here to live safely. 38They’ll be my people and I’ll be their God. 39I’ll give them one heart and one way so they’ll always respect me for the good of them and their descendants. 40I’ll make an everlasting covenant not to abandon them and to put respect for me in their hearts so they won’t abandon me. 41With all my heart and soul, I’ll enjoy doing them good and faithfully planting them in this land. 42Just as I brought this catastrophe on them, I’ll bring on them all the good I’m promising. 43People will buy fields in this land that you say is ‘a waste without people or animals,’ a land lost to the Babylonians. 44They’ll call witnesses and seal deeds in Benjamin, in Jerusalem, in the towns in Judah, the hill country, the western foothills, and the Negev. I’ll restore their fortunes.” Jer 32:36-44

33:1The LORD’s Second Message to Jeremiah

While Confined in the Courtyard of the Guard

2This is what the LORD says who made the earth, formed and established it: 3“Call out to me, and I’ll tell you important things you don’t know.” 4The God of Israel says this about the houses in this city—including the palace of Judah’s kings—that were torn down to get materials for defending against the siege mounds and the sword, 5“They’re coming to fight the Babylonians and fill the houses with the corpses of men that in my anger I’ve destined to die. I withdrew because of their sinfulness. 6Later I’ll bring them health and healing, and show them true prosperity and peace. 7I’ll restore the fortunes of Judah and Israel and rebuild them like they were before. 8I’ll cleanse them from their sin against me. 9This city will have a world-wide reputation for joy, praise, and honor to me. The nations will hear about the good I’m doing for it, and tremble at the peace I’m making for it.” Jer 33:1-9

10The LORD says, “You say this place is a waste without people or animals—desolate towns in Judah and streets in Jerusalem. 11But you’ll hear again the sound of happiness, the voices of bride and groom, of people who say,

‘Thank the LORD of Hosts;

he’s good;

his love endures forever.’

You’ll hear people bringing thank offerings to his Temple. I’ll restore the fortunes of the land like they were in the beginning.’

12The LORD of Hosts says, “Shepherds will bed down their flocks in the towns that are ‘a waste without people or animals.’ 13Flocks will pass again under the hands of the one that’s counting them in the hill country, the western foothills, the Negev, in Benjamin, around Jerusalem, and Judah. Jer 33:10-13

14“The time’s coming when I’ll keep the promise I’ve made about Israel and Judah. 15A good Branch will sprout from David and carry out justice and goodness in the land. 16Judah will be saved and Jerusalem will live safely. His name will be Yahveh Is Our Goodness [Yahveh Tsidekenu]. 17David will always have a man on the throne. 18The Levitical priests will always have a man to offer me burnt offerings, to burn grain offerings, and to prepare sacrifices.”

Jer 33:14-18

19A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

20“If my covenant with day and night could be broken so they wouldn’t happen at their appointed times, 21then my covenant could also be broken so that David wouldn’t have a descendant on his throne and the Levitical priests wouldn’t serve as my ministers. 22As the stars in the sky can’t be counted and the sand on the shore can’t be numbered, that’s how much I’ll multiply the descendants of David my servant and the Levites my ministers.” Jer 33:19-22

23A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

24“Have you noticed how the people say the LORD has rejected the two families he chose? They don’t consider my people one nation. 25My covenant with day and night stands. As sure as I’ve established the patterns of earth and sky, 26I’ll keep the offspring of Jacob and choose a descendant of David to rule the offspring of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. I’ll show them mercy and restore their fortunes.’” Jer 33:23-26

34:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

When Nebuchadnezzar, King of Babylon

and His Army and the Kingdoms He Ruled Were

Fighting Jerusalem and Surrounding Towns

A Warning to Zedekiah

2Go tell Zedekiah, king of Judah, that the LORD says, “I’m giving this city to the king of Babylon, and he’ll burn it. 3You’ll be captured and turned over to him. You’ll see him in person, he’ll speak to you directly, and you’ll go to Babylon.” 4But listen to the LORD, Zedekiah! “You won’t die by the sword; 5you’ll die in peace. As they burned spices for the kings before you, they’ll burn spices and lament, ‘Ah, lord!’ for you. I’ve spoken.”

6That’s what Jeremiah told Zedekiah 7while Babylon’s army was fighting Jerusalem, Lachish, and Azekah, the only fortified cities left in Judah. Jer 34:1-7

8A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

After King Zedekiah Made an Agreement

with the People in Jerusalem to Declare Liberty

A Warning to Zedekiah

9Each man was to free his Hebrew male and female slaves so nobody would enslave a fellow Jewish. 10The officials and the people obeyed and agreed not to hold them as slaves any longer. 11But afterward they went back on their word and brought their freed slave back into subjection. Jer 34:8-11

12Then a message from the LORD came to Jeremiah:

13The LORD God of Israel says, “I made a covenant with your ancestors when I brought them out of bondage in Egypt. 14At the end of seven years, set your fellow Hebrew free that’s been sold to you. But your ancestors didn’t obey me. 15Recently you changed and did what was right. You freed your fellow citizen and made a covenant in my presence. 16But you’ve gone back on your word and profaned my name. You’ve enslaved again the slaves you’d freed. Jer 34:12-16

17“You haven’t obeyed me by releasing your brother and fellow citizen; so I’m releasing you to sword, famine, and disease. I’ll make you something other kingdoms abhor. 18-20The ones that didn’t keep that covenant, I’ll release to their enemies that want to kill them: officials in Judah and Jerusalem, court officers, priests, and common people who cut a calf in two and passed between its parts. Their dead bodies will feed the buzzards from the sky and scavengers on the ground. 21I’ll deliver Zedekiah and his officials to their enemies, 22and direct them to attack this city again, burn it, and fill Judah with ghost towns.”

Jer 34:17-22

35:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

at the Time of Jehoiakim Son of Josiah, King of Judah

The Obedience of the Racabites

2“Go bring the Rechabites to a room in the LORD’s Temple and offer them wine.”

3I took Jaazaniah son of Jeremiah son of Habazziniah, his brothers and sons—the whole family of Rechabites—4to the LORD’s Temple to the office for the sons of Hanan son of Igdaliah, the man of God. It was close to the officials’ quarters, above the room for Maaseiah son of Shallum, the doorkeeper. 5I put pitchers of wine and cups in front of the Rechabites, “Have a drink!”

6But they said,

“We won’t drink wine. Our ancestor Jonadab/Jehonadab son of Rechab told us, ‘Never drink wine, you or your descendants, forever. 7Don’t build houses, sow seed, plant vineyards, or own them. Live in tents so you’ll live a long time in the land.’ 8We, our wives, sons, and daughters have obeyed him. 9We don’t build houses or own vineyards, fields, or seed. 10We live in tents. 11But when Nebuchadnezzar invaded the land, we came to Jerusalem before the Babylonian and Syrian armies got here. So we’ve been living in Jerusalem.” Jer 35:1-11

12Then a message from the LORD came to Jeremiah,

13The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says,

“Tell the people in Judah and Jerusalem, ‘Won’t you receive instruction and listen to me? 14The descendants of Jonadab still observe his command not to drink wine. I’ve spoken to you time and again, but you’ve ignored me. 15I’ve sent you prophets time and again and said, “Turn from your sinful way, correct your deeds, don’t go after other gods so you can live in the land I’ve given you and your ancestors.” But you’ve ignored me. 16Jonadab’s descendants have observed their ancestor’s command, but you’ve ignored me. 17So, I’m bringing on Judah and Jerusalem the disaster I’ve threatened.

I spoke to them, but they ignored me;

I called out to them, but they didn’t answer.’”

18Then Jeremiah told the Rechabites, “The LORD of Hosts says, ‘Because you’ve obeyed Jonadab, 19he’ll always have descendants to serve me.’” Jer 35:12-19

36:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

in the Fourth Year of Jehoiakim Son of Josiah, King of Judah

Baruch Reads Aloud the LORD’s Messages

2“On a scroll, write down everything I’ve told you about Israel, Judah, and the nations from Josiah’s time till now. 3Maybe Judah will listen to the catastrophe I intend to bring on them to get them to repent. Then I’ll forgive them.”

4Jeremiah called for Baruch son of Neriah, and he wrote down the LORD’s messages that Jeremiah dictated. 5He told Baruch,

“I can’t go to the LORD’s Temple. 6So you go on a fast day and read to the people the messages you’ve written. Read them to the people in Judah who come from their towns. 7Maybe they’ll turn from their sinful ways and ask for his forgiveness. The LORD has pronounced great anger against them.”

8Baruch did that and read the messages in the Temple. Jer 36:1-8

9In the ninth month, fifth year of Jehoiakim/Coniah, the people in Jerusalem and Judah declared a fast to the LORD. 10What Jeremiah said, Baruch read in the quarters of Gemariah son of Shaphan the secretary, in the upper courtyard at the entry of the New Gate to the Temple.

11When Micaiah son of Gemariah heard it, 12he went down to the secretary’s office in the king’s palace. The officials were sitting there—Elishama the secretary, Delaiah son of Shemaiah, Elnathan son of Achbor, Gemariah son of Shaphan, Zedekiah son of Hananiah, and the others. 13He told them what he heard Baruch reading to the people. 14They sent Jehudi son of Nethaniah (son of Shelemiah son of Cushi) to Baruch and said, “Bring the scroll you read to the people.”

So Baruch took it to them. Jer 36:9-14

15“Sit down and read it to us.”

16When they heard it, they turned in fear to one another and said to Baruch, “We have to report this to the king. 17Tell us how you wrote this. Did Jeremiah dictate it?”

18“He dictated it to me, and I wrote it in ink on the scroll.

19The officials said, “Both of you, go hide. Don’t tell anybody where you are.”

King Jehoiakim Burns the Scroll

20So they reported to the king what it said, but they’d deposited the scroll in the office of Elishama the secretary. 21He sent Jehudi to get it, and he read it to the king and the officials standing beside him. 22The king was sitting in the winter palace in the ninth month, with a fire burning in the brazier beside him. 23When Jehudi had read three or four columns, the king would cut them off with a scribe’s knife and throw them in the brazier till he’d burned up the whole scroll. 24The king and his attendants weren’t afraid and didn’t tear their clothes. 25Even though Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah pleaded with him not to burn the scroll, he did it anyway. 26He told Jerahmeel the king’s son, Seraiah son of Azriel, and Shelemiah son of Abdeel to arrest Baruch and Jeremiah; but the LORD hid them. Jer 36:15-26

27A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

After the King Burned the Scroll

Baruch Had Written at Jeremiah’s Dictation

Jeremiah Rewrites the Scroll

28“Take another scroll and write down everything again. 29Say to Jehoiakim, king of Judah, ‘You burned this scroll and said, “Why did you write that the king of Babylon will destroy this land and empty out its people and animals?” 30This is the LOR’s answer: ‘You won’t have any descendant to sit on David’s throne. They’ll toss your dead body out to the heat of the day and the frost of the night. 31I’ll punish you, your family, and your attendants for your sins. I’ll bring on you and the people in Jerusalem and Judah the catastrophe I’ve declared—but they didn’t listen.’”

32So Jeremiah gave Baruch another scroll, and dictated everything Jehoiakim had burned, and added similar messages. Jer 36:27-32

Jeremiah Imprisoned

37:1Zedekiah son of Josiah, that Nebuchadnezzar had appointed as king in Judah, ruled in place of Coniah son of Jehoiakim. 2But he, his attendants, and the people that were left ignored what the LORD said through Jeremiah.

3Yet King Zedekiah sent Jehucal son of Shelemiah and Zephaniah son of Maaseiah the priest to Jeremiah to say, “Pray to the LORD our God on our behalf.” 4Jeremiah was still moving freely among the people because they hadn’t put him in prison yet. 5Meantime, Pharaoh’s army had set out from Egypt. When the Babylonians besieging Jerusalem heard about that, they lifted the siege. Jer 37:1-5

6A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

7“Tell the king that sent you to inquire from me, ‘Pharaoh’s army that‘s come out to help you will go back to Egypt. 8The Babylonians will come back and attack this city, capture and burn it. 9Don’t deceive yourselves into thinking they’ll leave. 10Even if you’d defeated the whole Babylonian army and only the wounded were left in their tents, they’d get up and burn the city.’”

11When the Babylonian army lifted the siege from Jerusalem because of Pharaoh’s army, 12Jeremiah left Jerusalem for the territory of Benjamin to take over some property there. 13At the Benjamin Gate, a sentry named Irijah (son of Shelemiah son of Hananiah) arrested him, claiming he was deserting to the Babylonians! 14Jeremiah denied it, but he wouldn’t listen. He arrested him and took him to the officials. 15They were mad at Jeremiah, and beat him and put him in jail in the house of Jonathan the secretary, which they’d converted into a prison. Jer 37:6-15

16When he’d been in the dungeon many days, 17King Zedekiah secretly brought him to his palace to ask him if any message had come from the LORD.

“Yes! You’ll be turned over to the king of Babylon! 18How have I sinned against you, your attendants, or the people that you’ve put me in prison? 19Where are your prophets now that said the king of Babylon wouldn’t attack you or this land? 20But listen now, my lord the king. Don’t put me back in Jonathan’s house to die.”

21King Zedekiah commanded them to commit him to the courtyard of the guard. They gave him a loaf of bread each day from the bakers’ street till the bread in the city ran out. So he remained in the courtyard of the guard. Jer 37:16-21

Jeremiah Put in a Cistern

38:1Shephatiah son of Mattan, Gedaliah son of Pashhur, Jucal son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur son of Malchijah heard what Jeremiah was telling the people:

2“The LORD says, ‘If you stay in the city, you’ll die by sword, famine, and disease. If you surrender, you’ll have your life as a reward of war. 3The king of Babylon’s army is going to capture the city.’”

4The officials told the king,

“Execute him. He’s discouraging the fighting men in the city and the people by telling them things like that. He’s not looking out for their welfare, but their harm.”

5King Zedekiah said, “Do with him whatever you want.”

6They put Jeremiah in a cistern that belonged to Malchijah the king’s son in the court of the guardhouse. They let him down with ropes. There wasn’t any water in it, but he sank in the mud. Jer 38:1-6

7But Ebed-melech the Nubian, a eunuch in the king’s palace, heard they’d put him in the cistern. The king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate. 8Ebed-melech left the palace to speak to him,

9“My lord the king, these fellows have done something awful to Jeremiah; they’ve put him in a cistern. He’ll starve to death; there’s no more bread in the city.”

10The king said, “Take 30 men from here under your authority and get him out before he dies.”

11So Ebed-melech took them to a place under the storeroom in the king’s palace. They took worn-out clothes and rags, and let them down by ropes into the cistern to Jeremiah. 12“Put these under your arms over the ropes.” 13They pulled him up out of the cistern, and he remained in the court of the guardhouse. Jer 38:7-13

Jeremiah Warns Zedekiah Again

14Then King Zedekiah had Jeremiah brought to the third entrance of the LORD’s Temple, “I’m going to ask you something. Don’t keep back anything from me.”

15Jeremiah said, “If I tell you, won’t you put me to death? If I give you advice, you won’t take it.”

16But King Zedekiah swore to him privately, “As sure as the LORD lives who made this life for us, I won’t put you to death or turn you over to the ones who want to kill you.”

17So Jeremiah said,

“The LORD God of hosts says, ‘You’ll live if you go out to the officials of Babylon. The city won’t be burned, and you and your household will survive. 18If you don’t surrender, the city will fall, they’ll burn it, and you won’t escape.’”

Jer 38:14-18

19King Zedekiah said, “I’m afraid the Jews that have deserted to the Babylonians may turn me over to them, and they’ll torture me.”

20“They won’t do that. Obey the LORD so you’ll live. 21If you keep refusing to go out, this is what the LORD has shown me. 22The women that are left in the palace are going to be brought out to the officers of Babylon, and they’ll say,

‘Your trusted friends have deceived you

and prevailed over you.

Now that your feet are sunk in the mire,

they desert you.’

23They’ll bring out your wives and sons to the Babylonians, and you won’t escape. The king of Babylon will capture you and burn the city.”

24Zedekiah told Jeremiah,

“Don’t tell anybody what you’ve said, and you won’t die. 25If the officials hear that I’ve talked to you, ‘Tell us what you and the king talked about; don’t keep back any of it from us, and we won’t put you to death’; 26then tell them, ‘I pleaded with the king not to put me back in Jonathan’s house to die.’”

27Then the officials came to question Jeremiah. So he told them what the king commanded him, and they dropped the issue since nobody had heard the conversation. 28So Jeremiah stayed in the court of the guardhouse till Jerusalem fell. Jer 38:19-28

The Fall of Jerusalem

39:1In the tenth month, ninth year of Zedekiah, king of Judah. Nebuchadnezzar came to Jerusalem and began to lay siege to it. 2The ninth day, fourth month, eleventh year of Zedekiah, they breached the wall. 3The officials of the king of Babylon came in and sat down at the Middle Gate: Nergal-sharezer the Samgar, Nebo-sarsekim the Rabsaris, Nergal-sharezer the Rabmag, and the rest. 4When Zedekiah and his soldiers saw them, they fled at night by way of the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls and headed toward the Arabah. 5But the Babylonian army caught up with him in the plains of Jericho. They captured him and took him up to Nebuchadnezzar at Riblah in Hamath, and he passed sentence on him. 6He executed Zedekiah’s sons right in front of him and executed the nobles of Judah. 7Then he put out Zedekiah’s eyes, bound him in bronze restraints, and took him to Babylon. 8The Babylonians burned the king’s palace and the people’s houses and tore down the walls around Jerusalem. 9Nebuchadnezzar exiled to Babylon the rest of the people in the city and the ones that defected to him. 10Nebuzaradan, captain of the bodyguard, left some people in Judah that didn’t have anything, and gave them vineyards and fields. Jer 39:1-10

11Nebuchadnezzar gave Nebuzaradan orders about Jeremiah, 12“Look after him; don’t harm him. Deal with him like he tells you.” 13So Nebuzaradan, Nebushazban the Rabsaris, Nergal-sharezer the Rabmag, and the leading officials of the king of Babylon 14sent and took Jeremiah out of the court of the guardhouse and entrusted him to Gedaliah to take him home. So he stayed among the people. Jer 39:11-14

15A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

While He Was in the Guardhouse

16“Go tell Ebed-melech the Nubian, ‘The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says, “I’m about to bring my message on this city for disaster, not prosperity. It’ll take place before yousg on that day. 17But yousg won’t be given over to the men you dread. 18I’ll rescue you so you won’t fall by the sword. You’ll have to save your life by being a reward of war, because you’ve trusted in me.”’”

Jer 39:15-18

40:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

After Nebuzaradan Released Him from Ramah,

When He’d Taken Him Bound in Chains

Among the Exiles from Jerusalem and Judah

That Were Being Exiled to Babylon

Jeremiah Freed

2The captain of the bodyguard took Jeremiah and told him,

“The LORD your God declared this catastrophe on this place. 3He brought it on and did what he declared. Because your people sinned against him and ignored him, this happened to youpl. 4But I’m freeing yousg from your chains. If you prefer to come with me to Babylon, come along. I’ll take care of you. But if you prefer not to, don’t. The whole land is open to you. Go wherever seems right. 5Go to Gedaliah son of Ahikam son of Shaphan that the king of Babylon has appointed over the towns in Judah. Stay with him among the people or go somewhere else.”

So he gave him a ration and a gift, and released him. 6Jeremiah went to Mizpah to Gedaliah and stayed with him among the people that were left in the land. Jer 40:1-6

Governor Jedaliah Assassinated

7The commanders of the forces in the open country and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah over the land and put him in charge of the men, women, and children, the poorest left in the land. 8So they and their men went to Gedaliah: Ishmael son of Nethaniah; Johanan and Jonathan, sons of Kareah; Seraiah son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Jezaniah son of the Maacathite. 9Gedaliah swore to them and their men,

“Don’t be afraid to serve the Babylonians. If you stay and serve the king of Babylon, you’ll survive. 10I’ll be at Mizpah to represent you to the Babylonians that come to us. Gather in wine, summer fruit, and oil, and put them in storage containers. Live in the towns you’ve taken over. Jer 40:7-10

11The Jews in Moab, Ammon, Edom, and other countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant in Judah and appointed Gedaliah over them. 12They came back to him in Judah and gathered a bumper crop of wine and summer fruit.

13Johanan and the commanders of his forces in the open country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah 14and said, “Are you aware that Baalis, king of the Ammonites, has sent Ishmael to kill you?” But Gedaliah didn’t believe it. 15Then Johanan spoke secretly to him,

“Let me go kill Ishmael; nobody will know it. Why should he take your life, and the Jews that have gathered to you, get scattered, and the remnant of Judah perish?”

16But Gedaliah said, “Don’t do that. What you’re telling me isn’t true.” Jer 40:11-16

41:1In the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah son of Elishama from the royal family and a chief officer of the king, along with 10 men, came to Gedaliah at Mizpah. While they were eating there, 2Ishmael and the 10 men got up and struck down Gedaliah with the sword. 3He struck down the Jews that were with Gedaliah as well as the Babylonian soldiers there. Jer 41:1-3

4The next day, before anybody knew what had happened, 580 men came from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria with their beards shaved off, their clothes torn, and their bodies gashed. They had grain offerings and incense to present at the LORD’s Temple. 6Ishmael went out of Mizpah to meet them, weeping as he went. When he met them, he said, “Come in to Gedaliah.” 7But as soon as they came in the city, he and the men killed them and threw them in a cistern. 8But 10 of them said to Ishmael, “Don’t kill us. We have stores of wheat, barley, olive oil, and honey stashed in the field” so he didn’t kill them. 9The cistern that Ishmael filled with corpses was the one King Asa had made because of Baasha, king of Israel. 10Then he took captive everybody left in Mizpah, the king’s daughters, and the remaining people that Nebuzaradan had put under Gedaliah’s charge. He set out with them to cross over to the Ammonites. Jer 41:4-10

11But Johanan son of Kareah and his commanders heard what Ishmael had done. 12So they took all the men and went to fight him; they found him by the large pool in Gibeon. 13When the people with Ishmael saw Johanan and his commanders, they were happy. 14So the ones Ishmael had taken captive defected to Johanan. 15But Ishmael escaped from Johanan with 8 men and went to the Ammonites. 16Johanan and his commanders took from Mizpah the remnant of the people he’d recovered from Ishmael—the soldiers, the women, children, and eunuchs. 17They went and stayed in Geruth Chimham, near Bethlehem, with the intention of going to Egypt. 18They were afraid of the Babylonians since Ishmael had struck down Gedaliah.

Jer 41:11-18

Jeremiah’s Warning to Stay in Judah

42:1Then Johanan, his commanders, Jezaniah son of Hoshaiah, and the people least to greatest came 2to Jeremiah,

“Please honor our petition. Pray for us to the LORD your God for this remnant. There are just a few of us left, as you can see. 3Pray that the LORD will tell us what we should do.”

4Jeremiah said,

“I’ll pray to him and not keep back a word of his answer.”

5They said,

“May the LORD be a true and faithful witness against us if we don’t obey his whole message. 6Whether pleasant or not, we’ll listen so things will go well with us. Jer 42:1-6

7Ten days later, a message came to Jeremiah. 8He called Johanan, his commanders, and the people,

9“The LORD says, 10‘If you stay in this land, I’ll plant you and build you up, and relent from the catastrophe I’ve inflicted on you. 11Don’t be afraid; I’ll deliver you from the king of Babylon 12and show you mercy so he’ll have mercy and return you to your own land. 13But if you say, 14“We’ll go stay in Egypt, where we won’t be near war, hear the bugle, or go hungry,” [15] 16then the sword you fear will catch up with you, the famine you’re anxious about will follow soon after you arrive, and you’ll die there. 17Everybody that goes to Egypt will die by sword, famine, and disease. Nobody will survive the catastrophe I’ll bring.’”

Jer 42:7-17

18“‘As I’ve poured out my anger on the people in Jerusalem, I’ll pour it out on you in Egypt. You’ll become a curse, something abhorred, a disgrace. You won’t be coming back here.’ 19The LORD is telling you today not to go to Egypt! 20You’re only deceiving yourselves. You said, ‘Pray to the LORD our God; we’ll do whatever he says.’ 21But you’re not doing it. 22So understand that you’ll die by sword, famine, and disease where you want to go live.” Jer 42:18-22

43:1As soon as Jeremiah finished, 2Azariah son of Hoshaiah, Johanan son of Kareah, and the arrogant men told him, “You’re lying. The LORD didn’t say not to go live in Egypt. 3Baruch son of Neriah is prompting you to turn us over to the Babylonians so they can execute us or exile us to Babylon.” 4-5So Johanan and the commanders took to Egypt the entire remnant that had come back from the countries where they’d been driven: 6men, women, children, the king’s daughters, everyone Nebuzaradan had left with Gedaliah, together with Jeremiah and Baruch. 7They got as far as Tahpanhes. Jer 43:1-7

8The LORD told Jeremiah in Tahpanhes,

9“Bury some big rocks in the mortar in the brick terrace at the entrance to Pharaoh’s palace in Tahpanhes so some of the Jews can see it. 10Tell them that the LORD of Hosts says, ‘I’m going to send for Nebuchadnezzar my servant and set his throne on those rocks. He’ll spread his canopy over them 11when he comes to strike Egypt. The ones destined to die will die; the ones destined for captivity will go captive, the ones destined for the sword will die by the sword. 12-13He’ll burn the temples of Egypt’s gods and shatter the obelisks in Heliopolis. He’ll wrap himself with Egypt like a shepherd wraps himself in his coat and leave unscathed.’” Jer 43:8-13

44:1A Message to Jeremiah for the Jews Living in Egypt

in Migdol, Tahpanhes, Memphis, and the Territory of Pathros

Disaster Because of Idolatry

2“Yahveh of Hosts, the God of Israel, says, ‘You’ve seen the catastrophe I brought on Jerusalem and the towns in Judah; they’re in ruins. Nobody’s living in them 3because their sinfulness made me angry. They kept serving and burning sacrifices to gods they and their ancestors hadn’t known. 4Yet I sent them my prophets time and again, saying not to do that detestable thing. 5‘But they didn’t listen, turn from their sin, or quit burning sacrifices to other gods. 6So my anger boiled over and burned in the towns of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem.’ 7Now Yahveh says, ‘Why harm yourselves and slay man and woman, child and infant, from Judah and leave yourselves without even a remnant? 8You’ve made me angry with the things you’ve made with your hands and the sacrifices you’ve burned to other gods in Egypt. You’ll be destroyed and become a curse and disgrace among the nations. 9Have you forgotten your ancestors’ sinfulness, the sinfulness of Judah’s kings and their wives, the sinfulness you and your wives committed in Judah and the streets of Jerusalem? 10You haven’t humbled yourselves or respected me to this day or followed the Law and statutes I set before you and your ancestors.’ Jer 44:1-10

11“So Yahveh of Hosts says, ‘I’ll destroy everybody that’s from Judah 12and remove the remnant that’s determined to go live in Egypt. From least to greatest will meet their end here by sword or famine. They’ll become a curse, something abhorred, a disgrace. 13Like I’ve punished Jerusalem, I’ll punish Egypt with sword, famine, and disease. 14Only a few refugees will ever make it back to the land they long to see.’” Jer 44:11-14

15The men that knew their wives were burning sacrifices to other gods and the women that were standing by—including a large number from Pathros—answered Jeremiah,

16“We don’t have to listen to you! 17We’ll keep burning sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out liquid offerings to her like we and our ancestors, our kings and officials did in Judah and Jerusalem. We were well off then with plenty of food and no misfortune. 18Since we stopped doing that, we’ve lacked everything and met our end by sword and famine.” 19The women said, “When we were burning sacrifices to her, pouring out liquid offerings to her, and making sacrificial cakes in her image, didn’t our husbands know it?” Jer 44:15-19

20Jeremiah responded, 21“Didn’t Yahveh know about the smoking sacrifices you and your ancestors, kings and officials, and common people burned? 22He wouldn’t put up with your sinful deeds and detestable acts anymore. So your land has become a ruin, abhorred, a curse, and uninhabited. 23This catastrophe has fallen on you because you’ve burned sacrifices and sinned against him, and didn’t obey him or follow his Law, statutes, or testimonies. [24] 25You and your wives have said, ‘We’ll keep our vows to burn sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pour out liquid offerings to her.’ Go ahead and keep your vows! 26But listen to what Yahveh says, ‘I’ve sworn by my great name that nobody from Judah that’s in Egypt will ever invoke my name again, “As the Lord Yahveh lives . . .” 27I’ll see to it that they’re harmed. They’ll meet their end by sword and famine. 28Only a few will ever make it back to Judah. Then the remnant in Egypt will know whose message will stand, theirs or mine. 29-30This is how you’ll know: I’ll punish you here too and deliver Pharaoh Hophra [Apries] to his enemies like I turned Zedekiah over to Nebuchadnezzar.’” Jer 44:20-30

45:1The Message Jeremiah Spoke to Baruch

When He’d Written It in a Scroll at Jeremiah’s Dictation

in the Fourth Year of Jehoiakim Son of Josiah, King of Judah

Disaster Because of Idolatry

2“This is what the LORD God of Israel says to you, Baruch: 3‘You said, “Misfortune awaits me! The LORD has added sorrow to pain. I’m exhausted from groaning. I can’t sleep.”’ 4Tell him the LORD says, ‘What I’ve built up I’m about to tear down. What I’ve planted I’m about to uproot—the whole land. 5Are you anticipating great things for yourself? Don’t. I’m going to bring disaster on everybody, but I’ll give you your life as a reward of war wherever you go.’”

Jer 45:1-5

A Message About Egypt

46:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah About the Nations

2A Message to Egypt about Pharaoh Necho’s Army

That Was by the Euphrates River at Carchemish,

Which Nebuchadnezzar Defeated

in the Fourth Year of Jehoiakim Son of Josiah, King of Judah

3“Line up the shields and bucklers,

and advance for battle!

4Harness the horses, mount the steeds,

take your positions, put your helmets on!

Polish the spears;

put on the coats of mail!

5But what do I see?

Egypt’s army is panicking; they’re retreating.

Their soldiers are being defeated;

they’re fleeing without looking back.

They’re terrorized in every direction,”

the LORD says. Jer 46:1-5

6The fast can’t flee;

the strong can’t escape.

They’ve stumbled and fallen

in the north by the Euphrates.

7Who is this that’s flooding like the Nile,

like rivers out of their banks?

8Egypt floods like the Nile,

like rivers whose water surges.

It has said, “I’ll flood the land;

I’ll destroy city and residents.”

9Advance, horses; drive wildly, chariots,

so the infantry can march forward:

Nubia and Put, that wield the shield,

Lybians, that bend the bow. Jer 46:6-9

10That day belongs to the Lord GOD of hosts,

a time of revenge on his enemies.

The sword will devour till it’s satisfied

and drink its fill of their blood.

There’ll be a slaughter for the Lord GOD of hosts

in the north by the Euphrates.

11Go up to Gilead and buy salve,

virgin daughter in Egypt!

In vain do you use lots of medicines;

they won’t heal you up.

12The nations have heard about your humiliation;

the whole world has heard your distress cry.

One soldier stumbles over another,

and they both fall together. Jer 46:10-12

13The Message the LORD Spoke to Jeremiah

About Nebuchadnezzar Coming to Strike Egypt

14“Declare it in Egypt, announce it in Migdol,

tell it in Memphis and Tahpanhes;

‘Be prepared and stand ready

because the sword has taken everybody around you.’

15Why are your soldiers prostrate?

Because the LORD has beat them down.

16He made many stumble;

they have fallen overt one another.

Then they said, ‘Get up! Let’s go back

to our own people, to our native land,

away from the oppressor’s sword.’ Jer 46:13-16

17They cried out there,

‘Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is just a lot of noise;

he’s let the stated time pass by!’

18“As I live,” the King says,

whose name is Yahveh of Hosts,

“somebody is coming like Tabor among the mountains

or like Carmel by the sea.

19Get your baggage ready for exile,

daughter that lives in Egypt,

because Memphis will be desolate,

burned down, and uninhabited.

20Egypt is a pretty heifer,

but a horsefly is coming from the north!

21Egypt’s mercenaries are like grain-fed calves;

even they have retreated and fled together.

They didn’t stand their ground;

their catastrophe has descended on them;

it’s their time to be punished. Jer 46:17-21

22“Egypt is as silent as a snake slithering away,

because its enemies are moving in on it like an army,

like woodsmen with axes.

23They’ll cut down its forest;

it certainly won’t exist anymore,

even though it’s too numerous to count.

24Egypt has been humbled,

delivered to the powerful ones up north.” Jer 46:22-24

25The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says, “I’m going to punish Amon of Thebes, Egypt along with its gods and kings, Pharaoh and those who put their trust in him. 26I’m going to deliver them to Nebuchadnezzar and his officers, who want to kill them. Afterwards people will live in Egypt like before. Jer 46:25-26

27“But you, Jacob my servant,

don’t be afraid or intimidated!

I’ll rescue you from a long way off

and your descendants from where they’re captive.

Israel will come back and be secure,

with nobody to make him shudder.

28Jacob, don’t be afraid;

I’m with you.

I’ll make a complete end to the nations

where I’ve driven you,

but I won’t make a complete end of you;

I’ll discipline you appropriately—

(not leave you unpunished).” Jer 46:27-28

47:1A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah

About the Philistines Before Pharaoh Conquered Gaza

2The LORD says,

“A flood is swelling up from the north;

it will become a tsunami.

It’ll flood the land and everything in it,

the cities and those who live in them.

People will cry out;

everybody in the land will wail.

3Because of the noise of stallions,

rushing chariots, wheels,

fathers won’t look back for their children;

they’ll be too overwhelmed Jer 47:1-3

4by what’s coming

to destroy the Philistines,

to cut off from Tyre and Sidon

every ally that’s left.

The LORD will destroy the Philistines,

the remnant along the coast of Crete.

5Gaza will be bald;

Ashkelon will lie in ruins.

Remnant in the plain,

how long will you gash yourselves?

6Sword of the LORD,

how long before you’re still,

before you go back into your sheath?

7But how can it be still

when the LORD has ordered it to attack

against Ashkelon and the seacoast?” Jer 47:4-7

48:1About Moab

The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says,

“Misfortune awaits Nebo—laid waste;

Kiriathaim will be disgraced—taken;

the fortress will be humiliated—torn down.

2No more renown for Moab;

disaster’s in store for Heshbon

to cease being a nation!

Put Madmen to silence too;

chase it with a sword. Jer 48:1-2

3“An outcry from Horonaim,

‘Devastation and destruction!’

4Moab’s to be destroyed;

its little ones cry out in terror.

5At the ascent to Luhith,

Moab’s refugees go up crying;

at the descent to Horonaim

they’ve heard the anguished cry.

6Run, save yourselves

so you can be a juniper in the countryside. Jer 48:3-6

7Because you trusted in your wealth and skill,

you’ll be captured too.

Chemosh will go into exile

with his priests and officials.

8A destroyer will come on every city;

no city will escape.

The valley will perish;

the plateau will be destroyed like the LORD said.

9Give Moab wings so it can fly away;

its towns will be desolate without residents.

10A curse on the one that does the LORD’s work halfheartedly;

a curse on the one that restrains his sword from blood. Jer 48:7-10

11“Moab hasn’t been disturbed since it was founded;

its dregs haven’t been unsettled.

It hasn’t been poured from jug to jug—

or carried into exile.

So it still tastes clean;

its aroma has body.

12“But the times coming,” the LORD says, “when I’ll send it to the ones that upset jugs, and they’ll turn it upside down. They’ll empty its jugs and shatter its jars. 13Moab will be disillusioned with Chemosh like Israel lost confidence in Bethel.

14How can you claim to be great soldiers,

brave men in battle?

15Moab will be destroyed;

its towns will be under attack;

its elite young men will go down in slaughter,”

the King says, whose name is Yahveh of Hosts.

16“Moab’s disaster is on its way;

its destruction will be swift.

17Mourn for it, you that live near it,

you that know its name.

Say, ‘How the powerful scepter has broken

that splendid staff!’ Jer 48:11-17

18“Come down from your glory

and sit on parched dirt,

people in Dibon;

the one that destroyed Moab

is coming after you.

He’ll destroy your fortresses.

19Stand by the road and watch,

people in Aroer;

ask him that’s fleeing and her that’s escaping,

‘What’s happened?’

20‘Moab has been disgraced;

it’s shattered.

Wail and cry out;

declare by the Arnon,

‘Moab’s been destroyed.’ Jer 48:18-20

21“Judgment has also come on the plateau—on Holon and Jahzah, on Mephaath, 22Dibon, Nebo, and Beth-diblathaim, 23on Kiriathaim, Beth-gamul, and Beth-meon, 24on Kerioth, Bozrah, and the towns in Moab near and far. 25Moab’s horn has been cut off and his arm broken,” the LORD says.

26“Get him drunk because he’s gotten arrogant toward the LORD. So Moab will wallow in his own vomit, something to be ridiculed. 27Wasn’t Israel someone you ridiculed? Was he a thief caught stealing? Every time you spoke about him, you shook your head in scorn. Jer 48:21-27

28“Leave the towns and live in caves, people in Moab;

be like pigeons nesting in the cliffs along the gorge.

29We’ve heard about Moab’s great pride,

his haughtiness, arrogance, and self-exaltation.

30I know his insolence,” the LORD says,

“but it’s pointless;

his idle boasts are empty claims.

31So I’ll wail can cry out for Moab;

I’ll moan for the people of Kir-heres/hareseth.

32“More than for Jazer,

I’ll weep for you, vine of Sibmah!

Your branches once reached the sea,

the Sea of Jazer [Dead Sea].

The destroyer has destroyed

your summer fruits and grape harvest. Jer 48:28-32

33So happiness and joy have been taken away

from Moab’s fertile fields.

I’ve made wine quit flowing from the winepresses;

nobody will tread them with shouts of joy;

the shouts won’t be shouts of joy.

34“From Heshbon, Elealeh, and Jahaz, from Zoar, Horonaim, and Eglath-shelishiyah, they’ve raised their voice; because even the water in Nimrim will dry up. 35I’ll put an end to Moab that offers sacrifice on the high place and burns incense to its god. 36So my heart wails like a flute for Moab and the people in Kir-heres. They’ve lost the abundance it produced. 37Every head’s bald; every beard’s shaved off. Everybody has gashes on their hands and burlap around their waists. 38There’s mourning everywhere in Moab’s streets and on its housetops, because I’ve broken it like a pot nobody cares about. 39How shattered it is! How they wail! How Moab has turned its back in humiliation. So it’s something to laugh at, an object of terror to everyone around it.” Jer 48:33-39

40The LORD says,

“One will fly fast like an eagle

and spread its wings against Moab.

41Its towns will be taken,

its fortresses seized.

So the hearts of the strong men of Moab

will be like the heart of a woman in labor.

42Moab will be destroyed from being a people

because it’s become arrogant toward the LORD.

43Terror, pit, and snare are coming on you.

44The one that runs from the terror

will fall into a pit.

The one that climbs out of the pit

will step in a snare.

That’s what I’ll bring on Moab

when I punish it. Jer 48:40-44

45“Refugees will stand in the shadow of Heshbon

with no strength to flee any farther;

fire has erupted from Heshbon,

a flame from Sihon.

46Misfortune awaits you, Moab!

The people of Chemosh will perish;

your sons will be taken captive,

your daughters too.

47Yet later I’ll restore Moab’s fortunes.”

That’s the judgment on Moab. Jer 48:45-47

49:1About Ammon

The LORD says,

“Doesn’t Israel have any descendants?

Doesn’t he have an heir?

Why then has Malcam/Milcom taken possession of Gad,

and his people settled in its towns?

2The time’s coming

when I’ll raise the battle cry

against Rabbah of the Ammonites.

It’ll be a desolate mound;

its towns will be burned,

Then Israel will expel the ones that expelled him. Jer 49:1-2

3“Wail, Heshbon, because Ai is destroyed!

Cry out, young women of Rabbah;

put on burlap and lament;

run back and forth inside the walls.

Malcam/Milcom will go into exile

along with his priests and officials.

4Why do you brag about your fertile valleys?

Your valleys are flowing away, unfaithful daughter

that trusts in her treasures and says,

‘Who’s going to attack me?’

5I’m going to bring terror on you

from every direction.

Every one of you will be driven out headlong

with nobody to round up the refugees.

6Yet later I’ll restore Ammon’s fortunes.” Jer 49:3-6

7About Edom

The LORD of Hosts says,

“Is there no wisdom in Teman?

Has good advice disappeared from the prudent?

Has its wisdom declined?

8Turn around, run away,

live deep in the deserts, people in Dedan,

because I’ll bring disaster on Esau

when I punish him.

9If grape-gatherers come to you,

wouldn’t they leave some gleanings?

If thieves came at night,

wouldn’t they destroy only enough for themselves? Jer 49:7-9

10But I’ll strip bare Esau’s land

and expose its hiding places

so its people can’t hide.

Its inhabitants will be killed,

relatives and friends;

its land won’t be alive anymore.

11But leave its orphans behind; I’ll keep them alive;

its widows will need to depend on me.” Jer 49:10-11

12The LORD says,

“Is there no wisdom in Teman?

Has good advice disappeared from the prudent?

Has its wisdom declined?

8Turn around, run away,

live deep in the deserts, people in Dedan,

because I’ll bring disaster on Esau

when I punish him.

9If grape-gatherers come to you,

wouldn’t they leave some gleanings?

If thieves came at night,

wouldn’t they destroy only enough for themselves? Jer 49:7-9

10But I’ll strip bare Esau’s land

and expose its hiding places

so its people can’t hide.

Its inhabitants will be killed,

relatives and friends;

its land won’t be alive anymore.

11But leave its orphans behind; I’ll keep them alive;

its widows need to trust me.” Jer 49:10-11

12The LORD says,

“If the ones that didn’t deserve the cup have to drink it, will you be let off? You will drink it! 13I’ve sworn by myself that Bozrah will be something to abhor, a disgrace, a ruin, a curse. Its towns will lie in permanent ruins.”

14I’ve heard a message from the LORD;

a messenger is going among the nations and says,

“Gather together and attack it;

rise up for battle!”

15I’ll make you small among the nations;

people will despise you.

16The terror you inspired

has deceived you into an arrogant attitude,

you that live in the clefts of the rock,

that occupy the height of a hill.

Though you make your nest high like an eagle’s,

I’ll bring you down from there. Jer 49:12-16

17“Edom will be something to abhor. Everybody that goes past it will be horrified and hiss at its wounds. 18Like the overthrow of Sodom, Gomorrah, and its neighbors, nobody will live there. 19Like a lion from the thickets by the Jordan suddenly attacking a sheepfold, I’ll chase everybody away from it. I’ll appoint over it anyone I choose. Who can take me to court? What shepherd can oppose me. 20So listen to the LORD’s plan for Edom, his intentions for Teman. They’ll drag off the little ones in the flock and empty the pasture. 21The ground will shake at their downfall. The outcry will be heard all the way to the Red Sea. 22It’s enemy will soar high and swoop down like an eagle and spread his wings against Bozrah. The hearts of Edom’s mighty men will be like the heart of a woman in labor.” Jer 49:17-22

23About Damascus

“Hamath and Arpad are in panic;

they’ve heard bad news.

They’re disheartened;

their anxiety rages like a sea

that can’t be quieted.

24Damascus is helpless;

Its people have fled.

Panic, anguish, and pain have gripped it

like a woman in labor.

25How that famous city has been deserted,

the city of my joy!

26Its young men will fall in its streets;

its soldiers will go silent that day,”

the LORD of Hosts says.

27“I’ll set fire to the walls of Damascus

that will burn down Benhadad’s fortified towers.” Jer 49:23-27

28About Kedar and the Kingdoms of Hazor

That Nebuchadnezzar, King of Babylon Defeated

“Attack Kedar;

destroy the people from the east.

29They’ll take away their tents and flocks,

their ornate tent curtains, goods, and camels.

They’ll cry out,

‘There’s terror everywhere!’

30Run! Flee! Live in deep caves,

people in Hazor,” the LORD says. Jer 49:28-30a

“Nebuchadnezzar has devised a plan against you

and plotted a scheme:

31to attack a nation that’s at ease,

that lives securely,

that doesn’t have gates or bars,

that lives apart by itself.

32Their camels will be plunder;

their livestock will be spoil.

I’ll scatter to the winds

those who clip the hair on their temples

and bring catastrophe from every direction,”

the LORD says.

33“Hazor will be a haunt for jackals,

a permanent wasteland.

Nobody will live there.” Jer 49:30b-33

34A Message from the LORD to Jeremiah About Elam

at the Beginning of the Reign of Zedekiah, King of Judah

35“The LORD of Hosts says,

‘I’m going to break the bow of Elam,

the main weapon of their power.

36I’m going to bring on Elam the four winds

from the four ends of the sky.

I’ll scatter them to all those winds;

there won’t be any nation

the refugees from Elam can flee to.

37I’ll scatter Elam ahead the enemies

that want to kill them.

I’ll bring catastrophe on them,

my fierce anger.

I’ll send out the sword after them

till I’ve consumed them all.

38Then I’ll set my throne in Elam

and destroy its king and officials.

39Yet later I’ll restore Elam’s fortunes.’” Jer 49:34-39

50:1A Message the LORD Spoke About Babylon,

the Land of the Babylonians, Through the Prophet Jeremiah:

2“Announce it among the nations;

hoist a standard everyone can see:

‘Babylon has been captured,

Bel humbled,

Marduk shattered,

its images disgraced,

its idols smashed.’

3A nation has come down against it from the north. It will make the land something to abhor; nobody will live there. People and animals will wander off.

4“At that time, Israel and Judah will return home. They’ll go along weeping, looking for the LORD their God. 5They’ll ask how to get to Zion and turn in that direction to join the LORD in an everlasting covenant they won’t forget. Jer 50:1-5

6“My people have become lost sheep. Their shepherds had led them astray and abandoned them on the mountains. They’ve gone along from mountain to hill and lost track of their resting place. 7Everyone that came at them has devoured them. Their enemies have said, ‘We didn’t do anything wrong; they’d sinned against the LORD, where goodness lives, who was their ancestors’ hope.’

8“Wander away from Babylon and leave the land of the Babylonians. Be like male goats at the head of the flock. 9I’m going to bring against Babylon a horde of great nations from farther north. They’ll draw up their battle lines and capture it. Their arrows will fly from skilled soldiers that won’t come back empty-handed. 10Babylonia will become plunder. Those who plunder it will gather as much as they want,” the LORD says. Jer 50:6-10

11“Though you’re happy and jubilant now,

you that plundered my permanent possession,

though you run around like a heifer on grass

and neigh like a stallion,

12your mother will be ashamed;

she that bore you will be humiliated.

She’ll be the least of the nations,

a parched wilderness, a desert.

13Because of the LORD’s anger,

Babylon will be empty,

completely desolate.

Everybody that goes past it will be appalled

and gasp at its wounds.

14Draw up your battle lines on every side of Babylon,

you that bend the bow.

Shoot at it; don’t spare your arrows

because it’s sinned against the LORD. Jer 50:11-14

15Raise your battle cry at it everywhere!

It has given up; its pillars have fallen;

its walls have been torn down.

This is the LORD’s revenge:

carry out that revenge on it;

do to it what it’s done to others.

16Eliminate the sower from Babylon

and the one that swings the sickle at harvest time.

Each one will retreat from the sword

back to their own people;

they’ll flee to their own land. Jer 50:15-16

17“Israel is like a flock driven away and scattered by lions. The king of Assyria devoured it first. Then Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, broke its bones. 18So the LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says, ‘I’m going to punish Babylon like I punished Assyria. 19I’ll bring Israel back to his pasture so he can graze on Carmel and Bashan. He’ll eat as much as he wants in the hill country of Ephraim and Gilead. 20At that time, they’ll search for Israel’s iniquity and Judah’s sin, but they won’t find any. That’s because I’ll pardon the ones I’m leaving as a remnant.’ Jer 50:17-20

21“Go up against the land of Merathaim

and the people in Pekod.

Slay and destroy them,” the LORD says.

“Do everything I’ve commanded you.

22The noise of battle is in the land

and great destruction.

23How the sledgehammer of the whole world

has been cut off and broken!

How Babylon has become

something to abhor among the countries! Jer 50:21-23

24I set a snare for you and caught you, Babylon,

while you weren’t watching.

You’ve been found and captured

because you’ve engaged the LORD in conflict.”

25The LORD has opened his armory

and brought out his weapons of wrath.

This is his work against the Babylonians.

26Attack it from the farthest border;

open your arms, pile it in heaps,

destroy it.

Don’t leave anything.

27Kill its young bulls with the sword;

let them go down to slaughter!

Misfortune awaits them because their time has come,

the time for their punishment.

28There’s the sound of fugitives from Babylon;

it speaks of the LORD’s revenge for his Temple. Jer 50:24-28

29“Summon many nations against Babylon,

every one that bends the bow;

camp against it all the way around;

don’t let anyone escape.

Repay it according to its work;

do to it everything it has done,

because it’s been arrogant against the LORD,

the Holy One of Israel.

30So its young men will fall in its streets;

its fighting men will fall silent then.

31I’m against you, arrogant one;

it’s time for me to punish you.

32The arrogant one will stumble and fall

with nobody to help him up.

I’ll set fire to its towns

and consume his surroundings.” Jer 50:29-32

33The LORD of Hosts says,

“Israel is oppressed,

Judah as well.

All who have taken them captive

have held onto them fast

and won’t let go.

34Their redeemer is strong;

his name is Yahveh of Hosts.

He’ll certainly argue their case

and give rest to their land;

he’ll bring unrest to the people in Babylon.

35A sword against them,

their officials and wise men! Jer 50:33-35

36A sword against their fortunetellers

so they’ll become fools!

A sword against their fighting men

so they’ll be shattered!

37A sword against their horses and chariots,

against the foreigners in it

so they’ll become women!

A sword against its treasures

so they’ll be plundered!

38A drought to dry up its water

because it’s a land of idols,

and they’re crazy about their idols

39“So the desert animals will live there along with jackals and owls. Nobody will ever live in it again 40as when I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighbors. Jer 50:39-40

41“People are coming from the north;

a big empire with many kings

will rise up from the remote parts of the earth.

42They take hold of bow and javelin;

they’re cruel with no mercy.

They roar like the sea; they ride on horses,

arrayed against you like soldiers for battle, Babylon.

43The king of Babylon has heard the reports about them,

and his hands hang limp;

anguish has seized him,

agony like a woman in childbirth. Jer 50:41-43

44“Like a lion from the thickets by the Jordan suddenly attacking a sheepfold, I’ll chase everyone away from it in an instant. I’ll appoint over it anyone I choose. Who can take me to court? What shepherd can oppose me?”

45So listen to what the LORD has planned for Babylon and the Babylonians. They’ll drag off the little ones in the flock and empty the pasture. 46At the shout, “Babylon’s been captured!” the ground will shake. The nations will hear the shout. Jer 50:44-46

51:1The LORD says,

“I’m going to stir up the spirit of the destroyer

against Babylon and the people in Leb-kamai.

2I’ll send foreign winnowers to Babylon

to devastate its land.

On every side they’ll oppose it

at the time of its catastrophe.

3Let the defending archer not bend his bow

or stand in his coat of mail.

Don’t spare the young men;

devote the whole army to destruction.

4They’ll fall down dead in the land of the Babylonians,

pierced through in their streets.” Jer 51:1-4

5God, the LORD of Hosts,

has not abandoned Israel and Judah

even though their land is full of guilt

in front of the Holy One of Israel.

6Escape from Babylon;

save yourselves!

Don’t get destroyed in its punishment;

this is the LORD’s revenge;

he’s going to render retribution to it.

7Babylon has been a gold cup in the LORD’s hand,

intoxicating the whole region.

The nations have drunk its wine;

so they’re acting crazy. Jer 51:5-7

8All of a sudden Babylon has fallen!

Wail for it!

Bring salve to heal its pain.

9We tried to heal Babylon, but it didn’t heal;

so abandon it and get to your own country.

Its judgment has reached heaven;

it towers as high as the sky.

10The LORD has brought about our vindication;

let’s recount in Zion the work of the LORD our God! Jer 51:8-10

11Sharpen the arrows, fill the quills!

The LORD has stirred up the kings of the Medes

to destroy Babylon.

It’s the LORD’s revenge for his Temple.

12Raise up a standard against the walls of Babylon;

post a strong guard, station sentries, set men in ambush!

It’s the LORD’s revenge for his Temple.

13You that live by lots of water, abundant in treasures,

your end has come; your life cord’s been cut.

14The LORD of Hosts has sworn by himself:

“I’ll fill you with soldiers like locusts;

they’ll raise shouts of victory over you.” Jer 51:11-14

A Hymn of Praise to the LORD

15He’s the One that made the earth by his power,

that established the world by his wisdom,

that stretched out the sky with his intelligence.

16When he speaks, there’s thunder in the rain above;

he makes clouds rise up from the horizon,

makes lightning for the rain,

and brings wind out of his storehouses.

17Every mortal is stupid and ignorant;

goldsmiths are disgraced by their idols

because their molten images misrepresent;

they can’t even breathe.

18They’re worthless objects to ridicule;

when they’re punished, they perish.

19Jacob’s portion is not like theirs.

His God has made everything;

Israel is his inheritance;

his name is Yahveh of Hosts. Jer 51:15-19

Babylon’s Destruction

20“You’re my battle-ax and weapon;

I’ll shatter nations with you;

I’ll destroy kingdoms.

21I’ll break horse and rider in pieces,

22chariot and occupant,

man and woman, young and old.

23With you I’ll destroy shepherd and flock,

farmer and ox team,

governors and prefects. Jer 51:20-23

24“I’ll repay Babylon and the Babylonians

for the devastation they’ve brought on Zion

right in my presence,” the LORD says.

25“I’m against you, destroying mountain

that destroys the world.

I’ll reach out against you

and roll you down from the crags

and make you a burned-out ruble.

26They won’t reuse from you

a cornerstone or foundation stone.

You’ll be as permanent wasteland.” Jer 51:24-26

27Set up a standard in the land;

blow the bugle among the nations.

Consecrate the nations against it;

summon Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz.

Appoint a marshal against it;

bring on horses like bristling locusts.

28Prepare the nations against it,

the kings of the Medes,

their governors and officials,

and every land they control.

29So the ground shakes

because the LORD’s intention against Babylon stands:

to make it an uninhabited wasteland. Jer 51:27-29

30The mighty men of Babylon have stopped fighting;

they’re staying in the barracks.

They’ve used up their strength

and become like women.

Their houses are on fire;

the bars of its gates are broken.

31One courier runs to another,

one ambassador runs to another

to tell the king of Babylon

his city’s been captured from end to end.

32They’ve seized the fords;

they’ve burned the fortifications;

the army is in panic. Jer 51:30-32

33The LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, says,

“Babylon is like a threshing floor tamped firm;

in a little while threshing will begin on it. Jer 51:33

34“Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon,

has devoured me and crushed me.

He has set me down like an empty cup,

swallowed me like a monster,

filled his stomach with my delicacies,

and rinsed me out.”

35Zion will say,

“May the violence done to us

be done to Babylon.”

Jerusalem will say,

“May my blood be on the people in Babylon.”

36So the LORD says,

“I’ll argue your case

and take full revenge for you;

I’ll dry up its River

and dry up its oasis. Jer 51:34-36

37Babylon will be a pile of rubble, a den for jackals,

something to abhor and gasp at;

nobody will live there.

38They’ll roar together like young lions;

they’ll growl like lion cubs.

39When they get hungry,

I’ll serve them their banquet.

I’ll make them drunk till they pass out

and put them to sleep forever.

40I’ll bring them down like lambs to slaughter,

like rams and male goats for sacrifice. Jer 51:37-40

41“How Sheshak has been captured!

What the whole world praised has been seized!

How Babylon has become something to abhor among the nations!

42The River has flooded Babylon,

swamped it in crashing waves.

43Its towns have become something to abhor,

a parched land, a desert,

a land where nobody lives

and nobody visits.

44I’ll punish Bel in Babylon

and make him vomit what he’s swallowed.

The nations won’t stream to him anymore;

even Babylon’s walls have fallen down! Jer 51:41-44

45“Get out of there, my people!

Save yourselves from my fury!

46Don’t let your heart faint;

don’t be afraid at the report in the land

when a report comes one year,

another one comes a year later,

and violence is in the land

with ruler against ruler.

47So the time’s coming

when I’ll punish the idols in Babylon.

Its whole land will be disgraced;

its slain will fall inside it.

48Earth and sky and everything in them

will shout for joy over Babylon,

because its destroyers will come from the north,”

the LORD says. Jer 51:45-48

49Babylon will fall in payment for the slain in Israel

and the whole region.

50You that have escaped the sword,

leave! Don’t stay!

Remember the LORD from afar

and keep Jerusalem in your mind.

51We’re ashamed because we’ve heard reproof;

disgrace shows on our faces

because foreigners have entered

the holy places in the LORD’s Temple. Jer 51:49-51

52“So the time’s coming

when I’ll punish its idols,

and the mortally wounded will groan throughout its land.

53Even if Babylon ascends to the sky

and fortifies its lofty fortress,

destroyers will come to it from me,”

the LORD says. Jer 51:52-53

54There’s an outcry from Babylon,

great destruction in the land of the Babylonians!

55The LORD is going to destroy it

and quiet its loud noise.

The waves of enemies will roar,

and the noise from their uproar will increase.

56The destroyer is coming against Babylon;

he’ll capture its strong men.

The LORD is a God that exacts recompense;

he’ll fully repay.

57“I’ll make its officials and wise men drunk,

its governors, officers, and strong men too;

they’ll sleep forever,”

the King says, whose name is Yahveh of Hosts.

58“Babylon’s thick walls will be completely torn down,

its massive gates set on fire;

so the nations will have worked for nothing;

the builders will have worn themselves out

only to get their work burned.” Jer 51:54-58

59The Message Jeremiah Gave to Seraiah Son of Neriah,

Grandson of Mahseiah, When He Went with Zedekiah, King of Judah,

to Babylon in the Fourth Year of His Reign

(Seraiah Was Quartermaster.)

60Jeremiah wrote in one scroll the catastrophe to come on Babylon. 61He told Seraiah,

“As soon as you get to Babylon, read this message out loud: 62‘LORD, you’ve promised to cut this place off so nothing will live in it, people or animals, so it’ll be a permanent desolation.’ 63As soon as you finish reading this scroll, tie a stone to it and throw it into the Euphrates River. 64Say, ‘In the same way, Babylon will sink and not float back up because of the catastrophe I’m going to bring on it. The workers will have worn themselves out for nothing.’”

Jeremiah’s message ends here. Jer 51:59-64

The Fall of Jerusalem

52:1Zedekiah was 21 when he became king and ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah. 2He did all the evil Jehoiakim had done. 3Because of the LORD’s anger over that, he put Jerusalem and Judah out of his presence.

Zedekiah revolted against the king of Babylon. 4The tenth day, tenth month, ninth year of Zedekiah’s reign, Nebuchadnezzar came with his army, set up camp against Jerusalem, and built a siege wall around it. 5The city lay under siege till Zedekiah’s eleventh year. 6The ninth day, fourth month, the famine was so severe in the city that the people didn’t have any food left. 7Then they broke into the city, and the fighting men fled at night through the gate between the two walls by the king’s garden, even though the Babylonians were all around the city. They went toward the Arabah, 8but the Babylonian army overtook the king in the plains by Jericho. His whole army scattered from him. 9They captured him and took him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah in Hamath, and he passed sentence on him. 10He executed Zedekiah’s sons right in front of him and executed the officials of Judah. 11Then he put out Zedekiah’s eyes, bound him with bronze bonds, and took him to Babylon. He put him in prison till his death. Jer 52:1-11

The Temple Burned

12The tenth day, fifth month, nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuzaradan, captain of the king of Babylon’s bodyguard, came to Jerusalem. 13He burned the LORD’s Temple, the king’s palace, the houses in Jerusalem, and the important buildings. 14The Babylonian army tore down the walls around Jerusalem. 15Nebuzaradan took into exile some of the poorest people, people left in the city, those who defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the artisans. 16He left some destitute to dress grapevines and plow fields. Jer 52:12-16
