17The Babylonians broke in pieces the bronze pillars in front of the LORD’s Temple, the stands, and the bronze sea; and carried their bronze to Babylon. 18They took away the pots, shovels, snuffers, basins, pans—all the bronze articles for the Temple service. 19The captain of the guard also took away the bowls, firepans, basins, pots, lampstands, dishes for incense and liquid offering bowls, what was gold and fine silver. 20The 2 pillars, the sea, the 12 bronze bulls under the sea, and the stands King Solomon had made for the LORD’s Temple—the bronze in all those items was too much to weigh. 21Each pillar was 27ft tall and 18ft in circumference—4 fingers thick and hollow. 22The bronze capital on each pillar was 7½ft high, with bronze network and pomegranates all around it. 23There were 96 pomegranates on the sides—100 altogether.

Jer 52:17-23

24Nebuzaradan took

Seraiah the chief priest,

Zephaniah the assistant priest,

three of the Temple’s doorkeepers,

25one city official that oversaw the fighting men,

seven of the king’s council they found in the city,

the secretary to the commander of the army who mustered the people, and

60 men they found in the city.

26He took them to the king of Babylon at Riblah, 27and the king put them to death there in Hamath. So they led Judah away into exile.

28These are the people Nebuchadnezzar carried away:

in his seventh year, 3,023 Jews;

29in his eighteenth year, 832 from Jerusalem;

30in his twenty-third year Nebuzaradan took away, 745 Jews:

4,600 in all. Jer 52:24-30

Jehoiachin Released

31The twenty-fifth day, twelfth month, thirty-seventh year of Jehoiachin’s exile, Evil-merodach, king of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, was gracious to Jehoiachin and brought him out of prison. 32He was kind to him and set his throne above the thrones of the other kings that were with him in Babylon. 33So Jehoiachin changed his prison clothes and had his meals with the king regularly 34till his death. Jer 52:31-34

THE LAMENTATIONS OF JEREMIAH

Jerusalem Deserted

1:1How lonely the city sits that used to bustle with people!

She’s like a widow that was once great among the nations!

The princess among the provinces has become a slave!

2She cries bitterly at night; tears are on her cheeks.

Nobody among her lovers is there to comfort her.

Her friends have betrayed her

and become her enemies.

3Judah has gone into exile in suffering and hard servitude;

she’s spread out among the nations now;

with no resting place.

Her pursuers have caught up with her in the middle of her distress.

4The roads to Zion are in mourning

because nobody attends the appointed festivals.

Her gates are desolate, her priests groan,

her virgins suffer, and she suffers bitterly herself. Lam 1:1-4

5Her adversaries have become her masters; her enemies prosper.

The LORD has made her suffer for her many sins.

Her children have gone away captive to the foe.

6The majesty is gone from Zion;

her officials are like bucks that can’t find pasture;

they’ve fled away weak before their pursuers.

7In her time of suffering and homelessness,

Jerusalem remembers her treasured things from before;

when her people fell to her adversaries and nobody helped her,

the enemies gloated over her and mocked her downfall.

8Jerusalem sinned grievously, so she’s become filthy.

Everybody that honored her before despises her now,

because they’ve seen her nakedness;

she groans and turns away. Lam 1:5-8

9Her uncleanness was in her skirts;

she didn’t give any thought to her doom;

so she’s fallen terribly with no comforter.

10The foe has reached out for her treasured things;

she has watched the nations invade her sanctuary,

people you commanded not to enter your community.

11The people are groaning as they look for bread;

they’ve given their treasured things for food to stay alive;

“Look, LORD, I’m despised.

12Is it nothing to you that go by?

Look and see if there’s any pain like my pain

that was severely dealt out to me,

that the LORD inflicted in his fierce anger. Lam 1:9-12

13He sent fire from on high into my bones, and it descended on them.

He spread a net for my feet and turned me back;

he left me desolate and faint all day long.

14He has tied my sins together into a yoke around my neck;

he has made my strength fail,

and turned me over to those I can’t withstand.

15The Lord has rejected the strong men that are with me;

he has called an appointed time against me to crush my young men;

like a winepress he has trodden down the young virgin Judah.

16I weep for those things; my eyes run down with tears

because there’s no comforter near to restore my soul.

My children are desolate because the enemy has prevailed.” Lam 1:13-16

17Zion holds out her hands, but there’s no one to comfort her;

the LORD has commanded against Jacob

that his neighbors would be his enemies;

Jerusalem has become something filthy in their minds.

18“The LORD is good; I’ve rebelled against his command;

listen now, all you nations, and look at my pain;

my virgins and young men have gone into captivity.

19I called to my lovers, but they deceived me;

my priests and elders perished in the city

as they looked for food to stay alive.

20Look, LORD, because I’m in distress; my soul is in turmoil.

My heart’s upset because I’ve been rebellious.

The sword bereaves in the street; it’s like death in the house. Lam 1:17-20

21They’ve heard that I’m groaning with nobody to comfort me.

My enemies have heard about my trouble;

they’re glad you’ve done it.

Bring the time you’ve promised,

and let them be like me.

22Pay attention to their sinfulness,,

and deal with them like you’ve dealt with me for my sins.

I groan a lot, and my heart is faint.” Lam 1:21-22

Destruction for Sin

2:1How the Lord in his anger has covered Zion under a cloud!

He has thrown down Israel’s splendor from heaven to earth;

he hasn’t remembered his footstool in his wrath.

2Without mercy the Lord has swallowed up the residents in Jacob.

In his anger he has thrown down Judah’s fortresses

and leveled the kingdom and its officials to the ground in dishonor.

3In his fury he has cut down Israel’s power

and stopped restraining the enemy.

He has burned like a fire in Jacob

and consumed it everywhere.

4He has bent his bow like an enemy;

he has set his right hand like an adversary

and killed everybody we took pride in.

He has poured out his anger like fire in the tent of Zion. Lam 2:1-4

5The Lord has become like an enemy;

he has swallowed up Israel,

laid its palaces in ruins,

destroyed its fortresses,

and multiplied mourning and groaning in Judah.

6He’s violently treated his Tabernacle like a garden shed

and laid in ruins his appointed meeting place.

The LORD has stricken from memory

the appointed festivals and Sabbaths in Zion,

and deposed king and priest in his angry indignation.

7The Lord has rejected his altar, disowned his sanctuary,

and delivered to the enemy the walls of its palaces.

A clamor was raised in the LORD’s Temple

like that of an appointed festival day.

8The LORD decided to destroy the wall around Zion.

He stretched out a line

and didn’t restrain his destroying.

He made rampart and wall mourn;

they’ve broken down together. Lam 2:5-8

9Its gates have sunk into the ground;

he has ruined and broken its bars

and scattered its king and officials among the nations.

There’s no law anymore;

prophets don’t have visions from the LORD.

10The elders of Zion sit silent on the ground;

they’ve thrown dust on their heads

and wrapped themselves in burlap.

The virgins of Jerusalem have bowed their heads to the ground.

11My eyes are worn out from crying;

my spirit is in turmoil;

my heart is poured out on the ground

because my people have been destroyed;

the little ones and babies pass out in the street.

12They ask their mothers, “Where is the bread and wine?”

as they faint like wounded men in the city streets,

as their life dies out on their mother’s chest. Lam 2:9-12

13What can I say for you?

What can I compare you to, young woman in Jerusalem?

What can I liken you to, as I comfort you, young virgin in Zion?

Your ruin is as wide as the sea; who can restore you?

14Your prophets have deceived you with false visions;

they haven’t exposed your iniquity to restore you from sin;

they’ve seen false, misleading oracles for you.

15Everybody that goes by claps their hands at you;

they gasp and shake their heads at Jerusalem,

“Is this the city they used to say was ‘perfectly beautiful,

a delight to the whole world’?”

16Your enemies mock you;

they scoff and snarl,

and shout, “We’ve swallowed you up!

That’s what we’ve been waiting for;

at last it’s here to see.” Lam 2:13-16

17The LORD has accomplished his purpose

and carried out the threat he ordained long ago.

He has destroyed without pity

and enabled your enemies to celebrate over you

and increased the power of your adversaries.

18Their heart appealed to the Lord,

“Resident of Zion, let your tears run down like a river day and night;

don’t give yourself any relief or let your eyes rest.

19Get up, cry out loud at the beginning of the night watches;

pour your heart out like water to the Lord;

lift your hands up to him for the life of your little ones

who are faint from hunger at the end of every street.”

20See, LORD, look! Who else have you ever dealt with this way?

Should women eat their offspring, little babies born healthy?

Should prophet and priest be killed in your sanctuary? Lam 2:17-20

21Young and old lie on the ground in the streets;

my virgins and young men have fallen by the sword.

You’ve slain them in your anger,

slaughtered them without mercy.

22You invited terrors on every side of me as to an appointed festival.

Nobody escaped or survived your anger.

My enemy destroyed the ones I cared for and raised. Lam 2:21-22

Hope in the LORD’s Faithfulness

3:1I have seen suffering

under the rod God used in his anger.

2He has driven me out and made me walk in the dark;

3he has turned his hand against me repeatedly all day.

4He made my skin and body waste away,

and broke my bones. Lam 3:1-4

5He besieged me with bitterness and hardship.

6He made me live in dark places

like the dead from long ago.

7He walled me in so I couldn’t escape

and put heavy chains on me.

8Even when I call for help,

he shuts out my prayer. Lam 3:5-8

9He has blocked my road with hewn stones

and made my paths crooked.

10He’s like a bear lying in wait for me,

like a lion in unexpected places.

11He dragged me off the road, tore me to pieces;

and made me desolate.

12He bent his bow and made me a target for his arrow; Lam 3:9-12

13he shot deep into me the arrows from his quiver.

14I’m a laughingstock to my people,

mocked in musical ditties all day.

15He filled me with bitterness

and made me drink wormwood.

16He cracked my teeth with gravel

and made me grovel in the dust. Lam 3:13-16

17I’ve been set apart from peace

and forget what happiness is like.

18So I say, “My strength is gone,

and so is my hope in the LORD.”

19Remember my suffering and homelessness.

20I certainly remember

and am humbled within. Lam 3:17-20

21I recall this and have hope from it:

22The LORD’s love never stops coming;

his mercies don’t end.

23His faithfulness is great;

it’s renewed every morning.

24I say to myself, “The LORD is my portion;

so I have hope in him.” Lam 3:21-24

25The LORD is good to those who depend on him,

people that look for him.

26They do well to wait silently for his salvation.

27It’s good for people to bear the yoke when they’re young,

28to sit alone in silence, since God has laid it on them,

29to put their mouth in the dust—maybe there’s hope,

30to turn their cheek to their abuser,

to be filled with disgrace;

31because the LORD won’t reject forever. Lam 3:25-31

32If he causes grief, he’ll have mercy

according to his enduring love;

33because he doesn’t willingly hurt people or grieve them.

34-36God doesn’t approve

of crushing every prisoner in the land under his feet,

of depriving people of justice in the presence of the Most High,

of defrauding people in his lawsuit.

37Who is there that speaks and it happens

unless the Lord has commanded it?

38Don’t both good and bad come from the Most High? Lam 3:32-38

39Why should we complain in light of our sins?

40Let’s examine our ways and return to the LORD.

41Let’s lift up our heart and hands toward God in heaven;

42we’ve sinned and rebelled; you haven’t pardoned us.

43You’ve covered yourself with anger and chased us;

you’ve slain without pity.

44You’ve wrapped yourself in a cloud

so no prayer can get to you. Lam 3:39-44

45You’ve made us residue and refuse among the nations.

46Our enemies rail out against us.

47Panic and pitfall descend on us, devastation and destruction.

48My eyes run with streams of tears

because my people are being destroyed.

49My eyes will keep pouring out

50till the LORD looks down from heaven and sees.

51My eyes bring pain to my soul

because of all the residents in my city.

52For no reason my enemies hunted me down like a bird;

53they’ve silenced me in the pit, and put a stone over me;

54water closed over my head; I said, “I’m lost.”

55I called to you, LORD, from down in the pit. Lam 3:45-55

56You heard my plea

and didn’t hide from my prayer for relief, my call for help.

57You came and said, “Don’t be afraid!”

58Lord, you pled my case and redeemed my life.

59LORD, you’ve seen my oppression; judge my case.

60You’ve seen their revenge, their schemes against me.

61You’ve heard their taunts.

62My assailants’ whispers aim at me all day.

63Look at their sitting and rising;

I’m what they mock in their song.

64Pay them back, LORD, according to what they’ve done;

65harden their heart so your curse will fall on them.

66Chase them in anger and destroy them from under the sky! Lam 3:56-66

The LORD’s Anger Satisfied

4:1How the gold has tarnished; how pure gold has changed!

The holy stones lie scattered at the beginning of every street.

2The precious sons of Zion, worth their weight in gold,

are treated like clay pots that potters make!

3Even jackals nurse their young,

but my people have become cruel like wild ostriches.

4The infant’s tongue sticks to the roof of its mouth for thirst;

little ones beg for bread, but nobody gives them any.

5People that used to eat delicacies sit desolate in the streets;

the ones brought up in purple lie on ash heaps.

6The iniquity of my people is worse than the sin of Sodom,

which was overthrown without hands in one moment.

7Zion’s Nazirites were purer than snow, whiter than milk,

healthier looking than corals, like polished lapis lazuli. Lam 4:1-7

8Now they’re darker than soot, not recognizable in the streets;

their skin is shriveled on their bones, withered like wood.

9Those killed with the sword are happier than those slain by hunger;

they pine away, stricken for lack of crops in the field.

10Merciful women boiled their own children;

they became their food because my people were being destroyed.

11The LORD has accomplished his wrath,

poured out his hot anger,

and sparked a fire in Zion that has consumed its foundations.

12The kings and inhabitants of the region

didn’t believe enemies could get in the gates of Jerusalem. Lam 4:8-12

13Because of its prophets’ sins and its priests’ iniquities—

who shed the blood of good people in it—

14they wandered in the streets, blind and defiled with blood

so nobody would even touch their clothes.

15They shouted at them, “Get away! Unclean! Don’t touch!”

So they fled and wandered.

People in the nations said, “They can’t stay here anymore.”

16The LORD has scattered them;

he won’t continue to care especially about them;

they didn’t honor the priests or bless the elders. Lam 4:13-16

17Our eyes failed us; looking for help was useless;

we certainly watched for a nation that couldn’t save.

18People dogged our steps so we couldn’t walk in the streets;

our end came near, our days failed, we were through. Lam 4:17-18

19Our pursuers were faster than eagles in the sky;

they chased us on the mountains and ambushed us in the desert.

20Our very breath, the LORD’s anointed, was captured in their pits;

we’d said about him, “In his shadow we’ll live among the nations.”

21Celebrate and be happy, Edom that lives in Uz;

the cup will come around to you as well; you’ll be drunk and naked.

22The punishment for your sinfulness is finished, Zion;

he won’t exile you any longer.

But he’ll punish your iniquity, Edom;

he’ll expose your sins! Lam 4:19-22

Prayer for Restoration

5:1LORD, remember what’s happened to us;

look at our disgrace!

2Our inheritance has been turned over to foreigners,

and our houses belong to aliens.

3We’ve become orphans without fathers;

our mothers are like widows.

4We have to pay for drinking water and buy wood.

5Our drivers put yokes on our necks;

we’re worn out; we can’t get any rest. Lam 5:1-5

6We’ve submitted to Egypt and Assyria to get enough bread.

7Our fathers sinned, and they’re gone,

but we have to suffer for their sins.

8Slaves rule us; nobody can deliver us from them.

9We risk our lives just getting bread

because of the sword in the open country.

10Our skin is hot like an oven,

because of the burning heat of famine.

11They rape the women in Zion

and the virgins in the towns in Judah. Lam 5:6-11

12They hang up officials by their hands

and show no respect for old men.

13Young men work at the grinding mill

and stagger under loads of wood.

14Elders are gone from the city gate,

young men have quit their music.

15The joy in our hearts is gone;

our dancing has turned into mourning.

16The crown has fallen from our head;

misfortune awaits us because we’ve sinned!

17Our heart is faint because of it;

our eyes are weak.

18Jackals prowl in desolate Zion. Lam 5:12-18

19LORD, you rule forever;

your throne goes on for endless generations.

20Why don’t you keep us in mind forever?

Why abandon us so long?

21Restore us to yourself, LORD, so we can be restored;

renew our days as of old,

22unless you’ve completely rejected us

and are really angry with us. Lam 5:19-22

EZEKIEL

A Vision of Living Beings and

the Glory of the LORD

1:1The fifth day, fourth month, thirtieth year, I was by the Chebar River with the exiles. The sky opened up, and I saw a vision of God. (2The fifth month, fifth year of Jehoiachin’s exile, 3God’s message came to Ezekiel, and God’s hand came on him.) 4A strong north wind was blowing, and a large cloud with a bright glow around it flashed constantly with lightning. In the cloud was something like glowing metal 5and four figures like living beings with human forms. 6Each one had four faces and four wings. 7They had straight legs, and their feet resembled calf hooves that shined like polished bronze. 8There were hands under their wings, 9and the wings of all four touched each other. Their faces didn’t turn as they moved straight forward. 10Each one had the faces of a man, an eagle, a lion on the right, and a bull on the left. 11Their wings spread out above them, two wings touching the wings of the next living beings and two covering their bodies. 12They went straight forward wherever the spirit went, without turning as they went. 13Among the beings were what looked like burning coals, like torches moving back and forth. The fire burned bright, and lightning kept flashing out of it. 14The living beings darted back and forth like bolts of lightning. Ezek 1:1-14

15A wheel appeared on the ground beside each living being. 16The wheels looked like glowing chrysolite built with a wheel inside a wheel. 17When they moved in any of the four directions, they moved without turning. 18Their rims were tall with eyes all the way around. 19-20When the living beings left the ground or moved, the wheels moved with them. The spirit of the living beings was in the wheels. [21]

22A bright expanse glowed like crystal above them. 23Under it their wings stretched out toward one another, and two wings covered the sides of their bodies. 24Their wings sounded like rushing water, like the Almighty, like war, like an army camp. When they stood still, they lowered their wings, 25and a voice spoke from the expanse above them. Ezek 1:15-25

26High above the expanse was a throne the color of lapis lazuli; the One sitting on it resembled a man. 27From the waist up, he glowed like metal on fire; from the waist down, he resembled fire. The radiance around him was 28like a rainbow on a rainy day. This scene looked like the glory of the LORD. When I saw it, I fell on my face and heard a voice, Ezek 1:26-28

2:1“Son of man, stand up so I can talk to you!” 2When the Spirit stood me up, 3he said,

“I’m sending you to the Israelites, a rebellious people. They and their ancestors have been sinning against me to this day. 4Tell those impudent, stubborn children, ‘The Lord GOD says.’ 5Whether they listen or not, they’ll know a prophet’s been there. 6Don’t be afraid of them or intimidated by what they say, though you’re surrounded by briars and thorns and sitting on scorpions. 7Tell them what I’ve said whether they listen or not. Ezek 2:1-7

8“Don’t be like that rebellious house. Eat what I’m giving you.” 9A hand held out a scroll to me. 10When he unrolled it for me, I could see writing on both sides—lamentations, mourning, and misfortune. 3:1“Eat this scroll and go speak to Israel.” 2So I opened my mouth, and he fed it to me. 3It tasted sweet like honey. Ezek 2:8-3:3

[4] 5-6“I’m not sending you to people that speak a hard foreign language you can’t understand. I’m sending you to people that should listen; 7but they won’t listen to you, because they won’t listen to me. The whole house is stubborn. 8I’ve made your face and forehead as hard as theirs, 9like corundum, harder than flint. So don’t be afraid of them or be intimidated by them though they’re rebellious people. 10Listen closely and take everything to heart that I tell you. 11Go to your people in exile and tell them, ‘The Lord GOD says,’ whether they listen or not.”

12The Spirit picked me up, and I heard a loud rumbling sound behind me, “Bless the LORD in his place.” 13I was hearing the wings of the living beings that touched one another and had the wheels beside them. 14The Spirit took me away; I felt bitter and angry, and the LORD’s hand weighed heavy on me. 15I went to the exiles by the Chebar River at Tel-abib and sat there with them for a week, feeling overwhelmed. Ezek 3:4-15

A Watchman for Israel

16A week later a message came from the LORD:

17“Son of man, I’ve appointed you to be a watchman for Israel. Whenever you hear something from me, warn them. 18When I tell sinful people they’re going to die, and you don’t warn them so they can live, they’ll die in their sin, but I’ll hold you responsible for it. 19If you’ve warned them, and they don’t change, they’ll die in their sin, but you’ve delivered yourself. 20On the other hand, when good people start sinning and I block them, they’ll die. Since you didn’t warn them, they’ll die in their sin. I won’t consider the good they’d done, but I’ll hold you responsible for their death. 21But if you’ve warned them and they quit sinning, they’ll live because they listened, and you’ll deliver yourself.”

Ezek 3:16-21

22The LORD put hand on me there and said, “Get up and go out to the plain, and I’ll talk to you.” 23The glory of the LORD was there, glory like I’d seen by the Chebar River; I fell on my face. 24The Spirit came into me and stood me up, and said,

“Go shut yourself up in your house. 25They’ll tie you up with ropes so you can’t go out among them. 26I’ll make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so you can’t talk. You won’t be able to rebuke them because they’re a rebellious house. 27But when I speak to you and you tell them, ‘The Lord GOD says,’ the ones that listen will listen; the ones that won’t, won’t. They’re a rebellious house. Ezek 3:22-27

Siege of Jerusalem Symbolized

4:1“Now, son of man, take a tablet and etch Jerusalem on it. 2Lay a siege against it with a siege wall and ramp, pitch camps, and position battering rams all around it. 3Then set up an iron plate as a wall between you and the city. Face it and press the siege against it. It’s an omen for Israel.

4“Lie down on your left side, and I’ll lay Israel’s punishment on you. You’ll bear their punishment for the number of days you lie on it. 5Lie like that one day for each of the 390 years they’ve sinned. 6When you’ve finished, lie down on your right side, and bear Judah’s sin. I’ve assigned you 40 days, one for each year. 7Then you’ll face the siege of Jerusalem with your arm bared, and prophesy against it. 8I’ve tied you up with ropes so you can’t turn from one side to the other till you’ve finished the days of your siege. Ezek 4:1-8

9“Take wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and spelt; put them in one container and bake bread. Eat it for the 390 days you’re lying on your side. 10Once a day eat 8 oz 20 shekels of food 11and drink a quart ⅙ hin of water. 12Eat it like a barley cake after you’ve baked it in front of them over human feces. 13That’s how the Israelites will eat their bread unclean among the nations where I’ll banish them.”

14But I said, “Lord GOD, since I was a kid, I’ve never defiled myself by eating ceremonially unclean meat, anything that died, anything an animal had torn in pieces.”

15He said, “I’ll give you cow manure instead of human feces to bake your bread. 16I’m going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem. They’ll ration bread by weight with fear and water by measure in alarm. 17Bread and water will be scarce; people will look at one another in dismay and waste away in their sin.”

Ezek 4:9-17

5:1“Son of man, take a sharp sword and shave off your hair and beard. Divide up the hair on a scales. 2Burn a third of it in the center of the city when the siege is over. Strike a third of it with a sword all around the city. Scatter another third of it in the wind, because I’m going to chase my people with a drawn sword. 3Attach a few to the hem of your robe. 4Throw a few in the fire. They’ll spread from the fire to the whole House of Israel. 5I’ve set Jerusalem in the center of the nations. 6It rebelled against my ordinances and statutes more than those other nations did.” Ezek 5:1-6

7So the Lord GOD says, “I’m against you; there’s more turmoil in you than in the nations around you. You haven’t followed my statutes or observed my ordinances or even [LXX] the ordinances of surrounding nations. 8I’ll carry out judgments on you for the nations to see. 9Because of your detestable deeds, I’ll do to you what I’ve never done before or will ever do again. 10Fathers will eat their own sons and sons will eat their fathers. My condemnations will scatter your remnant in every direction. 11As I live, I’ll withdraw from you because you’ve defiled my sanctuary with your detestable idols and carved images. I won’t pity or spare. 12A third of you will die by disease and starvation, a third will fall by the sword, a third I’ll scatter in every direction from the drawn sword. Ezek 5:7-12

13“That’s how I’ll vent my fury on you. You’ll know I’ve said it. 14I’ll make a wasteland out of you among the nations, something everyone that passes by will consider a disgrace, 15a taunt, a warning, something they’ll abhor when I carry out condemnations on you in anger and rebuke. 16When I send you the deadly arrows of famine meant for your foes, I’ll intensify it to break your staff of bread. 17Wild animals will bereave you of your children. Disease, sword, and bloodshed will surge through you. I’ve said so.” Ezek 5:13-17

A Prophecy Against the Mountains of Israel

6:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, face Israel’s mountains and prophesy, 3‘Listen to the Lord GOD’s message to the mountains and hills, ravines and valleys: “I’m going to bring a sword against you and destroy your high places. 4Your altars will be demolished and your incense altars smashed. You’ll fall slain in front of your idols, 5and I’ll scatter your bones around your altars. 6Everywhere you live, towns will be waste, high places desolate, idols broken, incense altars cut down, and the religious objects you’ve made, destroyed. 7You’ll know I’m the LORD.

8“But I’ll leave a few of you. Some will escape the sword in the nations where you scatter. 9You’ll think back to me where they take you captive—how you’ve hurt me with your adulterous hearts and with eyes that carried on prostitution with idols. You’ll abhor yourselves for those detestable deeds. 10You’ll know I’m the LORD, that I meant it when I said I’d inflict you with this disaster.”’ Ezek 6:1-10

11“The Lord GOD says, ‘Clap your hands, stomp your feet, say, “This has happened because of Israel’s abominations. It will fall by sword, famine, and disease! 12The one that’s far off will die by the disease. The one that’s nearby will fall by the sword. The one that’s left and besieged will starve to death.” That’s how I’ll vent my fury on you. 13Your slain will lie among your idols, around your altars, on every tall hill and mountaintop, under every green tree and leafy terebinth tree—where you offered a soothing aroma to your idols. 14The land will be more desolate than the desert toward Diblah. That’s how you’ll know I’m the LORD.’” Ezek 6:11-14

The End Has Come

7:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, the Lord GOD says to Israel, ‘The end is coming on the four corners of your land. 3I’ll judge you by your ways, direct my anger at you, and bring your detestable things against you. 4I won’t pity or spare when I bring on you the consequences of your deeds with the detestable things you’ve used.’ 5A disaster—a unique disaster—is coming! 6The end is here! It has awakened against you! 7You’re doomed, resident in the land—confusion instead of happy shouting on the mountains. [8] 9You’ll know that I the LORD am striking you.

10“The rod has budded, arrogance has blossomed, 11violence has grown into a rod of sinfulness. Nothing will remain of their multitude, their wealth, or anything outstanding that they have. 12The buyer shouldn’t celebrate, the seller shouldn’t mourn, because anger is aimed at their abundance. 13The seller won’t regain what he sold as long as they’re both alive, because the vision about their affluence won’t fade away. Because of his sin, neither will live. Ezek 7:1-13

14“They’ve blown the bugle and everything’s ready, but nobody is going to battle because I’m angry with their whole population. 15The sword’s outside; famine and disease are inside. The ones out in the country will die by the sword; famine and disease will kill the ones in the city. 16Even when survivors escape, they’ll be on the mountains like pigeons from the valley, mourning over his sinfulness. 17Hands will hang limp; knees will be like water. 18They’ll put on burlap and shudder. Their faces will blush; their heads will be bald. 19They’ll toss their silver into the streets and abhor their gold. Their silver and gold won’t be able to deliver them from the LORD’s anger. They won’t satisfy their hunger with it because that’s what made them stumble. 20The beautiful jewels they were so proud of, they used for making detestable idols; so I’ll turn their wealth into something detestable to them. 21I’ll give them to foreigners as plunder, to the sinful as spoil; and they’ll defile them. 22I’ll look the other way while invaders profane my precious land. Robbers will go in and defile it 23and make it desolate.

Ezek 7:14-23a

“The land’s filled with bloody crimes; the city’s full of violence. 24So I’ll bring the worst of the nations to take over their houses. I’ll put an end to their proud strength and profane their holy places. 25When anguish comes, they’ll look for peace, but there won’t be any, 26just disaster on top of disaster, rumor on top of rumor. They’ll find no vision from a prophet; the law will be lost from the priest and counsel from the elders. 27The king will mourn; the prince will put on rags; the people’s hands will tremble. I’ll deal with them by the way they’ve acted, judge them by their own judgments. They’ll know I’m the LORD.’”

Ezek 7:23b-27

Idolatry in the Temple

8:1The fifth day, sixth month, sixth year, I was sitting in my house with Judah’s elders sitting in front of me, and the hand of the Lord GOD came down on me. 2I saw what looked like a man. From the waist down, he looked like fire; from the waist up, he looked like bright glowing metal. 3He reached out with a hand and took hold of my hair. The Spirit lifted me up between earth and sky, and took me in a vision to Jerusalem, to the entrance of the north gate of the inner court, to the seat of the idol that provokes jealousy. 4The glory of Israel’s God was there—like what I’d seen in the plain.

5He said, “Son of man, look north.” North of the altar gate at the entrance, I saw this idol that made God jealous. 6“Do you see the detestable things Israel is doing here to keep me out of my own sanctuary? But you’ll see still more detestable things.” Ezek 8:1-6

7Then he took me to the entrance to the court and showed me a hole in the wall. 8“Dig through the wall.” I dug through it and found an entrance. 9“Go in and see what awful, detestable things they’re doing.” 10I went in and saw the shape of every crawling thing, every animal and detestable thing along with Israel’s idols carved all around the wall. 11Seventy elders of Israel were standing in front of them with Jaazaniah son of Shaphan. Each one was holding a censer, and the fragrance of the incense was rising in a cloud.

12“See what Israel’s elders are doing in the dark in the room of carved images? They’re saying, ‘The LORD’s not watching us; he’s abandoned the land.’ 13You’ll see still more detestable things they’re doing.” Ezek 8:7-13

14He took me to the entrance of the north gate of the Temple. Women were sitting there weeping for Tammuz. 15“See that? You’ll see still more detestable things.”

16He took me to the inner court. At the entrance to the Temple between the porch and altar, about 25 men with their backs to the Temple were facing east, prostrating themselves toward the sun.

17“See that? Isn’t it enough for Judah to do those detestable things, that they’ve filled the land with violence and provoked me time and again? They’re putting a twig up their nose. 18I’ll deal in anger. I won’t pity or spare. Though they call out loudly, I’ll ignore them.” Ezek 8:14-18

Idolaters Killed

9:1He shouted, “Executioners, come here with your weapons.” 2Six men, each holding a shattering weapon, came from the direction of the upper gate, which faces north. One of them was wearing linen with a scribe’s inkhorn on his hip. They went in and stood beside the bronze altar.

3The glory of God rose up from the cherub it rested on and went to the threshold of the temple. He called out to the man with the inkhorn, Ezek 9:1-3

4“Go all over the city and mark the foreheads of people who sigh and groan over the detestable things going on here.” 5-6He told the others, “Follow him and kill old men, young men, girls, little children, and women. Don’t pity or spare, but don’t touch anybody with the mark. Start at my sanctuary.” So they started with the elders that were in front of the Temple. 7He told them, “Defile the Temple and fill the courts with the slain. Go!” So they went out and struck down the people in the city. 8While they were striking them down and I was by myself, I fell on my face and shouted, “Lord GOD! Are you going to destroy the whole remnant of Israel by pouring out your anger on Jerusalem?”

9He told me, “The sinfulness of Israel and Judah is extreme. The land is filled with blood; the city is full of perversion. They’re saying, ‘The LORD has abandoned the land; he’s not watching us!’ 10I won’t pity or spare. I’ll bring the consequences of their actions on their own heads.”

11The man with the inkhorn reported, “I’ve done what you said.” Ezek 9:4-11

The LORD’s Glory Leaves the Temple

10:1Then in the expanse above the cherubs, I saw something like a sapphire stone shaped like a throne. 2He spoke to the man dressed in linen, “Go between the turning wheels under the cherubs and fill your hands with coals. Scatter them over the city.” I watched him go in.

3The cherubs were standing on the right side of the Temple when he went in, and a cloud filled the inner court. 4The glory of the LORD rose up from the cherubs to the threshold of the Temple. The cloud filled the Temple, and the bright glory of the LORD filled the court. 5The cherubs’ wings could be heard all the way to the outer court—like God Almighty when he speaks. Ezek 10:1-5

6When he told the man in linen to take fire from between the turning wheels, he went in and stood beside a wheel. 7A cherub reached out to the fire between the cherubs, took some coals, and put them in the man’s hand. He took them and went out. 8The cherubs had what looked like a man’s hand under their wings.

9Then I saw four wheels beside the cherubs, one beside each one. The wheels glowed like chrysolite. 10All four looked alike as if one wheel was inside another wheel. 11When they moved they went in any of four directions without turning from the direction they faced. 12Their whole bodies were covered with eyes—backs, hands, wings, and their wheels. 13I heard the wheels called “whirling wheels.” 14They had four faces each—a cherub, man, lion, and eagle.

Ezek 10:6-14

15The cherubs rose up—the living beings I’d seen by the Chebar River. 16When they moved, the wheels went beside them. When they lifted up their wings to rise from the ground, the wheels stayed beside them. 17When they stood still, the wheels stood still, because the spirit of the living beings was in them.

18The glory of the LORD went from the Temple threshold to stand above the cherubs. 19When they left, I saw them lift their wings and rise up from the ground with the wheels beside them. They stood at the entrance of the Temple’s east gate, and the glory of God hovered over them. 20They were the living beings I’d seen below God by the Chebar River; so I knew they were cherubs. [21-22] Ezek 10:15-22

Judgment on Israel’s Leaders

11:1The Spirit lifted me up and took me to the east gate of the Temple. There were 25 men at the entrance of the gate, including Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, leaders of the people. 2He told me,

“Those men devise sin and give bad advice in this city. 3They say, ‘Isn’t it time to build houses? This city is the pot and we’re the meat.’ 4So prophesy against them, son of man, prophesy!” Ezek 11:1-4

5The Spirit of the LORD fell on me:

“Say, ‘The LORD says, “I know your thoughts. 6You’ve multiplied the slain in this city and filled its streets with them. 7So the slain are the meat, and the city is the pot; but I’ll take you out of it. 8You’ve been afraid of the sword; so I’ll bring the sword on you. 9I’ll remove you from the city and deliver you to foreigners to carry out your condemnation. 10You’ll fall by the sword all the way to Israel’s border. 11This city won’t be a pot for you, and you won’t be the meat in it. 12You’ll know I’m the LORD because you haven’t followed my statutes or carried out my ordinances. You’ve followed the ordinances of the nations around you.”’”

13As I prophesied, Pelatiah died. I fell on my face and shouted, “Lord GOD! Are you going to put an end to the remnant of Israel completely?” Ezek 11:5-13

A New Heart and Spirit for Israel

14A message from the LORD came to me:

15“Son of man, your brothers, relatives, fellow exiles, and the whole House of Israel are the ones the people in Jerusalem have told, ‘Go far away from the LORD; we’ve received this land.’ 16So say, ‘The Lord GOD says, “Though I’ve removed them far away, yet I’ve been a sanctuary for them a little while where they’ve gone. 17I’ll gather them out of those countries back to Israel.”’ 18They’ll get rid of its abominations and detestable things. 19I’ll give them one heart and a new spirit. I’ll take out their stone heart and give them a real one 20so they can follow my statutes and keep my ordinances. They’ll be my people and I’ll be their God. 21Those who go after detestable things will have the consequences of their conduct come down on their own heads,”

the Lord GOD says. Ezek 11:14-21

22Then the cherubs lifted up their wings with the wheels beside them, and the glory of God hovered over them. 23His glory went up from the city and stood above the mountain east of it. 24The Spirit of God lifted me up and took me in a vision to the exiles in Babylonia. So the vision I’d seen left me. 25I told the exiles what the LORD had shown me. Ezek 11:22-25

Judah’s Exile Symbolized

12:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, you’re living with a rebellious people. They have eyes but don’t see, and ears but don’t hear. 3So get together baggage for exile and go into exile in the daytime so they can watch; go from one place to another. Maybe they’ll understand, though they’re a rebellious people. 4Bring your baggage out in the daytime. Then go out in the evening as if you’re going into exile. 5Make a hole in the wall so they can watch you go out through it. Ezek 12:1-5

6“Put the baggage on your shoulder and carry it out in the dark. Cover your face so you can’t see where you’re going. I’m using you as an object lesson for Israel.”

7So in the daytime I brought out my baggage like an exile. In the evening I made a hole in the wall with my hands. I went out in the dark and carried the baggage on my shoulder while they watched. Ezek 12:6-7

8In the morning a message from the LORD came to me:

9“Son of man, hasn’t the rebellious House of Israel asked you what you’re doing? 10Tell them the Lord GOD says this oracle is about the official in Jerusalem and the House of Israel that’s there. 11‘I’m an object lesson for you. As I’ve done, you’ll do. You’ll go into exile.’ 12The official that’s among you will put his baggage on his shoulder in the dark and go out. He’ll make a hole in the wall to take it out. He’ll cover his face so he can’t see where he’s going. 13I’ll throw my net over him and take him to Babylon in the land of the Babylonians, but he won’t see it even though he’s going to die there. 14I’ll scatter in every direction his helpers and troops, and chase them with a sword. 15They’ll know I’m the LORD when I scatter them among the countries. 16I’ll spare a few from sword, famine, and disease so they can confess their detestable acts to the nations where they go.” Ezek 12:8-16

17A message from the LORD came to me:

18“Son of man, eat your bread cringing; drink your water shuddering with anxiety. 19Then tell the people the Lord GOD says, “The people in Jerusalem will eat their bread with anxiety and drink their water with alarm, because everybody living there will strip them violently. 20The populated towns will be laid waste; the land will be desolate. They’ll know I’m the LORD.’” Ezek 12:17-20

21A message from the LORD came to me:

22“Son of man, what’s this proverb you people have about Israel, ‘The days are long and every vision fails’? 23Tell them the Lord GOD says, ‘I’ll make this proverb stop being used. The time’s coming soon for fulfilling every vision. 24From now on, there won’t be false vision or flattering fortunetelling in Israel. 25I’ll speak, and it’ll happen without delay. In your days, rebellious people, what I’ll say I’ll do.’”

26A message from the LORD came to me:

27“Son of man, Israel is saying, ‘The vision he sees is for years from now.’ 28Tell them, “None of what I’m saying will delay any longer. It will happen soon,’” the Lord GOD says. Ezek 12:21-28

False Prophets Condemned

13:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, prophesy against Israel’s prophets who prophesy their own ideas, 3‘The Lord GOD says, “Misfortune awaits foolish prophets that follow their own imagination and haven’t seen anything. 4Israel, your prophets have been like foxes among ruins. 5You haven’t gone up into the breaches or built the wall around the House of Israel to stand in the battle in the day of the LORD. 6They see falsehood and lying fortunetelling who say, ‘The LORD says,’ when he hasn’t sent them. They’re just hoping their message will be what happens. 7Didn’t you see a false vision and say a lying fortunetelling when you said, ‘the LORD says’? I’m not the one that spoke.”’” Ezek 13:1-7

8“So because you’ve lied, 9I’m against the prophets that see false visions and say lying fortunetelling. You won’t be in the council of my people, be recorded in the registry of Israel, or go to the land of Israel. You’ll know I’m the Lord GOD. 10That’s because you’ve misled my people by saying, ‘Peace!’ when there isn’t any. When somebody builds a wall, he daubs it with whitewash. 11Tell him it will fall. A downpour will come, hailstones will fall, violent wind will blow. 12When it falls, won’t they ask you where the plaster is you daubed on it?”

Ezek 13:8-12

13So the Lord GOD says, “In my anger I’ll make a violent wind break out with hailstones and a downpour to bring down that wall. 14What you daubed with whitewash I’ll bring down till its foundation shows. When it falls, it will bring you down with it. You’ll know I’m the LORD. 15I’ll spend my anger on the wall and the ones that whitewashed it. I’ll tell you, ‘The wall is gone and its plasterers too, 16along with the prophets in Jerusalem that see visions of peace for it when there isn’t any.’

17“Now, son of man, set your face against your people that are prophesying from their own imagination. Prophesy against them, 18‘Misfortune awaits women that sew magic bands on everybody’s wrists and make every size of veil for the people’s heads to hunt down lives! Will you hunt down my people, but preserve others for yourselves? 19For handfuls of barley and scraps of bread, you’ve profaned me to my people, killing some who shouldn’t die and protecting others that shouldn’t live. You’ve done it by lying to my people.’ Ezek 13:13-19

20“I’m against the magic bands you use to hunt lives like birds. I’ll tear them off your arms and let go the ones you hunt like birds. 21I’ll tear off your veils and deliver my people from you. They won’t be in your hands to be hunted. 22Since you disheartened good people with falsehood when I didn’t cause them grief, since you’ve encouraged the sinful not to turn from their sins and have kept them alive, 23your women won’t see false visions anymore or practice fortunetelling. I’ll deliver my people from you. That’s how you’ll know I’m the LORD.” Ezek 13:20-23

Israel’s Idolatrous Leaders Condemned

14:1Then some elders of Israel came and sat down in front of me. 2A message from the LORD came to me:

3“Son of man, these people have set up idols in their hearts, and put their sins in front of them to trip over. Should they consult me? 4So tell them, ‘The Lord GOD says, “If any Israelites or immigrants in Israel set up idols in their heart, put their sin in front of them to trip over, and then come to a prophet to inquire from me, I’ll answer them myself because of their many idols. 5I’ll do it to lay hold of the hearts in Israel that are alienated from me by their idols.”’ Ezek 14:1-5

6’So repent and turn away from your detestable idols. [7] 8I’ll oppose you and make an example out of you and a proverb. I’ll cut you off from my people. So you’ll know I’m the LORD. 9But if the prophet is tempted to speak a message, I’m the one that tempted him, and I’ll destroy him from my people. 10The inquirer and the prophet will get the same punishment for their iniquity. 11That’s so Israel won’t stray from me anymore and defile themselves with their sins.’” Ezek 14:6-11

Jerusalem Not Spared

12A message from the LORD came to me:

13“Son of man, if a country is unfaithful to me, and I destroy its food supply, send famine on it, and slay its people and animals, 14even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, they’d only deliver themselves. 15If I let wild animals overrun it and make it so dangerous nobody would go through it,16though these three men were in it, as I live, they couldn’t deliver their own sons or daughters. They’d only deliver themselves; the country would be a wasteland. 17If I bring a sword on that country to cut off people and animals, 18though these three men were in it, they couldn’t deliver their own sons or daughters. They’d only deliver themselves. 19If I send a disease on it and pour out my anger on it to slay people and animals, 20even though Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, they couldn’t deliver their own sons or daughters. They would only deliver themselves by their goodness.

Ezek 14:12-20

21“How much more, then, when I send my four severe judgments against Jerusalem: sword, famine, wild animals, and disease to slay people and animals in it! 22But some children will survive and come out to you to comfort you from the catastrophe I’ve brought on Jerusalem. 23They’ll comfort you when you see their deeds, and you’ll know I’ve done it for a reason.” Ezek 14:21-23

Jerusalem, a Useless Vine

15:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, how does the wood in a grapevine compare to the wood in a tree limb? 3Can you make anything out of grapevine wood, say, a peg to hang a bucket on? 4If it’s been put in the fire for fuel, is burned on both ends and charred in the middle, can you make anything out of it? 5If it’s intact and you can’t make it into anything, how much less when fire has burned and charred it.” 6So the Lord GOD says, “Like grapevine wood that I’ve put in the fire for fuel, I’ve given up the people in Jerusalem. 7Though they’ve come out of the fire, it’s charred them. You’ll know I’m the LORD when I set myself against them. 8I’ll make the country desolate because they’ve been unfaithful.” Ezek 15:1-8

Jerusalem, an Unfaithful Wife

16:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, confront Jerusalem about her detestable things. 3Say, ‘Your birth was from the Canaanites—an Amorite father and a Hittite mother. 4When you were born, your umbilical cord wasn’t cut off, you weren’t washed, or rubbed with salt, or even wrapped in cloth. 5Nobody took pity on you to do any of those things for you. You were tossed out in an open field because you were repulsive.

Ezek 16:1-5

6“When I went by and saw you squirming in your blood, I said to you, ‘Live!’ 7I made you as numerous as plants in a field. You grew up tall and filled out. Your breasts formed and your hair grew, but you were naked and bare. 8Then I went by and saw you were at the age to be sexually active; so I spread my cloak over you and covered your nakedness. I gave you my word and made a covenant with you so you’d be mine. 9I gave you a bath, washed off your blood, and anointed you with oil. 10I dressed you with embroidered cloth, put porpoise-skin sandals on you, wrapped you in fine linen, and covered you with silk. 11I adorned you with bracelets, a necklace, 12a ring in your nostril, earrings, and a beautiful crown. 13You wore gold and silver, fine linen, silk, and embroidered cloth. You ate fine flour, honey, and olive oil. So you were especially beautiful and advanced to royalty. 14You became famous in every country because of your beauty. It was perfect because of the splendor I put on you.” Ezek 16:6-14

15“But you trusted in your beauty and played the prostitute because you were famous. You poured out your prostitutions on every passer-by that was willing. 16You took some of your clothes and made high places of various colors and played the prostitute on them. That shouldn’t have happened. 17You took the beautiful gold and silver jewels I gave you and made male images so you could carry on prostitution with them. 18You took your embroidered cloth and covered them, and offered my oil and incense to them. 19The bread I gave you, the fine flour, olive oil, and honey I fed you, you offered in front of them for a soothing aroma. 20You took the sons and daughters you bore to me and sacrificed them to idols. Were your prostitutions a small thing? 21You slaughtered my children and offered them up to idols by making them pass through fire. 22Besides your abominations and prostitutions, you forgot your youth when you were naked, squirming in your blood. Ezek 16:15-22

23“Then after all your sinfulness (The Lord GOD says, ‘Misfortune awaits you!’), 24you built a shrine and made a high place in every square. 25You build a high place at the head of every street and made your beauty detestable. You spread your legs to every passer-by to multiply your prostitution. 26You carried on prostitution with the Egyptians, your lustful neighbors, to make me angry. 27I reached out against you, diminished your rations, and delivered you to those who hate you, the young women of the Philistines, who are embarrassed by your lewd behavior. 28You carried on prostitution with the Assyrians 29and multiplied it with the merchants of Babylon. You still weren’t satisfied.”’” Ezek 16:23-29

30“How lovesick your heart is,” the Lord GOD says, “while you do all this brazen prostitution. 31When you built your shrine at the beginning of every street and made your high place in every square, in disdaining money, you weren’t like a prostitute—32you adulteress wife that takes strangers instead of your husband! 33Men pay prostitutes but you pay your lovers! 34Nobody carries on prostitution like you do. You do the paying!” Ezek 16:30-34

35So, prostitute, listen to what the LORD says, 36“Because your lewdness was poured out and your nakedness uncovered through your prostitution with your lovers and your detestable idols, and because of your sons’ blood that you gave to idols, 37I’ll gather the lovers you had pleasure with, the ones both loved and hated. I’ll gather them against you from every direction and expose your nakedness to them. 38That’s how I’ll judge you—like women that commit adultery or shed blood. I’ll bring on you the blood of anger and jealousy. 39I’ll deliver you to your lovers. They’ll tear down your shrines, demolish your high places, strip off your clothes, steal your jewels, and leave you naked. 40They’ll stir up a mob against you, stone you, and cut you to pieces with swords. 41Many women will watch me burn your houses and carry out judgments on you. I’ll make you quit being a prostitute. You won’t be paying your lovers anymore. 42I’ll calm my fury against you. My jealousy will leave you, and I’ll be at peace. 43Since you’ve forgotten your youth and angered me with those things, I’ll bring your deeds down on your own head. So you won’t continue to commit that lewdness in addition to your other disgusting deeds. Ezek 16:35-43

44“Everybody that quotes sayings will quote this one about you: ‘Like mother, like daughter.’ 45You’re your mother’s daughter, who despised her husband and children. You’re your sisters’ sister, who despised their husbands and children. Your mother was a Hittite; your father was an Amorite. 46Your older sister is Samaria that lives north of you with her daughters. Your younger sister is Sodom that lives south of you with her daughters. 47You haven’t just done disgusting things like theirs; you’ve done worse. 48As I live, Sodom your sister and her daughters haven’t done like you and your daughters have done. 49This was the guilt of your sister Sodom: she and her daughters had arrogance, abundant food, and careless ease, but she didn’t help the poor and needy. 50They were arrogant and committed disgusting sins in my presence; so I removed them. 51Samaria didn’t commit half the sins you did. 52Deal with your disgrace because you’ve made judgment easier on your sisters. Your sins are worse than theirs. They’re better than you. Be ashamed and deal with your disgrace, because by comparison you make your sisters look good. Ezek 16:44-52

53“But, I’ll overturn the captivity of Sodom and her daughters, the captivity of Samaria and her daughters, along with your captivity, 54so you can deal with your humiliation, and feel ashamed of everything you’ve done when you become a consolation to them. 55Your sisters, Sodom and Samaria with their daughters, will come back to their former condition, and you with your daughters will come back to your former condition. 56-57Before your own sinfulness was revealed, you wouldn’t even say the name of your sister Sodom in your pride. 57So now you’ve become the disgrace of the Edomites and everybody around them, the disgrace of the Philistines, people around you that despise you. 58You’ve borne the penalty for your lewdness. 59I’ll do to you what you’ve done—you that have despised the oath by breaking the covenant. Ezek 16:53-59

60“Nevertheless, I’ll remember my covenant with you when you were young, and I’ll establish an everlasting covenant with you. 61Then you’ll remember your ways and be ashamed when you receive your sisters, Samaria and Sodom, your older and younger ones. I’ll give them to you as daughters even though they’re not part of our covenant. 62That’s how I’ll re-establish my covenant with you, and you’ll know I’m the LORD. 63In your humiliation, you won’t open your mouth when I forgive you for everything you’ve done,”

the Lord GOD says. Ezek 16:60-63

Two Eagles and a Vine

17:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, tell Israel this parable. 3‘A large eagle with big wings, long pinions, and full plumage of many colors flew to Lebanon and plucked off 4the top of a cedar tree. He took it to a land filled with merchants and planted it in a city full of tradesmen. 5He also took a seedling from the land and planted it in fertile soil, like a willow beside a stream. 6It took root and became a low, spreading vine with branches turned upward toward the eagle and roots growing down into the soil. It put out shoots and grew branches. Ezek 17:1-6

7‘But then another large eagle came along with big wings and full plumage. Now the vine bent its roots and branches toward him so he would water it. 8It was already planted in good soil beside plenty of water so it could grow branches, bear fruit, and become a splendid vine.’ 9Say, ‘The Lord GOD asks, “Will it thrive? I’ll pull it up by the roots, cut off its fruit, and let its leaves wither. I won’t need great strength or a big army to uproot it. 10If it’s transplanted, will it thrive? It will completely wither when the east wind blows on it in the soil where it had grown so well before.”’” Ezek 17:7-10

11A message from the LORD came to me:

12“Say to this rebellious nation, ‘Do you know what that parable means? The king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and took its king and officials to Babylon. 13He made a covenant with one royal family member and put him under oath. He took away the leaders in the land 14so the kingdom would stay subject to him and not try to mount an insurrection. That way it could continue. 15But the royal seed rebelled and sent ambassadors to Egypt to get horses and troops. Will that work? Will anybody avoid the consequences of doing something like that? Can he get away with breaking the covenant? 16As I live, he’ll die in Babylon—in the land of the king that put him on the throne, whose oath he disregarded, whose covenant he broke. 17Pharoah’s large, powerful army won’t help the royal seed in war, when the Babylonians build mounds and siege walls to take countless lives. 18The royal seed disregarded the oath by breaking the covenant; he pledged allegiance but rebelled. He won’t get away with it.’”

19So the Lord GOD says, “As I live, I’ll bring down on his head the consequences of the solemn oath he disregarded, and the covenant sworn in my name that he broke. 20I’ll cast my net over him, take him to Babylon, and condemn him there for his unfaithfulness to me. 21His elite troops will fall by the sword; survivors will scatter in every direction. You’ll know I the LORD have said it.” Ezek 17:11-21

22-23“I’ll pluck a young tender twig from the highest branches of a cedar tree and plant it on Israel’s high mountain. It will put out branches, produce seed, and become a stately cedar birds will nest in. 24All the trees will know I’m the LORD. I’ll cut down the tall tree, grow up the short one, dry up the green tree, and make the dry tree flourish. I’m the LORD; I’ll do what I say.” Ezek 17:22-24

The Soul That Sins Will Die

18:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“What do you mean by the proverb about Israel,

‘The parents ate sour grapes,

and the children’s mouths puckered’?

3As I live, you won’t be using that proverb in Israel anymore. 4Every soul belongs to me, the parent’s as well as the children’s. The soul that sins is the one that dies.

5“If a man practices goodness,

6doesn’t eat at the mountain shrines or

look up to the idols in Israel,

defile his neighbor’s wife or

approach a woman during her period;

7if he doesn’t oppress anybody, but

restores the debtor’s pledge;

if he doesn’t steal,

but feeds the hungry and clothes the naked,

8if he doesn’t lend money with interest,

if he keeps from sinning and

carries out true goodness between people,

9if he follows my statutes and ordinances to deal faithfully—

he’s good; he’ll live.” Ezek 18:1-9

10“If he has a violent son that

sheds blood and

does any of those sins to a brother 11(though the father didn’t

do any of them himself)—

eats at the mountain shrines and

defiles his neighbor’s wife,

12oppresses the poor and needy,

steals,

doesn’t return a pledge, but

looks up to idols and

commits disgusting acts,

13lends money with interest—

will he live? No! He’s committed detestable acts;

put him to death. His blood will be on himself. Ezek 18:10-13

14“If he has a son that’s seen his father’s sins and doesn’t do them—

15if he doesn’t eat at the mountain shrines or

look up to idols in Israel or

defile his neighbor’s wife,

16if he doesn’t oppress anybody or

keep a pledge or steal,

but gives bread to the hungry and clothes to the naked,

17refuses to hurt the poor,

doesn’t charge interest,

but carries out my ordinances and follows my statutes—

he won’t die for his father’s sins; he’ll live. Ezek 18:14-17

18Because the father practiced extortion, robbed his brother, and did what wasn’t good, he’ll die for his own sins.

19“Yet you say, ‘Why shouldn’t a child take the punishment for a parent’s sins?’ When children practice goodness and observe my statutes, they’ll live. 20The one that sins is the one that dies. An offspring won’t take the punishment for a parent’s sins or vice versa. A person’s goodness or sinfulness applies to the one that does it. Ezek 18:18-20

21“If sinful people quit sinning, keep my statutes, and practice goodness, they’ll live. 22The sins they’ve committed I won’t hold against them. Because they’re practicing goodness now, they’ll live. 23Do I get any satisfaction out of seeing a sinner die,” the Lord GOD says, “instead of turning from sin and living?

24“But when good people turn away from their goodness, and do what sinful people do, will they live? I won’t consider their good deeds before; they’ll die for the treachery they’re committing now. 25Yet you say the LORD’s way’s not right. Listen, Israel! Aren’t your ways the ones that aren’t right? 26When good people turn away from their goodness, they’ll die in their sin. 27When sinful people quit sinning and practice what’s right, they’ll save their life. 28They’ll live because they thought it over and turned away from their sin. 29But Israel says, ‘The LORD’s way isn’t right.’ Aren’t my ways right, Israel? Aren’t your ways the ones that aren’t? Ezek 18:21-29

30“So I’ll judge you, Israel, each person by their own behavior. Repent and quit sinning so your sins won’t make you stumble. 31Get rid of them. Make a new heart and spirit for yourselves! Why die, Israel? 32I don’t get any satisfaction out of seeing somebody die. So repent and live.” Ezek 18:30-32

A Funeral Song for Israel’s Princes

19:1“Sing this funeral song for Israel’s officials:

2‘What was your mother?

A lioness among lions!

She lay down among young lions;

she raised her cubs.

3When she brought up one of her cubs,

he became a young lion,

learned to catch prey,

and devoured people. Ezek 19:1-3

4Then nations heard about him.

They captured him in their pit

and took him with hooks to Egypt.

5‘As time went on, she saw

that her hopes for him were lost,

and took another of her cubs

and made him a young lion.

6He walked among the lions;

he became a young lion,

earned to catch prey,

and devoured people. Ezek 19:4-6

7He destroyed their fortresses

and laid waste their towns;

everybody in the land

was terrified at his roaring.

8Then nations attacked him

on every side from their provinces.

They threw their net over him

and captured him in their pit.

9With hooks they put him in a cage

and took him to the king of Babylon.

They took him in hunting nets

so people couldn’t hear him anymore

on the mountains in Israel. Ezek 19:7-9

10‘Your mother was like a vine in your vineyard,

planted near water.

It was fruitful with lots of branches

because it had plenty of water.

11Its strong stems became rulers’ scepters.

It was taller than the clouds,

so it could be seen with its mass of branches.

12But it was plucked up in fury

and dashed to the ground.

The east wind dried up its fruit

and tore off and withered its strong branches.

Fire burned it up. Ezek 19:10-12

13Now it stands in the wilderness,

in a dry, thirsty land.

14The fire that broke out in its branches

and burned up its fruit

didn’t leave any branch

strong enough to be a ruler’s scepter.’”

A Dirge Ezek 19:13-14

Israel’s Rebellion

20:1The tenth day, fifth month, seventh year, some of Israel’s elders came to inquire from the LORD and sat in front of me. 2A message from him came to me:

3“Son of man, tell Israel’s elders the Lord GOD says, ‘Are you coming to inquire from me? As I live, I won’t let you.’

4“Are you willing to judge them, son of man? Then remind them about their ancestors’ detestable deeds. 5Tell them that when I chose Israel, swore to Jacob’s descendants, and made myself known to them in Egypt, 6I swore I’d take them out of Egypt to a land I’d chosen, a land flowing with milk and honey, the most beautiful of all the lands. 7I told them to throw away the detestable things their eyes feasted on and not defile themselves with Egypt’s idols. I’m the LORD their God. 8But they wouldn’t discard them. Ezek 20:1-8a

“So I resolved to pour out my anger on them in Egypt. 9I did it to keep my name from being profaned in the nations that I revealed myself to by bringing Israel out of Egypt. 10So I took them into the desert, 11and gave them my statutes and ordinances that would give people life if they kept them. 12I gave them my Sabbaths as a sign between us so they’d know I’m the LORD who sanctifies them. 13But Israel rebelled. So I resolved to pour out my anger on them in the desert and wipe them out. [14] 15I swore to them there that I wouldn’t bring them to the land I’d given them. [16] 17Yet I didn’t wipe them out in the desert. Ezek 20:8b-17

18“I told their children in the desert, ‘Don’t follow the statutes of your fathers, keep their ordinances, or defile yourselves with their idols. 19I’m the LORD your God: follow my statutes and keep my ordinances, 20sanctify my Sabbaths as a sign between us so you can know that I’m the LORD their God.’ 21But the children wouldn’t do it. 22I withdrew my hand to keep my name from being profaned in the nations that saw me bring them out of Egypt. 23I swore to them in the desert that I’d scatter them among the nations 24for their rebellion. 25I let them keep statutes that weren’t good and ordinances that couldn’t give life. 26I pronounced them unclean for making their firstborn pass through fire so I could make them desolate. Ezek 20:18-26

Judgment and Restoration

27“So, son of man, tell Israel the Lord GOD says, ‘Your ancestors blasphemed me by acting deceitfully against me. 28When I did bring them to the land I swore to give them, they looked at every tall hill and leafy tree, and offered their sacrifices there and presented their provoking offerings. They made their soothing aroma and poured out their liquid offerings. 29Then I said to them, “What’s the ‘high place’ that you go to?” Its name is still Bamah. 30So say to Israel the Lord GOD says, ‘Will you defile yourselves like your ancestors did and carry on prostitution with their detestable things? 31When you offer your gifts—making your sons pass through fire—you’re still defiling yourselves with your idols. Will you inquire from me, House of Israel? As I live, I won’t let you.

32“What you imagine won’t happen—as when you say you’ll be like the nations and tribes in the lands and serve wood and stone.’ Ezek 20:27-32

33“As I live, I’ll rule you with a strong hand, outstretched arm, and anger poured out. 34From the lands where you’re scattered, 35I’ll take you to the wilderness of the nations and judge you directly 36like I judged your ancestors in the desert in Egypt. 37I’ll make you pass evaluation and bring you into the covenant. 38I’ll purge from you the rebels that sin against me. I’ll bring you out of the land where you’re living temporarily, but you won’t enter Israel. So you’ll know I’m the LORD.

39“Go on and serve your idols, Israel; later you’ll listen. You won’t profane my holy name anymore with your idols and offerings. Ezek 20:33-39

40-41“On my holy hill, Israel’s high mountain, the whole House of Israel will serve me. Like a soothing aroma, I’ll accept you there and seek your contributions and choice gifts with your holy things. I’ll prove myself holy among you for the nations to see 42when I bring you to the land I swore to give your ancestors. 43You’ll think back there to the ways you defiled yourselves, and you’ll despise yourselves for the sins you’ve committed. 44You’ll know I’m the LORD when I’ve dealt with you to maintain my reputation more than to punish your sins.’” Ezek 20:40-44

Judgment Against the Negev

45A message from the LORD came to me:

46“Son of man, face Teman. Prophesy against the south, against the forest in the Negev, 47‘Listen to what the Lord GOD says, “I’m about to light a fire in you that will burn up every tree in you, green or dry. It won’t go out till it has burned the whole surface from south to north. 48Everybody will see that I lit it.”’”

49Then I said, “Lord GOD, they’re saying I’m just telling stories.”

Ezek 20:45-49

Babylon, God’s Sword of Judgment

21:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, face Jerusalem. Speak against its sanctuaries and prophesy against Israel, 3‘The LORD says, “I’ll draw my sword and slay the good and the bad in you, 4everybody from south to north. 5Everyone will know I’ve drawn it, and it won’t go back into its sheath.”’

6“Son of man, moan with breaking heart and bitter grief. 7When they ask why you’re moaning, say, ‘Over the news that’s coming. Hearts will melt, hands will go limp, spirits will faint, knees will be as weak as water.” Ezek 21:1-7

8Again, a message from the LORD came to me:

9“Son of man, prophesy,

‘A sword, a sword,

sharpened and polished!

10sharpened for slaughter,

polished to flash like lightning!

Or should we be happy? Son, you’ve despised the rod and everything wood. 11A sword is sharpened and polished for the executioner. 12Cry out and wail, son of man. It’s against my people and their officials. They’ve been delivered to the sword, so strike your thigh. 13It won’t be for disciplining. What good would that do if you despise the rod? Ezek 21:8-13

14‘So prophesy, son of man. Clap your hands; bring the sword down twice, three times on the slain, for the great slaughter on everyone around. 15Their hearts will melt and many will fall at their gates. I’ve provided the glittering sword, made for striking like lightning, wrapped and ready for slaughter, 16to cut sharp wherever its aimed. 17I’ll clap my hands and vent my fury. I’ve said so.’”

Ezek 21:14-17

18A message from the LORD came to me:

19“Son of man, mark two roads for the king of Babylon to take that fork off from the same land. Put up a sign at the beginning of the road to each city. 20Mark a way for the sword to come to Rabbah in Ammon and Jerusalem in Judah. 21The king of Babylon is standing at the fork in the road ready to use fortunetelling, to shake arrows, to consult household idols, to inspect the liver. 22The lot for Jerusalem comes into his right hand, to set up battering rams against its gates, to lift up the battle cry for slaughter, to build mounds and a siege wall. 23It will seem to them like false fortunetelling; they’ve sworn solemn oaths. But he’s remembering their sin; so he’ll seize them.

24“So the Lord GOD says, ‘Because you’ve made your sin memorable and your transgressions evident in everything you do, they’ll take you. 25You slain, sinful, prince of Israel, whose time has come for final punishment, 26take off your turban, remove your crown. Things are going to be different. Raise up what’s low, abase what’s high. 27I’ll make it a ruin. There won’t be any trace of it till the one comes that I’ve given the right to have it.’ Ezek 21:18-27

28“So prophesy, son of man, ‘The Lord GOD says about the Ammonites and their disgrace: ‘a sword drawn, polished to slaughter like lightning—29while they see false visions for you, while they tell you lying fortunes—to place that sword on the necks of the sinful slain at their time of final punishment. 30Put it back in its sheath. I’ll condemn you where you originated. 31I’ll pour out my indignation on you, blow fire on you out of my anger, and turn you over to brutal men that know how to destroy. 32You’ll be fuel for the fire; your blood will be spilled in your own land. You’ll be forgotten. I’ve said so.’” Ezek 21:28-32

Israel’s Sins

22:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, are you willing to judge the bloody city? Then tell it about its abominations. 3Say, ‘The Lord GOD says,

“A city that sheds blood in it,

a city whose time will come,

a city that makes idols to defile itself!

4-5You’ve become guilty by shedding blood

and defiled by making idols.

You’ve brought your appointed time near,

you infamous one full of turmoil;

I’ve made you a disgrace to nations near and far,

something to ridicule. Ezek 22:1-5

6“Every ruler in Israel is intent on shedding blood, each according to his power. 7They treat parents with contempt, oppress foreigners, wrong the fatherless and widows. 8They despise my holy things and profane my Sabbaths. 9Slanderous men accuse falsely to get the death penalty, eat at the mountain shrine, commit lewd acts. 10They uncover their father’s nakedness and rape women that are in their period. 11One commit detestable acts with his neighbor’s wife, another defiles his daughter-in-law, another rapes his sister. 12You do murder for hire, charge interest, oppress other people for gain, and forget me.”

13“I slap my hand at your bloodshed and crooked gain. 14Will you have the courage and strength to deal with me when I do what I’ve said? 15I’ll scatter you across the nations and burn off your uncleanness. 16You’ll profane yourself in the sight of the nations. You’ll know I’m the LORD.”’” Ezek 22:6-16

17A message from the LORD came to me:

18“Son of man, Israel is slag to me. Its people are bronze and tin, iron, lead, and silver from a furnace. 19So the Lord GOD says, ‘Because you’re slag, I’m going to gather you to Jerusalem. 20Like they gather silver, bronze, iron, lead, and tin and melt it down in a furnace, I’ll melt you down there 21with fire from my anger. [22]’” Ezek 22:17-22

23A message from the LORD came to me:

24“Son of man, say, ‘You’re a polluted land that won’t get any rain to wash it off all during the time of my indignation.’ 25There‘s a conspiracy among your prophets. Like a roaring lion mauling its prey, you devour lives. You steal treasure and precious things and make many widows.

26Israel’s priests violate my Law and profane my holy things. They don’t distinguish holy from profane or teach the difference between clean and unclean. They don’t observe my Sabbaths, and they dishonor me among themselves. 27Israel’s leaders are like wolves tearing apart prey. They shed blood and destroy lives to get gain. 28Its prophets smear whitewash for them, see false visions, tell lying fortunes for them, and say, ‘The Lord GOD says,’ when I haven’t said. 29They oppress and rob the people, wrong the poor and needy, and mistreat temporary residents with injustice.

30“I looked for someone to build the wall around it and stand in the gap for Israel so I wouldn’t destroy it, but I didn’t find anybody. 31So I’ve poured out my indignation on them. I’ve burned them up with the fire from my anger and brought the consequences of their ways on their heads.” Ezek 22:23-31

The Adultery of Oholah and Oholibah

23:1A message from the LORD came to me:

2“Son of man, there were two women, daughters of the same mother. 3They carried on prostitution in Egypt when they were young. Their breasts were pressed there and their virgin bosom was handled. 4Their names were Oholah the older and Oholibah her sister. They became mine and had children. Samaria is Oholah; Jerusalem is Oholibah.

5“Oholah played the prostitute while she belonged to me, and doted on her lovers, the Assyrians, her neighbors, 6who dressed in purple, governors and officials, all of them desirable young men, horsemen riding on their horses. 7She bestowed her prostitution on them, choice men of Assyria. She defiled herself with their idols. 8She didn’t abandon her prostitution from the time she was in Egypt. When she was young, men had lain with her, and handled her virgin bosom and poured out their lust on her. 9So I gave her to her lovers, the Assyrians. 10They uncovered her nakedness; they took her children but killed her with a sword. So she became a byword among women, and they carried out judgments on her.

Ezek 23:1-10

11“Her sister Oholibah saw that and became even more corrupt in doting on her lovers. Her prostitution was worse than her sister’s. 12She doted on the Assyrians, nearby governors and officials, magnificently attired, horsemen riding horses, all desirable young men. 13I saw that she’d defiled herself; they both had followed the same path. 14So she increased her prostitution. She saw men painted on the wall, images of Babylonians painted with vermilion, 15wearing waistbands, with flowing turbans on their heads, all looking like officers, like Babylonians in Babylonia, the land where they were born. 16When she saw them, she doted on them and sent messengers to them in Babylonia. 17The Babylonians came to her bed of lust and defiled her with their prostitution. When they’d defiled her, she became disgusted with them. 18She uncovered her prostitution and her nakedness.

Then I became disgusted with her like I had with her sister. 19She still increased her prostitution and remembered her youth when she carried on prostitution in Egypt. 20She doted on her paramours, whose members are like donkeys’ and whose issue is like horses’. 21So she longed for the lewdness of her youth when the Egyptians handled her young breasts. Ezek 23:11-21

God’s Judgment on Oholibah

22“So, Oholibah, the Lord GOD says, ‘I’ll arouse your lovers against you—the ones you’re alienated from—and bring them against you from every direction: 23the Babylonians and all the Chaldeans; Pekod, Shoa, Koa, and the Assyrians, desirable young men, governors and officials all, officers and soldiers every one, riding horses. 24They’ll attack you with weapons, chariots, and wagons, and an army of soldiers arrayed against you on every side with buckler, shield, and helmet.
