the new wine has dried up,

the fresh oil has failed.

11Despair, farmers; wail, vinedressers,

for the wheat and barley;

the harvest is ruined.

12The grapevines have shriveled up, the fig trees have withered;

the pomegranate, palm, and apple trees as well.

The fruit trees in the orchard have dried up,

the joy among the people too. Joel 1:8-12

A Call to Repentance

13Put on burlap and chant a dirge, priests;

wail, ministers at the altar!

Come, spend the night in burlap, ministers of God,

because the grain offerings and liquid offerings

have stopped in his Temple.

14Consecrate a fast, declare a solemn assembly;

gather the elders and the people to the LORD’s Temple,

and cry out to him.

15Dread the day!

The day of the LORD is upon us,

a day of destruction that’s coming from the Almighty.

16Hasn’t food disappeared in front of us,

and happiness left the Temple?

17Seeds shrivel under the clods;

barns stand empty;

granaries are abandoned

because the crops have failed. Joel 1:13-17

18The cattle are bawling!

Herds are wandering aimlessly

because there’s no pasture;

flocks of sheep are bleating in misery.

19I’m calling out to you, LORD,

because fire has burned off the open range;

flames have burned up the trees in the fields.

20Even the wild animals pant for you

because the streams have dried up

and fire has scorched the pastures. Joel 1:18-20

The Day of the LORD

2:1Blow a bugle in Zion;

sound an alarm on my holy mountain!

Let the people in the land tremble

because the day of the LORD is coming.

It’s near,

2a dark and gloomy day,

a cloudy day with deep blackness.

A numerous, powerful army is spreading out

like shadows in the mountains.

There’s never been anything like them before,

and there won’t be for ages to come.

3Fire consumes ahead of them;

flames burn behind them.

The land is like the Orchard of Eden in front of them,

but desolation lies behind them;

nothing escapes.

4They look like horses;

they run like steeds.

5With rumbling like chariots,

they leap along on the hilltops—

like a crackling flame consuming stubble,

like a powerful army in battle formation. Joel 2:1-5

6Defenders are in anguish in front of them

with faces turned pale.

7They run like warriors

and scale walls like soldiers;

they march in line

without breaking rank.

8They don’t bump into one another;

each one marches straight ahead.

When they break through the defenses,

they just keep going.

9They rush at the city and

run along its walls;

they climb into houses

through windows like thieves.

10 The ground quakes in front of them,

the sky shakes,

the sun and moon go out,

the stars grow dim. Joel 2:6-10

11The LORD raises his voice in front of his army;

his camp is large

because he’s strong that carries out his word.

The day of the LORD is terrifying;

who can survive it?

A Call to Repentance

12“Yet even now,” the LORD says,

“come back to me with all your heart,

with fasting, tears, and mourning.

13Tear you hearts, not your clothes.”

Come back to him;

he’s gracious and merciful,

slow to get angry, full of enduring love,

and relents from carrying out destruction.

14Who knows if he’ll relent

and leave behind a blessing for you,

the possibility of offering again

a grain offering and a liquid offering

for the LORD your God. Joel 2:11-14

15Blow a bugle in Zion,

consecrate a fast,

declare a solemn assembly,

16bring the people together,

sanctify the community,

assemble the elders,

gather the children and nursing infants.

Have the groom come out of his room

and the bride leave her quarters.

17Let the priests, the LORD’s ministers,

weep between the porch and altar.

Let them say, “Spare your people, LORD.

Don’t make your permanent possession a disgrace,

a byword the world over.

Why should they say,

‘Where’s their God?’” Joel 2:15-17

The Lord Promises Restoration

18Then the LORD will become zealous for his land

and take pity on his people.

19He’ll answer them,

“I’m going to send you grain, new wine, and olive oil;

you’ll be satisfied.

I’ll never again make you a byword the world over.

20I’ll remove the northern threat far from you

and drive him into a parched, desolate land.

I’ll drive his vanguard into the Dead Sea,

his rear guard into the Mediterranean.

The stench from rotting bodies will rise over the land.”

The Lord has done great things! Joel 2:18-20

21Don’t be afraid, O land; celebrate and be happy

because the LORD has done great things.

22Don’t be afraid, animals in the field,

because the pastures in the countryside have turned green.

The trees have borne their fruit;

the fig tree and vine have given their full yield.

23So celebrate, people of Zion;

be happy in the LORD your God

because he’s given you the autumn rains to vindicate you.

He has poured down rain for you,

the autumn and spring rains like before.

24The threshing floor will be full of grain;

the vats will overflow with new wine and olive oil.

25 “Then I’ll make up to you for the years

the swarming locusts, crawling locusts,

stripping locusts, and cutting locusts have eaten—

the enormous army I sent at you.

26You’ll have plenty to eat;

praise the LORD your God,

who has dealt with you amazingly;

then you’ll never be disgraced.

27That’s how you’ll know I’m in the land,

that I’m the LORD your God,

and there’s no other. Joel 2:21-27

The LORD Promises His Spirit

28“After that, I’ll pour out my Spirit on all kinds of people:

sons and daughters will prophesy,

old men will dream dreams,

young men will see visions.

29I’ll even pour out my Spirit

on male and female servants.

30I’ll display wonders in the sky and on the earth:

blood, fire, and columns of smoke.

31The sun will turn dark, and the moon will turn red

before that great, notable day of the LORD.”

32At that time, he’ll save whoever calls on him.

On Mount Zion and in Jerusalem

people will escape like the LORD said;

among the survivors will be the people the LORD calls.

Joel 2:28-32

Judgment Against Enemy Nations

3:1“When I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem, 2I’ll gather the nations to the Valley of Jehoshaphat and condemn them there on behalf of Israel, my permanent possession, my people. They scattered them among the nations, divided up my land, 3cast lots for my people, traded a boy for a prostitute, and sold a girl for wine to get drunk on.

4“What are you to me, Tyre, Sidon, Philistia? You think you’re going to pay me back? If you try, I’ll return it on your head swift and soon. 5You’ve stolen my silver and gold, taken my precious treasures into your temples, 6and sold Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks to remove them far away. 7So I’m going to raise them up from where you sold them and pay you back on your own head. 8I’ll sell your sons and daughters to Judah to sell to the Sabeans far away.

I, the LORD, have spoken.” Joel 3:1-8

9Declare this among the nations:

“Prepare for war; rouse the powerful;

let the fighting men advance and engage.

10Beat your plowshares into swords,

your pruning hooks into spears;

have even the weak say, ‘I’m a soldier now.’

11Come quickly, nations everywhere;

gather there.”

LORD, bring out your soldiers!

12“Let the nations muster to the Valley of Jehoshaphat;

that’s where I’ll pronounce judgment on them all. Joel 3:9-12

13Use the sickle; the harvest is ripe.

Come and tread; the winepress is full;

the vats are overflowing with those people’s sinfulness.”

14Thousands upon thousands in the valley of decision!

The day of the LORD is near in the valley of decision!

15The sun and moon will grow dark;

the stars will quit shining.

16The LORD will roar out of Zion;

he’ll thunder from Jerusalem.

Earth and sky will reverberate;

the LORD will be his people’s refuge,

a strong fortress for the sons of Israel.

17Then you’ll know I’m the LORD your God,

who lives on Zion, my holy mountain.

So Jerusalem will be holy;

foreigners will never overrun it again. Joel 3:13-17

Blessings for God’s People

18“At that time, the mountains will drip with sweet wine;

the hills will flow with milk.

Water will run down the wadis in Judah;

a spring will gush out of the LORD’s Temple

and water the Valley of Shittim.

19Egypt will be a wasteland

and Edom a desert

because of their violence against Judah

and the murder of its innocent people.

20But people will live in Judah forever,

in Jerusalem for all generations.

21I’ll avenge their blood that I haven’t already avenged

and make my home with them in Zion.” Joel 3:18-21

AMOS

1:1The Message of Amos, Shepherd from Tekoa, That He Saw

at the Time of Uzziah, King of Judah, and Jeroboam Son of Joash, King of Israel,

Two Years Before the Earthquake

2He said,

“The LORD will roar from Zion;

he’ll thunder from Jerusalem.

The shepherds’ pastures will dry up;

the grass on Carmel’s summit will wither away.”

God’s Judgment on Israel’s Neighbors

3The LORD says,

“For three sins of Damascus and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:e said, He said

they threshed the people of Gilead

with sledges that had iron teeth.

4So I’ll send down fire on the house of Hazael,

consume the fortresses of Benhadad,

5break the bars on the gates of Damascus,

eliminate the people in the Valley of Aven

and the one that holds the scepter from Beth-eden.

The people of Syria will go to Kir in exile.” Amos 1:1-5

6The LORD says,

“For three sins of Gaza and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they deported an entire population to Edom.

7So I’ll send down fire on the walls of Gaza

and consume its fortresses.

8I’ll eliminate the people from Ashdod

and the one that holds the scepter in Ashkelon.

I’ll unleash my power on Ekron,

And the remnant of Philistines will perish.” Amos 1:6-8

9The LORD says,

“For three sins of Tyre and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they delivered an entire population to Edom

and broke the treaty between kin.

10So I’ll send down fire on the walls of Tyre

and burn its fortresses.” Amos 1:9-10

11The LORD says,

“For three sins of Edom and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they pursued their brothers with a sword

and tossed mercy aside.

In their anger they slashed them again and again;

they kept up their fury without end.

12So I’ll send down fire on Teman

and burn the fortresses in Bozrah.” Amos 1:11-12

13The LORD says,

“For three sins of the Ammonites and for four,

I won’t hold back their punishment:

they ripped open pregnant women in Gilead

when they extended their borders.

14So I’ll kindle a fire on the walls of Rabbah

and burn its fortresses

amid war cries like a storm.

15Their king will go into exile with his officials.” Amos 1:13-15

2:1The LORD says,

“For three sins of Moab and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they burned the king of Edom’s bones into lime.

2So I’ll burn the fortresses in Kerioth;

Moab will die amid turmoil,

war cries, and bugle blasts.

3I’ll eliminate judges from him

and slay his officials with him.” Amos 2:1-3

God’s Judgment on Judah and Israel

4The LORD says,

“For three sins of Judah and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

he rejected the Law of the LORD

and didn’t keep his statutes.

The same lies have led them astray

that their ancestors followed.

5So I’ll send down fire on Judah

and burn the fortresses in Jerusalem.” Amos 2:4-5

6The LORD says,

“For three sins of Israel and for four,

I won’t hold back its punishment:

they sell the good for money,

the poor for a pair of shoes.

7They walk on the heads of the poor in the dust

and abandon those who are suffering.

A man and his father sleep with the same girl

to profane my holy name.

8They lie down beside every altar

on cloaks taken as pledges.

In God’s Temple they drink the wine

of the people they’ve fined. Amos 2:6-8

9“Yet I was the One that destroyed the Amorites for you,

though they were as tall as cedars and strong as oaks.

I destroyed their fruit above and their roots below.

10I was the One that brought you up from Egypt,

and led you in the desert for 40 years

to take over the land of the Amorites.

11Then I raised up some of your offspring to be prophets

and some of your young men to be Nazirites.

Isn’t that so, Israel? Amos 2:9-11

12“But you made Nazirites drink wine

and told prophets not to prophesy!

13I’ll weigh you down like a wagon

overloaded with bundles,

14The swift won’t be able to flee;

the strong will lose their strength;

the powerful won’t save their lives.

15The archers won’t stand their ground;

the swift won’t escape;

the cavalry won’t save themselves.

16The bravest among the troops

will drop their weapons and run

when that time comes.” Amos 2:12-16

Witnesses Summoned Against Israel

3:1Listen to what the LORD says against you, Israel, against the entire family he brought out of Egypt:

2“Of all the families in the world, only you have me;

so I’ll punish you for your sins.

3Can two men walk together unless they’ve agreed on their route?

4Does a lion roar in the woods before it’s made a kill?

Does a young lion growl in his den unless he’s taken something?

5Does a bird fall into a trap on the ground if there’s no bait in it?

Does a trap snap shut if nothing trips it?

6If a bugle blows in the city, won’t the people be afraid?

If a catastrophe falls on a city, hasn’t the LORD planned it?

7For certain the LORD God doesn’t do anything

without revealing his secret counsel to his prophets.

8A lion has roared! Who’s not afraid?

The Lord GOD has spoken! Who can refuse to prophesy?”

Amos 3:1-8

9Declare on the fortresses in Ashdod and Egypt:

“Gather in the mountains around Samaria and watch the great turmoil and oppression in it. 10They don’t know how to do what’s right; they store up violence and devastation in their fortresses.”

11So the Lord GOD says,

“An enemy will surround the land,

pull down your fortresses,

and loot your strongholds.

12Like a shepherd snatches from a lion’s mouth

a couple legs or part of an ear,

so I’ll deliver the Israelites living in Samaria

like the corner of a couch and the cover on a bed.

13Listen and testify against Jacob’s house.

14When I punish Israel’s sins, I’ll punish Bethel’s altars too.

I’ll cut off the horns of the altar, and they’ll fall on the ground.

15I’ll strike their winter palaces and summer homes;

stately residences full of ivory will perish;

their mansions will meet their end.” Amos 3:9-15

Israel Does Not Learn

4:1Listen to this, you cows of Bashan living in Samaria,

you women that oppress the poor and crush the needy,

that tell their husbands, “Bring the wine so we can get drunk!”

2The Lord GOD has sworn by his holiness,

“The time’s coming when they’ll take you away with meat hooks,

the last of you like fish on hooks.

3You’ll leave through the breaches in the walls,

each one straight ahead.

You’ll be thrown out into Harmon/Mt. Hermon.” Amos 4:1-3

4“Go sacrifice at Bethel and sin;

multiply your disobedience in Gilgal!

Bring your sacrifices every morning,

your tithes every three days.

5Offer a thank offering with yeast in it;

declare freewill offerings and brag about it.

That’s what you like to do, you people in Israel.

6“I brought hunger to all your towns,

clean teeth everywhere you live;

yet you haven’t come back to me. Amos 4:4-6

7“I kept it from raining

when it was still three months till harvest.

Then I’d let it rain on one city

and not on another.

One place would get rain;

the place that didn’t, would dry up.

8So two or three towns would stagger to another to get a drink,

but they wouldn’t get enough;

yet you haven’t come back to me.

9“I struck you with blight and mildew,

and laid waste your orchards and vineyards.

The locusts ate your fig trees and olives;

yet you haven’t come back to me.” Amos 4:7-9

10“I sent a plague among you like I did in Egypt;

I killed your young men with the sword

along with your captured horses.

I made the stench in your camp fill your nostrils;

yet you haven’t come back to me.

11“I overthrew you like I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah;

your survivors were like charred stakes snatched from the fire;

yet you haven’t come back to me. Amos 4:10-11

12“Because I’m going to do this to you, Israel,

prepare to meet your God.”

13The One that builds mountains and creates wind,

reveals to people what he’s thinking,

the One that turns dawn into darkness

and walks on mountaintops—

the LORD God of Hosts. Amos 4:12-13

A Call to Repentance

5:1Listen to the dirge I’m chanting for you, Israel:

2“She’s fallen;

virgin Israel won’t get up again.

She’s abandoned on the ground;

no one will help get her up.

3The city that goes out 1,000 strong

will have 100 left;

the one that goes out 100 strong

will have 10.” Amos 5:1-3

4The LORD tells Israel,

“Rely on me so you can live.

5Don’t rely on Bethel or go to Gilgal or Beersheba;

Gilgal is headed for captivity,

and Bethel will cease to exist.

6Rely on me so you can live,

so I don’t break out like fire, House of Joseph,

and burn in Bethel with no one to quench it,

7you that pervert justice into bitter oppression

and toss goodness on the ground.” Amos 5:4-7

8The LORD is the One that made Pleiades and Orion,

that changes deep darkness into morning

and darkens day into night,

that calls water out of the ocean

and pours it out on land.

9He’s the One that flashes destruction at the strong

and demolishes their fortresses. Amos 5:8-9

10They hate the one that reproves in court;

they abhor anyone that speaks with integrity.

11So, since you impose heavy rent on the poor

and exact tribute on their grain,

though you build houses out of well-hewn stone,

you won’t live in them;

though you plant lush vineyards,

you won’t drink their wine.

12I know about your many, serious sins,

you that distress decent people, accept bribes,

and deprive the poor of justice in court.

13In such cases, prudent people keep quiet

because it’s an evil time. Amos 5:10-13

14Do what’s good so you can live,

so the LORD God of Hosts will be with you

like you said.

15Hate evil, love good;

establish justice in court!

Maybe the LORD God of Hosts

will show grace to the remnant in Joseph. Amos 5:14-15

16So, the LORD God of Hosts says,

“What wailing there is in all the squares!

What mourning in every street!’

They’re calling on farmers to moan

and professional mourners to lament.

17In all the vineyards there’ll be wailing

because I’ll pass through your midst.” Amos 5:16-17

The Day of the LORD

18What longing you have for the day of the LORD!

But what good will it do you?

That day will be darkness for you, not light.

19It will be like a man that runs from a lion

and meets a bear;

or goes home, leans his hand on the wall,

and gets bit by a snake.

20Won’t the day of the LORD be darkness instead of light,

gloom without brightness? Amos 5:18-20

21“I despise your festivals;

I don’t delight in your solemn assemblies.

22Though you offer me burnt offerings and grain offerings,

I won’t accept them.

I won’t even look at your peace offerings of grain-fed animals.

23Take away your noisy songs;

I don’t want to listen to your lyres.

24Instead, make justice run down like water

and goodness like a constant-flowing stream. Amos 5:21-24

25“Did you bring me sacrifices and grain offerings in the desert for 40 years, Israel? 26Well, you also carried along Sakkuth your king god and Kaiwan your star god, images you made for yourselves. 27So I’ll send you into exile beyond Damascus,” the LORD says, whose name is The God of Hosts.

Amos 5:25-27

Woe to the Complacent

6:1“Misfortune awaits those of you at ease in Zion,

who feel secure in Samaria,

you notable leaders of that foremost nation

that the House of Israel comes to.

2Go over to Calneh and look at what happened there;

go from there to Hamath the great city;

then go down to Gath of the Philistines.

Are you better than those kingdoms?

Is their territory bigger than yours?

3Are you trying to push away the time of catastrophe?

You’re only bringing the violence nearer. Amos 6:1-3

4“Misfortune awaits you that stretch out on ivory beds,

that lounge on your couches,

that eat lambs from the flock

and calves from the stall,

5that sing idle songs to the sound of a lyre

and invent musical instruments like David did,

6that drink wine by the bowlful

and anoint yourselves with the finest oils,

but don’t grieve over Joseph’s demise.

7You’ll be at the front of the exiles;

your partying on couches is over with.” Amos 6:4-7

8The Lord GOD has sworn by himself,

the LORD God of Hosts has declared:

“I abhor Jacob’s pride;

I detest his fortresses.

So I’ll deliver up to its enemies

this city and everything in it.” Amos 6:8

9It will be that, if ten die in one house 10and the relative that comes to dispose of their bodies says, “Is anyone else here?” any survivor may start to swear, “No, . . .” But the relative will interrupt, “Don’t finish your oath. Don’t even mention the LORD.” Amos 6:9-10

11The LORD is going to command

to smash big houses to pieces

and crush little ones to bits.

12Do horses run on rocks?

Do people plow the sea with oxen?

Yet you’ve turned justice into poison

and made the fruit of goodness bitter.

13To you that celebrate in Lo-debar

and say, “We’ve taken Karnaim by our own power.”

14the LORD God of Hosts says,

“I’m going to raise up a nation against you, Israel;

“they’ll oppress you from Lebo-hamath to the Arabah Valley.”

Amos 6:11-14

A Vision of Locusts

7:1The Lord GOD showed me a vision. He formed a locust swarm after the spring crop sprouted and the king had mowed his share. 2The swarm had finished eating the vegetation, and I said,

“Lord GOD, please pardon!

How will Joseph make it?

He’s too small!”

3The LORD changed his mind.

“It won’t happen.” Amos 7:1-3

A Vision of Fire

4The Lord GOD showed me another vision: he had called for fire to punish them. It had burned up the depths of the sea and was beginning to burn up the landscape. 5I said,

“Lord GOD, please stop!

How can Joseph make it?

He’s too small!”

6The LORD changed his mind.

“This won’t happen either.” Amos 7:4-6

A Vision of a Plumb Line

7He showed me that he was standing by a wall with a plumb line in his hand.

8He said, “What do you see, Amos?”

“A plumb line.”

“I’m about to put a plumb line on my people Israel;

I’m not going to spare them anymore.

9The high places of Isaac will be desolate,

the sanctuaries of Israel will be laid waste;

I’ll attack Jeroboam’s dynasty with a sword.” Amos 7:7-9

Amaziah Accuses Amos of Conspiracy

10Then Amaziah, priest at Bethel, sent a message to Jeroboam, king of Israel,

“Amos has plotted against you in Israel. The land can’t endure what he keeps saying: 11‘Jeroboam will die by the sword;

Israel will go into exile.’”

12So Amaziah told Amos, “Get out of here, you seer! Go to Judah and prophesy for food! 13Don’t prophesy at Bethel anymore. It’s a king’s sanctuary and a national place of worship.”

14Amos answered him,

“I wasn’t a prophet or a prophet’s son. I was a shepherd that tended fig trees. 15But the LORD took me from following flocks and told me to prophesy to his people. 16Listen to what he says. You tell me not to prophesy against Israel or preach against Isaac. 17So the LORD says,

‘Your wife will be a prostitute in the city,

your children will fall by the sword,

your property will be parceled up,

and you’ll die in an unclean land.

Israel will go into exile.’” Amos 7:10-17

A Vision of Ripe Fruit

8:1The Lord GOD showed me a basket of ripe fruit.

2“What do you see, Amos?”

“A basket of ripe fruit.”

“My people Israel are also ripe—for punishment. I won’t spare them any longer. 3The singing at the palace will turn into wailing. There’ll be lots of corpses silently thrown out everywhere.”

4Listen to this, you that run over the needy and trample on the humble, 5saying,

“When’s the new moon going to be over

so we can buy grain?

When will the Sabbath be past

so we can open the wheat market—

make the bushel smaller, the shekel heavier,

and cheat with dishonest scales;

6so we can buy the helpless for money

and the poor for a pair of shoes,

and sell the chaff with the wheat?” Amos 8:1-6

7The LORD has sworn by Jacob’s arrogance,

“I’ll never forget what they’ve done.

8“Because of it, won’t the land quake

and everybody in it mourn?

It will swell up like the Nile,

flood all over, and recede.

9At that time, I’ll make the sun go down at noon

and make the earth dark in broad daylight.

10I’ll turn your festivals into mourning

and your singing into funeral chants.

I’ll put burlap around everybody’s waist

and make every head bald,

like the mourning for an only son;

the end will be a bitter day.” Amos 8:7-10

11The Lord GOD says.

“The time’s coming when

I’ll send a famine on the land,

not a famine of bread and water,

but a famine of hearing from the LORD.

12People will stagger from sea to sea,

from north to east,

here to there,

looking for a message from the LORD,

but not finding any.

13At that time, beautiful virgins

and strong young men will faint from thirst.

14The ones that swear by the guilt of Samaria,

who say, ‘As your god lives, Dan,’

‘As the way to Beersheba lives’—

will fall and never get up.” Amos 8:11-14

A Vision of Locusts

9:1I saw the LORD standing by the altar. He said,

“Strike the capitals till the thresholds shake;

shatter them on the people’s heads.

What’s left, I’ll slay with the sword;

no fugitive will get away or refugee escape.

2Though they dig down to Sheol,

I’ll bring them up.

Though they fly up to the sky,

I’ll bring them down.

3Though they hide on top of Carmel,

I’ll look for them and banish them.

Though they hide on the floor of the sea,

I’ll tell a sea serpent to bite them.

4Even if their enemies take them into exile,

I’ll command a sword to slay them.

I’m determined to oppose them.” Amos 9:1-4

5The Lord Yahveh of Hosts—

who touches the land

and turns it into lava that makes the people mourn,

and the ground floods like the Nile and goes down again;

6the One who builds upper rooms that reach into the sky

and lays their foundations on the earth,

who draws up water from the sea

and pours it out as rain on the land—

his name is Yahveh. Amos 9:5-6

7“Aren’t you like Nubia to me, Israel?

Haven’t I brought Israel up from Egypt,

the Philistines from Crete,

the Syrians from Kir?

8I keep my eye on sinful kingdoms and destroy them;

but I won’t completely destroy the House of Jacob.

9I’ll give the command

to shake the House of Jacob among all nations

like grain in a sieve,

but not a kernel will fall on the ground.

10All the sinners among my people will die by the sword

who say, ‘Catastrophe won’t overtake us.’

A Promise of Restoration

11At that time, I’ll rebuild David’s fallen shelter

and fix the breaches in its walls.

I’ll raise it up from its ruins

and restore it like it was in the old days,

12so they can possess what’s left of Edom

and all the nations that wear my name.” Amos 9:7-12

13The LORD says,

“The time’s coming,

when reaping will last till plowing

and grape treading will go on till sowing time,

when new wine will drip from the mountains

and flow from the hills.

14I’ll return my people Israel from captivity.

They’ll rebuild the ruined towns and live in them,

plant vineyards and drink their wine,

plant gardens and eat their produce.

15I’ll plant them in their own country;

they won’t be uprooted again from the land

I’ve given them.” Amos 9:13-15

OBADIAH

1The Vision of Obadiah

Edom’s Judgment Foretold

The Lord GOD says this about Edom;

we’ve heard the report;

an ambassador has gone out to the nations to say:

“To arms, attack Edom.”

2“I’ll make you a minor player among the nations

and utterly despised.

3Your arrogance has deceived you,

you that live high in caves

and tell yourselves that nobody can bring you down.

4Though you’ve built high like an eagle

and put your nest among the stars,

I’ll bring you down. Obad 1-4

5“If thieves came to you at night—

what disaster awaits you!—

wouldn’t they steal only till they had enough?

If grape pickers came,

wouldn’t they leave some gleanings?

6But how you’ll be pillaged, Esau,

and your hidden treasures found!

7Your allies will drive you out of your borders;

the people at peace with you

will turn on you and overpower you;

the ones you eat with

will set up an ambush for you.

(You won’t suspect it.)

8At that time,” the LORD says, “won’t I destroy

the wise men out of Edom

and those with understanding from Esau’s mountain?

9Your strong troops will be afraid, Teman;

so everybody from Esau’s mountains

will be cut down in the slaughter. Obad 5-9

Edom’s Violence Against Israel

10“Because of your violence against Jacob your brother,

you’ll be covered with disgrace and permanently eliminated.

11You stood aloof

while foreigners cast lots for Jerusalem

and strangers entered its gates

to carry off its wealth.

You even joined them.

12You shouldn’t have gloated over your brother’s misfortune;

you shouldn’t have celebrated over Judah’s destruction

or boasted about his distress.

13You shouldn’t have entered my people’s gate

at the time of their disaster

or looted their goods during their catastrophe.

14You shouldn’t have stood at the fork in the road

to cut down their refugees

or have betrayed the survivors in their misfortune. Obad 10-14

Edom’s Destruction, Israel’s Restoration

15“The LORD’s judgment is coming on all the nations.

What you’ve done to Israel will be done to you;

your dealings will come back on your own head.

16You and those nations will drink the same punishment

you swallowed on my holy mountain.

You’ll all drink till you drown.

17But on Mount Zion some will escape,

and it’ll be holy;

Jacob’s house will return to reclaim its possession.

18Then Jacob’s house will become a fire,

Joseph’s house a flame,

Esau’s house the stubble.

They’ll set him on fire and burn him up;

there’ll be no survivors in Edom.”

The LORD has said it. Obad 15-18

19Then my people in the Negev will take over Esau’s mountains;

the ones in the western foothills will occupy the Philistine plain.

They’ll take over the fields of Ephraim and Samaria;

The people of Benjamin will occupy Gilead.

20Exiles from Israel

will replace the Phoenicians as far north as Zarephath;

the captives from Jerusalem that are in Sepharad [north]

will resettle their towns in the Negev [south].

21All those who were rescuedLXX will go up to Mount Zion

and extend its dominion over Esau’s mountains.

The kingdom will belong to the LORD. Obad 19-21

JONAH

Jonah’s Flight from the LORD

1:1The LORD told Jonah son of Amittai, 2“Go to Nineveh, that big city, and shout against it; I’ve seen how sinful they are.” 3But Jonah ran away. 3He went down to Joppa, found a ship to Tarshish, paid the fare, and boarded.

4The LORD hurled a gale on the sea, and it was about to break up the ship. 5The sailors were scared, and every man cried out to his god. They threw the cargo overboard to lighten the ship. Jonah had gone below and fallen sound asleep. 6The captain came and said, “How come you’re sleeping? Get up, call on your god. Maybe he’ll be concerned about us enough to keep us from dying.” 7They said to one another, “Let’s cast lots to find out who caused this catastrophe to hit us.” They cast lots, and it fell on Jonah. 8“Tell us, now! Why has this catastrophe fallen on us? What’s your job? What’s your country? Who are your people?” Jon 1:1-8

9“I’m a Hebrew; I fear the LORD God of heaven that made the land and sea.”

10They were really afraid, “How could you do that?” (They knew he was running from the LORD; he’d told them.) 11“What should we do to you to stop the sea from raging?” It kept getting worse.

12“Throw me into the sea. I know it’s my fault this severe storm has come on you.”

13But they rowed hard, trying to get back to shore, but they couldn’t. The sea was getting even rougher. 14So they called on the LORD, “We earnestly pray, LORD, not to let us die over this man’s sin. Don’t hold us guilty for throwing him to his death. You’re doing what you wanted.” 15They picked Jonah up and threw him overboard, and the sea stopped raging. 16They feared the LORD greatly and offered sacrifice to him and made vows. Jon 1:9-16

Jonah’s Prayer

17The LORD had a big fish swallow Jonah, and he was in its stomach three days and nights.

2:1Jonah prayed to the LORD his God from the fish’s stomach,

2“I called to you in my distress,

and you answered me;

I cried out for help from the belly of Sheol,

and you heard me.

3You threw me into the deep,

into the heart of the sea;

the current swirled over me;

your waves and breakers overwhelmed me.

4So I said, ‘I’ve been driven away from you,

but I’ll still look toward your holy Temple.’ Jon 1:17-2:4

5Water closed in over me;

the great deep surrounded me;

seaweed wrapped around my head.

6I sank down to the base of the mountains;

the earth imprisoned me forever,

but you brought me up from the Pit,

LORD my God.

7As my life was fading away,

I remembered you

and prayed to you in your holy Temple.

8Those who pay respects to pointless idols

forfeit your faithfulness,

9but I’ll sacrifice to you with thanksgiving.

I’ll do what I’ve vowed;

salvation comes from you.’”

10Then the LORD had the fish cough Jonah up onto the shore. Jon 2:5-10

Jonah Preaches at Nineveh

3:1The LORD told Jonah again, 2“Go to Nineveh, the big city, and deliver what I tell you.” 3So he went. It was a big city, a three-days’ walk-through. 4He went through it one day’s walk and shouted, “God is going to overthrow Nineveh in 40 days.” 5The people believed him. They called for a fast and put on burlap from least to greatest.

6When the message reached the king of Nineveh, he got off his throne, laid his robe aside, covered himself with burlap, and sat on ashes. 7He issued a proclamation:

“In Nineveh by decree of the king and his nobles: Don’t anybody—animal, herd, or flock—eat anything or drink water. 8People and animals have to wear burlap. Call on God earnestly so everyone will turn from sinfulness and violence. 9Who knows, maybe God will relent from his fierce anger and not destroy us.

10When God saw they’d repented, he relented from doing what he’d threatened. Jon 3:1-10

Jonah’s Anger over the LORD’s Mercy

4:1That really made Jonah mad. 2He told the LORD,

“That’s exactly what I said back home and why I tried to run away to Tarshish. I knew you’re a gracious, merciful God, slow to get angry and full of enduring love, and relent from bringing catastrophe. 3So take my life; I’d be better off dead.”

4The LORD asked, “What right do you have to be mad?” Jon 4:1-4

5Jonah left the city and sat down east of it. He made a lean-to and sat in its shade to see what would happen to the city. 6The LORD God had a plant grow up to shade him and give him relief. He was glad to see it. 7But at dawn the next day, God had a worm attack the plant, and it withered. 8When the sun came up, God had a scorching east wind blow and the sun beat down on Jonah’s head till he became faint and begged to die, “I’d be better off dead.” Jon 4:5-8

9Then God asked, “What right do you have to be mad about a plant?!”

“I’ve got reason to be mad enough to die.”

10“You’re concerned about a plant you didn’t plant or make grow, that came up overnight and died overnight. 11Shouldn’t I be concerned about Nineveh, a big city with more than 120,000 people that don’t know left from right—as well as lots of animals?” Jon 4:9-11

MICAH

1:1A Message from the LORD to Micah from Moresheth

at the Time of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, Kings of Judah.

What He Saw About Samaria and Jerusalem

Judgment Against Samaria and Jerusalem

2Listen, every nation;

listen, world and everybody in it.

Let the Lord GOD testify against you from his holy Temple.

3He’s coming down from his place

to walk on the mountaintops.

4The mountains will mash down under his feet

and cascade into the valleys—

like wax in a fire or

water rushing on a slope. Mic 1:1-4

5That’s because Jacob rebelled

and Israel sinned.

Where’s Jacob’s rebellion?

Isn’t it in Samaria?

Where’s Judah’s main high place?

Isn’t it in Jerusalem?

6I’ll make Samaria a pile of ruins in the countryside,

a place to plant vineyards.

I’ll drag the stones of its walls down to the valley

and expose its foundations.

7I’ll smash its idols,

and burn everything in it.

I’ll destroy its images

because they came from a prostitute’s pay;

that’s all they’ll be. Mic 1:5-7

8Because of this, I’ll mourn and wail,

and walk around barefoot and naked.

I’ll howl like a jackal

and moan like an owl.

9My people’s wound is too deep to heal;

it’s penetrated into Judah

all the way up to Jerusalem’s gates.

10Don’t “tell” it in Gath;

don’t weep at all;

roll in the “dust” at Beth-leaphrah.

11Just move on into captivity

naked and embarrassed, residents of Shaphir;

the people in Zaaman don’t dare “come outside” its wall;

there’s mourning in Beth-ezel

because its people have no back up. Mic 1:8-11

12Those living in Maroth grow weak waiting for relief,

because “bitter” calamity from the LORD

is reaching the gates of Jerusalem.

13Harness a “team of horses” to a chariot and flee,

people in Lachish, where Zion’s sin came from,

where Israel’s rebellious acts spread from into Judah.

14Send farewell gifts to Moresheth-gath;

the houses in Achzib have “deceived” the kings in Israel.

15I’ll bring a “conqueror” on you, people of Mareshah;

Israel’s leaders will flee to the cave of Adullam.

16Shave off your hair in despair for the children you delight in;

make yourself as bald as an eagle

because they’re going into exile. Mic 1:12-16

Judgment Against Wealthy Oppressors

2:1Misfortune awaits those who devise sin,

who lie awake plotting schemes in bed!

In the morning they do them

because they can.

2They covet fields and seize them;

they desire horses and take them.

They rob people

and confiscate the property they’ve inherited.

3So the LORD says,

“I’m devising a catastrophe for this family;

you won’t get your necks out of the noose.

You won’t keep carrying on arrogantly;

it’ll be a terrible time for you.

4Your enemies will taunt you with a proverb

and wail a bitter dirge in mockery,

‘We’re ruined!

God is reapportioning our things.

He’s taking them away from us

and giving our fields to apostates!’

5So you won’t have anyone stretching out a surveying line

for you by lot in the LORD’s assembly. Mic 2:1-5

6“‘Don’t preach about such things,’ they say;

‘disgrace won’t catch up with us.’

7Are you really saying such a thing, House of Jacob?

Isn’t the LORD’s Spirit patient?

Does he do such things?

Don’t his words do good

for those who do right?

8My people rise up against my people;

they strip robes off the peaceful,

off of people that go along innocently

with no thought of fighting.

9They evict my people’s women from their pleasant homes

and forever strip away from their children

the splendor I would give them.

10Get up and get out of here!

this is no longer a place to rest;

there’s sinfulness here

that brings painful destruction.

11If a liar full of hot air tells you

he’ll preach about the fun of wine and alcohol,

he’ll certainly get a hearing from you! Mic 2:6-11

12“I’ll assemble you, Jacob, remnant of Israel,

and put you together like sheep in a fold;

like a flock in its pasture,

you’ll be a noisy crowd in your land.

13The One that opens the gate will lead you out;

you’ll break out of exile through it.

Your King will go out ahead of you,

the LORD at the lead.” Mic 2:12-13

Judgment Against Israel’s Leaders

3:1I said,

“Listen, leaders of Jacob, rulers of Israel.

Aren’t you supposed to know what’s good,

2you that hate good and love evil,

who skin my people alive,

pull the meat off their bones,

3eat their flesh,

break up their bones in pieces,

and chop them up for the pot

like meat in a kettle?”

4You’ll call out to the LORD,

but he won’t answer you;

he’ll turn away from you

because of all your sins. Mic 3:1-4

5The LORD says this about you prophets

that mislead my people:

“When you have something to eat,

you prophesy peace;

But you declare holy war against anyone

that doesn’t feed you.

6Consequently, you’ll have nights without visions,

darkness without fortunetelling.

The sun will set on you prophets;

the day will get dark over you.

7You seers will be put to shame;

you fortunetellers will be disgraced.

You’ll have to cover your mouths in humiliation

because I won’t answer you.”

8But I’m filled with power—

with the Spirit of the LORD—

with justice and courage

to declare to Jacob his transgression,

to Israel his sin. Mic 3:5-8

9Listen, leaders of Jacob, rulers of Israel,

who abhor justice and twist the truth,

10who build Zion with bloodshed

and Jerusalem with violence.

11You leaders render verdicts for a bribe;

you priests teach for hire;

you prophets tell fortunes for money.

Yet you want to rely on the LORD and say,

“The LORD’s with us, right?

Catastrophe won’t happen to us.”

12So, because of you,

they’ll plow Zion like a field;

Jerusalem will become a pile of ruins;

the Temple mount will be a full-grown forest. Mic 3:9-12

The Mountain of the LORD

4:1In the last days,

the mountain the LORD’s Temple’s on

will be the tallest mountain.

It will loom above the hills,

and the people from many nations will stream to it.

2They’ll say,

“Let’s go up to the LORD’s mountain,

to the Temple of Jacob’s God,

so he can teach us his ways,

and we can follow in his paths.”

The Law will go out from Zion,

the LORD’s message from Jerusalem.

3He’ll mediate between many nations

and settle disputes between powerful countries far away.

They’ll hammer their swords into plowshares

and their spears into pruning hooks.

Nation won’t attack nation

or train for war anymore.

4Everyone will sit under their own vine and fig tree,

and nobody will make them afraid,

the LORD has said so. Mic 4:1-4

5The nations conduct themselves

in the name of their gods;

we will follow the LORD our God forever.

Israel’s Future Rescue from Exile

6“At that time,” the LORD says, “I’ll assemble the lame

and gather the exiles that I’ve oppressed.

7I’ll make the lame a remnant

and the exiles a powerful nation.

I’ll reign over them on Mount Zion permanently.

8Your former dominion will revert to you,

tower of the flock, hill of Zion, kingdom of Jerusalem. Mic 4:5-8

9“Now why are you crying out?

Don’t you have a king?

Has your advisor perished

and agony seized you as in childbirth?

10Writhe and groan, inhabitant of Zion,

like a woman in labor,

because you’ll leave this city

to live in the open country,

and go to Babylon.

But I’ll rescue you

and redeem you from your enemies there.

11Now many nations have gathered against you, saying,

‘Let’s desecrate it;

let’s take pride in destroying Zion.’

12But they don’t know what I’m thinking

or understand my purpose,

because I’m going to gather them up

like bundles for a threshing floor.

13Get up and thresh, Zion.

I’ll give you iron horns and bronze hoofs

so you can pulverize many nations

and the wealth of their unjust gain you can devote to me,

the Lord of the whole world. Mic 4:9-13

A Promised Ruler from Bethlehem

5:1“Muster your troops, Jerusalem;

your enemies are laying siege against you;

they’ll hit Israel’s leader in the face with a rod.

2But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah,

though you’re small among Judah’s clans,

you’ll have a ruler come out of you on my behalf in Israel.

His origins are from long ago, from ancient times.”

3Israel will be abandoned

till the one that’s in labor has the child;

then the rest of his relatives

will come back from exile.

4He’ll stand up and shepherd his flock

with the power and majesty of the LORD his God;

they’ll be able to remain secure

because at that time he’ll be great everywhere.

5He’ll give us peace. Mic 5:1-5a

When the Assyrians invade our land

and overrun fortresses,

we’ll fight back

with seven shepherds, eight princes leading us.

6They’ll shepherd Assyria with the sword,

the land of Nimrod with swords drawn.

A Remnant to Be Delivered

The LORD will deliver us from them

when they attack our land

and try to tramp all over our territory.

7Then the remnant of Jacob left in the land

will live among many nations

like dew from the LORD,

like showers on grass

that mortals can’t restrain,

that no one can delay. Mic 5:5b-7

8The remnant left in Jacob

will live among many nations

like a young lion in a flock of sheep.

He mauls and mangles as he goes;

no one can stop him.

9He’ll raise his hand against his enemies

and wipe them out.

10“At that time,” the LORD says,

“I’ll get rid of your horses

and destroy your chariots.

11I’ll demolish your towns

and tear down your defenses.

12I’ll abolish sorcery;

you won’t have fortunetellers anymore.

13I’ll get rid of your carved images and sacred pillars

so you won’t worship what you’ve made.

14I’ll pull up your Asherah poles

and destroy your pagan cities.

15I’ll carry out angry revenge

on nations that refuse to obey.” Mic 5:8-15

The LORD’s Case Against Israel

6:1Listen to what the LORD says:

“Present to the mountains your case against me;

let the hills hear your complaint.”

2But then listen, mountains, to the LORD’s complaint,

you enduring foundations of the world.

He has a suit against his people;

he’ll bring charges against Israel.

3“What have I done to you, my people?

How have I wearied you? Answer me.

4I brought you out of Egypt

and ransomed you from slavery.

I sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to lead you,

5My people, remember now

the curse that Balak, king of Moab, proposed,

the blessing that Balaam son of Beor answered with,

the laws that led you from Shittim to Gilgal,

so you could learn about my faithfulness.” Mic 6:1-5

6What should I bring to the LORD?

What should I bow with before God on high?

Should I come to him with burnt offerings

and yearling calves?

7Does the LORD delight in thousands of rams,

in 10,000 rivers of olive oil?

Am I to present my firstborn for my transgression,

the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?

8No, he’s told you what’s good:

what does the LORD require from you

but to do good, love kindness,

and walk humbly with him? Mic 6:6-8

Israel’s Guilt and Punishment

9The LORD will call out to the city—

it’s wise to respect him—

“Listen, tribe and city council.

10Can I overlook the wealth gained from cheating

that’s in sinners’ houses

and the short measure that’s accursed?

11Can I acquit a businessman that uses dishonest scales

and a bag of false weights?

12The rich in the city extort;

its residents lie and deceive. Mic 6:9-12

13So I’ll send diseases to strike you down,

and bring you to ruin for your sins.

14You’ll eat, but you won’t be satisfied;

there’ll be hunger among you.

You’ll store up for safe keeping,

but I’ll deliver most of it to the sword.

15You’ll plant, but not harvest;

you’ll tread olives, but not anoint yourself with the oil;

you’ll tread grapes, but not drink the wine.

16You’ve followed the statutes of sinful Omri

and the example of Ahab;

you’ve taken their advice.

So I’ll deliver you to destruction

and your people to ridicule;

you’ll endure the nations’ scorn.” Mic 6:13-16

Israel’s Misery Turned to Hope

7:1Misfortune is waiting for me!

I feel like people that pick fruit and gather grapes

but have no clusters to eat

or first-ripe figs to satisfy their hunger.

2Godly people have disappeared;

there aren’t any good ones left.

They all premeditate murder;

each hunts the other with a net.

3Both hands do evil well,

officials and judges both demand bribes,

influential people vie for preferential treatment;

together they weave injustice. Mic 7:1-3

4The best of them are like briars;

the most godly are like a thorn hedge.

They can post a watchman,

but their punishment will still come;

their confusion is at hand.

5Don’t trust your neighbor,

don’t confide in a friend,

be careful what you tell your wife.

6Son treats father with contempt;

daughter defies mother,

daughter-in-law defies mother-in-law;

people have enemies in their own families. Mic 7:4-6

7But I will look to the LORD;

I’ll wait for God, who keeps me safe.

He’ll listen to me.

8Don’t gloat over me, adversary.

Though I fall, I’ll get up;

though I live in the dark, the LORD’s my light. Mic 7:7-8

9I’ll bear the LORD’s indignation

because admittedly I’ve sinned against him;

then he’ll give me justice against my enemy.

He’ll bring me out to the light,

and I’ll be able to see his goodness.

10As a result, my enemy will see it too

and be put to shame who said,

“Where’s the LORD your God?”

I’ll watch while he’s tramped on

like dirt on a road.

11It’ll be a time, Israel, for rebuilding your walls

and extending your boundaries,

12a day when people come to you

from Assyria and the cities of Egypt—

from Egypt to the Euphrates,

from sea to sea and mountain to mountain.

13But first the land will become desolate

because of what its people have done. Mic 7:9-13

14Shepherd your people with your staff,

your flock that lives alone in a woods

surrounded by productive fields.

Let them pasture in Bashan and Gilead

like they did in the old days.

15“I’ll show you amazing miracles

like I did when you came out of Egypt.”

16Nations will see them

and be embarrassed at their own weakness.

They’ll put their hand over their mouth in awe,

and their ears will pop.

17They’ll lick dust like a snake,

like a reptile in the dirt.

They’ll come cringing out of their fortresses

and turn to the LORD our God. Mic 7:14-17

The LORD’s Compassion for Israel

18What God is like you, that pardons sin

and passes over the rebellious acts

the remnant of his permanent possession has done?

19You’ll show us mercy again,

tread our iniquities underfoot,

throw our sins in the sea.

20You’ll show covenant faithfulness to Jacob,

enduring love to Abraham

like you swore to our ancestors so long ago. Mic 7:18-20

NAHUM

1:1The Oracle of Nahum

The Book of the Vision of Nahum

The LORD’s Anger Against Nineveh

2The LORD is an exclusive God

that avenges with anger.

He carries out vengeance on his adversaries;

he stores up anger for his enemies.

3He doesn’t get mad quick,

but he does exert his power;

he doesn’t let the guilty go free.

He displays his power in storms and tornadoes;

clouds are dust beneath his feet. Nah 1:1-3

4At his command seas and rivers dry up,

Bashan and Carmel wither,

Lebanon’s blossoms wilt.

5In his presence, mountains quake and hills melt;

earth trembles and its people perish. Nah 1:4-5

6Who can withstand his indignation?

Who can endure his furious anger?

He pours out wrath like fire

and cracks rocks in pieces.

7The LORD is good, a fortress in times of trouble;

he knows who takes refuge in him.

8But with an overwhelming flood,

he brings his opponents to a complete end

and chases his enemies into the dark. Nah 1:6-8

9Whatever you’re plotting against the LORD

he’ll put an end to;

he doesn’t need to take revenge twice.

10His enemies, like tangled thornbushes and staggering people,

he’ll completely burn up like stubble.

11Who is this counselor of yours

that plots against the LORD with bad advice?

12This is what the LORD says,

“Though strong and numerous,

the Assyrians will perish and disappear.

Though I’ve let them punish you before,

I won’t let them do it again.

13I’ll break their yoke off your neck

and tear their shackles off your feet.” Nah 1:9-13

14The LORD has issued an edict about you, Assyria:

“No offspring will carry on your name;

I’ll remove idol and image

from the temples of your gods.

I’ll get your grave ready

because you’re contemptible.” Nah 1:14

15Over the mountains, a messenger is coming with good news,

someone that’s announcing peace!

Celebrate your festivals, Judah; fulfill your vows;

those wicked invaders will never attack you again.

I’ll completely destroy them. Nah 1:15

Nineveh to Fall

2:1Attackers are advancing to crush you, Nineveh.

Man the ramparts, guard the road,

muster your forces, get ready.

2The LORD is going to restore majesty to Jacob,

splendor to Israel;

because plunderers have stripped it

and cut the branches off its grapevines. Nah 2:1-2

3The shields of the valiant flash red;

the soldiers wear scarlet uniforms;

the chariots glitter like steel

as they muster into formation;

they rattle their cypress spears.

4The chariots rush madly down the streets

and race wildly around the squares.

They shine like torches,

dashing here and there like lightning.

5The king orders his officers;

they scramble around in their haste

and hurry to the wall to set up defenses.

6But their enemy tears open the gates of the river

to undermine the palace.

7They strip it and loot it.

Its young women moan like pigeons

and beat their chests. Nah 2:3-7

8Nineveh is like a leaking reservoir.

“Stop! Stop! deserting residents!”

but none of them even look back.

9Plunder the silver!

Plunder the gold!

Treasure without limit,

wealth of all kinds!

10IThe city is desolate and in ruins!

Hearts melt and knees knock!

Loins throb in pain; faces turn pale! Nah 2:8-10

11Where’s that lion’s den now,

that feeding place for young lions,

where the lion brought its prey,

where its cubs stayed unthreatened,

12where it tore off enough for its cubs

and strangled prey for its lionesses?

It filled its lair with prey, with mutilated meat.

13The LORD of Hosts says,

“I’m your enemy.

I’ll burn your chariots in smoke,

kill your young lions with a sword,

and leave you with no nations to prey on.

Your ambassadors won’t be bringing reports anymore.”

Nah 2:11-13

Woe to Nineveh

3:1Misfortune awaits bloody Nineveh,

filled with lies and pillage

and plunder without limit.

2Do you hear the crack of whips, rattling wheels,

galloping horses, rushing chariots!?

3Do you see cavalry charging,

swords flashing, spears gleaming,

many slain, piles of corpses,

countless bodies,

and people stumbling over them!?

4That’s all because of your continual prostitution,

that charming mistress of sorceries;

you sell nations by your prostitution,

countries by your sorceries.

5“I’m your enemy,” the LORD of Hosts says;

“I’ll pull your skirts up over your heads,

and show the nations your nakedness,

the kingdoms your disgrace.

6I’ll throw filth on you,

make you disgusting,

make a spectacle out of you!

7Everybody that sees you will back away and say,

‘Nineveh lies in ruins!

Who’s going to grieve over her?’

Where will her comforters come from?” Nah 3:1-7

8Are you any better than Thebes

that sat by the Nile

with water all around it,

with the river as its wall and rampart?

9Nubia was its strength,

Egypt too, with no limit;

Put and the Libyans allied with it.

10Yet Thebes was carried into captivity.

Its little ones were dashed to pieces

at the head of every street;

they cast lots for its honorable men

and tied up its leaders in chains. Nah 3:8-10

11You’ll get drunk too, Nineveh, go into a stupor,

and look for refuge from your enemy.

12Your fortresses are like fig trees with ripe fruit;

if you shake them, their figs fall into your mouth.

13Your troops are women!

Your gates stand wide open for your enemies;

fires consume your bars. Nah 3:11-13

14Draw water for your siege!

Strengthen your fortifications!

Get in the clay pits to tread mortar!

Put it in brick molds!

15But fire will burn you up;

the sword will cut you down

and eat you up like locusts.

Though you have multiplied like crawling locusts

and propagated like grasshoppers,

16though your traders have come to outnumber the stars—

nevertheless, like crawling locusts

your enemy will strip your land and fly away.

17Though your guards are like grasshoppers

and your marshals resemble locust swarms

settling in stone walls on a cold day,

when the sun comes up, they fly away,

nobody knows where. Nah 3:14-17

18Your shepherds are asleep, king of Assyria;

your nobles lie dead on the ground.

Your people have scattered to the mountains;

and there’s nobody to round them up.

19There’s no relief for your injury;

your wound won’t heal.

Everybody that hears about your destruction

claps their hands.

Who hasn’t come under your endless cruelty? Nah 3:18-19

HABAKKUK

1:1The Oracle That Habakkuk the Prophet Saw

Habakkuk’s Complaint

2How long, LORD, will I call out for help,

and you won’t listen?

I cry out, “Violence!”

but you don’t protect me.

3Why do you make me watch wickedness?

Destruction and violence go on right in front of me;

fighting and arguing keep getting worse and worse.

4The courts ignore the Law,

so they don’t render justice;

sinners are in the majority,

so they pervert justice. Hab 1:1-4

5The LORD’s first answer:

“Look around at the nations

and be astounded.

I’m doing something in your own day

you wouldn’t believe if somebody told you.

6I’m arousing the Babylonians,

that fierce, impetuous people

that marches across the region

to seize places to live that aren’t theirs.

7They’re dreaded and feared;

they’re a law unto themselves

and make their own rules

8Their horses are faster than cheetahs,

more vicious than wolves at dusk.

Their cavalry comes charging from far away

and swoops down like eagles to devour their prey.

9They come bent on violence;

their hordes surge forward like a desert wind

and sweep captives away like sand.

10They scoff at kings and ridicule rulers;

they laugh at fortresses

and pile up ramparts to besiege them.

11They rush through like the wind and move on;

they’re guilty men whose power is their god.” Hab 1:5-11

Habakkuk’s Second Complaint

12Aren’t you from everlasting,

LORD, my God, my Holy One?

Surely you won’t let us die.

You, LORD, have appointed the Babylonians to judge us;

you, Rock, have sent them to punish us.

13You’re too pure to approve of evil;

you can’t countenance wickedness.

Why do you tolerate treacherous people?

Why are you silent when sinners swallow up

people better than themselves? Hab 1:12-13

14They treat us like fish in the sea,

like creatures with no rulers.

15Sinful people fish us out with hooks

and scoop us up with nets.

They catch us in their seines;

they’re happy and celebrate.

16So they sacrifice to their seines

and burn incense to their fishing nets,

because they make large catches with them

and have lots to eat.

17Will they empty their nets then

and keep on killing nations without mercy? Hab 1:14-17

2:1I’ll stand at my post and watch;

I’ll station myself on a watchtower

to see how he’ll answer my complaint.

The LORD’s Second Answer

2The LORD’s second answer:

“Write down this vision, etch it on tablets

so the messenger can run with it

3The vision is still for a future time;

it speeds toward the goal and won’t fail.

Though it seems slow, wait for it;

it will certainly come in due time. Hab 2:1-3

4“Arrogant people aren’t righteous,

but the righteous will have life by his trust in me.

5Besides, wine betrays the arrogant, so they don’t last.

Their greed increases like the grave;

like death, they’re never satisfied.

They gather the whole world to themselves

and use everybody. Hab 2:4-5

6“Won’t people taunt them and say in mockery,

‘Misfortune awaits you that accumulate what’s not yours

and make yourselves rich by extortion

—for how long, though?

7Won’t your creditors suddenly decide

to call in their loans?

You’ll become their plunder.

8Since you’ve looted many nations,

other nations will loot you

for the blood of men and women that you shed,

for your violence to towns and their people.’

Hab 2:6-8

9“Misfortune awaits whoever uses dishonest gain

to build a prominent house up high,

like a nest beyond harm’s reach.

10You’ve plotted shamelessly to build that house

by ruining lots of people’s lives;

you end up sinning against yourself.

11The very stones cry out against you from the wall,

and the beams in the ceiling echo the complaint. Hab 2:9-11

12“Misfortune awaits whoever builds a city with murder

and establishes a town by violence!

13Isn’t it from the LORD of Hosts

that people labor only to have it burn up

and nations wear themselves out for nothing?

14The knowledge of the LORD’s glory

will cover the earth like water fills the ocean. Hab 2:12-14

15“Misfortune awaits you that make other people drink

your venom to get them drunk

so you can stare at their disgrace!

16You’ll be disgraced, not honored;

you’ll drink and expose your own disgrace.

The cup in the LORD’s right hand will come around to you;

complete disgrace will cover up your honor.

17The violence you did to Lebanon will overwhelm you;

the devastation of its animals will terrify you

because of the murder and violence

you did to the land, its towns, and their people.

Hab 2:15-17

18“What good is an idol after its maker carves it,

or an image, which represents a lie?

Its maker puts his faith in what he’s made

when the idol he’s made can’t even talk.

19Misfortune awaits whoever says to a piece of wood, ‘Wake up!’

or to a speechless rock, ‘Get up and help us!’

That’s your teacher!?

It’s overlaid with gold and silver,

but it can’t breathe.

20But the LORD is in his holy Temple;

let the whole earth be silent in his presence.” Hab 2:18-20

3:1A Prayer of Habakkuk

Set to Shigionoth

2 LORD, I’ve heard about you and stand in awe.

Revive your work in our time

and show what you can do;

in your anger remember mercy. Hab 3:1-2

3God is coming from Teman,

the Holy One from Mount Paran.

His brilliance covers the sky;

his praise fills the earth.

4His brightness shines like sunshine;

lightning bolts flash from his hand

where his power lies hidden.

5Disease goes ahead of him;

plague follows him.

6He stops and looks the world over;

the nations see him and tremble.

He beats down the everlasting mountains

and levels the ancient hills.

His ways of working have existed from eternity.

7I can see the tents in Nubia in distress;

the tent curtains in Midian are shaking in fear. Hab 3:3-7

8Did you rage against the rivers?

Was your anger against the streams?

Was it against the sea

that you drove your steeds and victory chariots?

9No. You took the cover off your bow

and put your arrows to the string.

You washed out canyons in the ground.

10The mountains watched you and shook

as the torrent flooded past;

The roaring deep cried out in surrender

and lifted its hands in submission.

11The sun and moon stood still;

they retreated at the flash of your arrows

and the radiance of your spear. Hab 3:8-11

12In your fury you marched across the world;

in your anger you trampled nations.

13You headed out to save your people,

to rescue your anointed ones.

You crushed the heads of the wicked

and laid them open from neck to thigh.

14You thrust through the leaders of their troops

with their own spears.

They’d stormed in to scatter us,

celebrating as if running over the poor unchecked.

15But with your horses you tramped down the sea of soldiers,

that surging mighty flood. Hab 3:12-15

16I heard it and my body trembled;

my lips quivered at the sound.

My knees buckled;

I froze, unable to move;

I’ll wait in silence for distress

to descend on our invaders.

17Though the fir tree hasn’t budded,

and there’re no grapes on the vine,

and the fields aren’t growing any food,

though the flock has scattered from the fold,

and there are no cattle in the stalls,

18I’ll still rejoice in the LORD

and delight in the salvation he’ll bring me.

19The Lord GOD is my strength;

he’s made my feet like deer’s feet

and enables me to walk surefooted on high places.

(For the choir director accompanied by my stringed instruments) Hab 3:16-19

ZEPHANIAH

1:1A Message from the LORD to Zephaniah Son of Cushi

(Son of Gedaliah Son of Amariah) Son of Hezekiah

at the Time of Josiah Son of Amon, King of Judah

The Coming Judgment on Judah

2“I’ll remove everything

from the earth,” the LORD says,

3“people and animals,

birds in the sky,

fish in the sea.

I’ll destroy sinful people.

4“I’ll reach out against Judah

and those who live in Jerusalem.

I’ll remove the remnant of Baal from this place

and the idolatrous priests,

5the ones that bow down on housetops to the host in the sky,

that swear to the LORD and swear by Milcom too,

6the ones that quit following the LORD,

that haven’t sought him or inquired from him.” Zeph 1:1-6

The Near Day of the LORD

7Be silent in front of the Lord GOD!

His day is near;

he’s prepared a sacrifice

and consecrated his guests.

8“On the day of my sacrifice,

I’ll punish the officials, the king’s sons in Judah,

everyone that dresses in foreign clothes,

9that breaks into houses,

and fills their masters’ homes with violence and deceit.

10On that day,” the LORD says,

“there’ll be cries from the Fish Gate,

wails from the Second Quarter,

loud crashes from the hills. Zeph 1:7-10

11Wail, people in the marketplace,

because your merchants will be wiped out;

every tradesman that weighs out silver will be gone.

12I’ll search Jerusalem with lanterns

and punish people that are complacent about their sin,

who tell themselves

that the LORD won’t do anything to them good or bad.

13Their wealth will become plunder,

and their houses demolished.

They’ll build houses, but not live in them;

they’ll plant vineyards, but not drink their wine.” Zeph 1:11-13

14That great day of the LORD is near and coming fast,

a bitter day: even soldiers will cry out bitterly,

15a day of anger,

a day of distress and anguish,

destruction and desolation,

a day of darkness and gloom,

clouds and dense blackness,

16a day of bugle blasts and battle cries

against fortified towns and high battle towers. Zeph 1:14-16

17He’ll bring such a distress on you

that you’ll stumble around like you’re blind,

because you’ve sinned against him.

Your blood will pour out and become like dust,

and your flesh will be like manure on the ground.

18Your silver and gold won’t save you

at the time of the LORD’s wrath;

he’ll consume the whole region with his burning anger

and make a complete, terrifying end

for people living in the land. Zeph 1:17-18

A Call for Repentance

2:1Get together,

go ahead, assemble, shameless nation,

2before the decree takes effect—

before that day of repentance passes by like chaff—

before the LORD’s burning anger comes down on you.

3Look to him,

you humble in the land

who’ve followed his commands.

Aspire to goodness and humility;

maybe the LORD will protect you when his anger comes. Zeph 2:1-3

Judgment Against Philistia

4Gaza will be abandoned;

Ashkelon, desolate.

Ashdod will be driven out at midday;

Ekron, uprooted.

5Misfortune awaits people along the coast,

nation of Cherethites!

The LORD’s message speaks against you,

Canaan, land of the Philistines;

I’ll destroy you till there’s no one left.

6The seacoast will be open range

with camps for shepherds and folds for flocks.

7It will serve as pasture

for the remnant from Judah.

In the evening they’ll lie down in the houses in Ashkelon,

because the LORD will take care of them

and restore their fortune. Zeph 2:4-7

Judgment Against Moab and Ammon

8“I’ve heard Moab taunting my people and Ammon insulting them;

they’ve become arrogant about my people’s territory.

9“So, as I live,” the LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel says,

“Moab will be like Sodom,

the Ammonites like Gomorrah—

a place full of nettles and salt pits,

a permanent wasteland.

The remnant of my people will plunder them;

the remainder of my nation will take their land.” Zeph 2:8-9

10That’s what they’ll get for their arrogance because they’ve taunted the people of the LORD of Hosts. 11He’ll terrify them and starve all the gods everywhere. Nations the world over will bow to him, each in their own land.

Judgment Against Nubia and Assyria

12“I’ll slay the Nubians with my sword,” says the LORD says.

13“I’ll reach out to the north to destroy Assyria

and make Nineveh a ruins, arid like a desert.

14Herds of wild animals will lie down in it;

buzzards and desert owls will roost on its columns.

Birds will chirp in its vacant windows;

rubble will block its doorways;

its cedar paneling will be exposed to the elements—

15the jubilant city that lived securely

and said to itself, ‘Nobody compares with me.’

What a wasteland it will become,

a haven for wild animals!

Anyone that goes by will gasp

and gesture in contempt.” Zeph 2:10-15

The Future of Jerusalem

3:1Misfortune awaits the rebellious, defiled, tyrannical city, Jerusalem,

2that wouldn’t take advice or accept instruction,

that didn’t trust in the LORD or come near to its God.

3Its officials are roaring lions;

its judges are ravening wolves at dusk

that leave nothing over till morning.

4Its prophets are reckless, devious men;

its priests profane the sanctuary and violate the Law.

5The LORD is good within it;

he still doesn’t do anything unjust.

Every morning he hands down justice without fail,

but they’re never ashamed of their unjust verdicts. Zeph 3:1-5

6“I’ve destroyed nations;

their towers lie in ruins.

I’ve made their streets deserted;

no one goes by there anymore.

Their towns have been laid waste;

nobody lives in them.

7I said, ‘Surely, they’ll respect me now

and accept my instruction

so their homes won’t get destroyed

along with everything else I’d appointed for them.’

But they were eager to corrupt everything they did. Zeph 3:6-7

8“So wait for me to attack my prey,” the LORD says.

I’ve decided to gather nations and kingdoms,

to pour out my indignation on them, my burning anger;

I’ll consume them with fiery zeal.

9Then I’ll purify the people’s lips

so they can call on me

and serve me together.

10From beyond the rivers in Nubia,

those who worship me—

descendants of my scattered people—

will bring me offerings.

11At that time, you won’t need to be ashamed

of all the things you did when you rebelled against me;

I’ll have removed arrogant, celebrating people from you

so you’ll never again be haughty on my holy mountain.

12But among you I’ll leave humble, common people

who will take refuge in me.

13The ones remaining in Israel will do no wrong,

tell no lies,

or have deceit among them;

They’ll graze and bed down in safety;

nobody will make them afraid.” Zeph 3:8-13

14Shout for joy, Jerusalem!

Cry out in triumph, Israel!

Celebrate with all your heart.

15The LORD has canceled your condemnation

and cleared away your foes.

The King of Israel is among you;

you need not dread disaster anymore. Zeph 3:14-15

16At that time, he’ll tell Jerusalem,

“Don’t be afraid, Zion;

don’t let your hands get weak.”

17The LORD your God is among you

as a victorious soldier.

I’ll celebrate over you

and renew my love for you;

I’ll celebrate over you with happy songs

18like on festival days.

“I’ll remove disaster from you, Zion;

you won’t be ashamed of being in exile.

19At that time, I’ll deal with your oppressors,

save the lame, gather the outcast,

and turn their shame into praise and renown

the world over.

20Then I’ll bring you home,

gather you together,

and give you renown among the nations

when I restore your fortunes before your very eyes,”

the LORD says. Zeph 3:16-20

HAGGAI

1:1The First Day, Sixth Month, Second Year of King Darius

A Message from the LORD by the Prophet Haggai

for Zerubbabel Son of Shealtiel, Governor of Judah,

and for Joshua Son of Jehozadak, the High Priest,

God’s Call to Rebuild the Temple

2“The LORD says, ‘These people are saying this is no time to be rebuilding the LORD’s Temple.’”

3A message came by Haggai, 4“Is this a time for you to be living in your paneled houses while my Temple lies in ruins?”

5“Think about how things are going for you!

6You sow a lot, but reap a little;

you eat, but not enough to satisfy;

you drink, but not enough to quench your thirst;

you put on clothes, but you’re not warm;

you put your pay in pouches with holes in them.” Hag 1:1-6

7“Think about what you’re doing!

8“Go up into the mountains to get lumber; rebuild the Temple so I can be pleased with it and honored by it. 9You look for a good crop, but it comes in poor. When you haul it in, I blow it away. Why? Because my Temple is lying in ruins while your interest lies in your own houses. 10So the sky hasn’t dropped dew, and the ground hasn’t produced crops. 11I called for a drought on the fields and hills: the grain, new wine, and olive oil—on what the ground grows; on you, your livestock, and your efforts.”

Obedience to God’s Call

12So Zerubbabel, Joshua/Jeshua, and the remnant obeyed Haggai because the LORD had sent him, and the people respected the LORD. 13Then Haggai said by God’s commission, “‘I’m with you,’ the LORD says.” 14So the LORD stirred up Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the remnant to begin work on the Temple 15the twenty-fourth day, sixth month, second year of Darius.

Hag 1:7-15

2:1The Twenty-First Day, Seventh Month

A Message from the LORD by Haggai

The New Temple’s Lesser Beauty

2“Ask Zerubbabel, Joshua/Jeshua the high priest, and the remnant, 3‘How many of you saw this Temple in its former beauty? How does it look to you now? Doesn’t it seem like nothing in comparison? 4But resolve to work because I’m with you. 5Like I promised when you came out of Egypt, my Spirit’s among you so you needn’t be afraid!’

6“Soon I’m going to shake earth and sky one more time, ocean and dry land, 7as well as the nations. Pilgrims will bring wealth from every country to fill this Temple with beauty. 8Silver and gold belong to me. 9This Temple’s beauty will be greater than the former, and there’ll be peace here.” Hag 2:1-9

10The Twenty-Fourth Day, Ninth Month, Second Year of Darius

A Message from the LORD to Haggai

Blessings for a Defiled People

11“Ask the priests for a ruling: 12‘if someone carries consecrated meat folded up in his cloak and that fold touches bread, cooked food, wine, olive oil, and the like, does the other food become consecrated?’”

“No.”

13“If somebody that’s ceremonially unclean from a corpse, touches any of these, will they become unclean?”

“Yes.”

14Then Haggai said,

“That’s the way it is with this nation. Everything you do and everything you offer is unclean. 15Think about what was happening before you began to place one stone on another in the LORD’s Temple: 16f you went to a grain pile to get 20 measures, there’d only be 10 left; if you went to a wine vat to draw 50 measures, there’d only be 20 left. 17You and everything you did, I struck with blasting wind, mildew, and hail; but you didn’t come back to me. 18-19But notice this: The seed is still in the granary; the grapevines, fig trees, pomegranates, and olive trees have not started to bear—but from this twenty-fourth day of the ninth month on, when you’ve begun laying the foundation for the Temple—I’ll be blessing you.” Hag 2:10-19

20 The Same Day: Twenty-Fourth Day of the Month

A Second Message from the LORD to Haggai

Zerubbabel as the LORD’s Signet Ring

21“Tell Zerubbabel, ‘I’m going to shake earth and sky, 22overthrow the thrones of kingdoms, destroy powerful nations, defeat chariots and riders; every horse and rider will fall by the sword. 23Then I’ll make you my signet ring because I’ve chosen you, Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel.’

I, the LORD of hosts, have spoken.”

Hag 2:20-23

ZECHARIAH

1:1The Eighth Month, Second Year of Darius

A Message from the LORD to the Prophet Zechariah Son of Berechiah Son of Iddo

A Call to Return to the LORD

2“I was angry with your ancestors. 3So tell the people, ‘The LORD of Hosts says, “Come back to me so I can come back to you. 4Don’t be like your ancestors that former prophets told to come back from their sinful ways and deeds, but they didn’t pay any attention. 5Where are those ancestors? Prophets don’t live forever, 6but my message commanded through them did come to bear on your ancestors. As a result, they repented and said, ‘The LORD of Hosts has dealt with us the way he intended, according to our ways and deeds.’”’”

Zech 1:1-6

7The Twenty-Fourth Day, Eleventh Month (Shebat), Second Year of Darius

A Message from the LORD to Zechariah

A Man Among the Murtle Trees

8During the night I saw a man on a chestnut horse among some myrtle trees in a ravine. Behind him were chestnut, sorrel, and white horses and their riders. 9I said, “Sir, what do those horses mean?”

The angel said, “I’ll show you.”

10The man on the horse among the myrtle trees said, “The LORD has sent them to patrol the earth.”

11They answered the angel of the LORD, who was standing among the myrtle trees, “We’ve patrolled the earth. It’s peaceful and quiet.”

12The angel asked, “LORD of Hosts, how long will you not have mercy on Jerusalem and the towns in Judah that you’ve been angry with these 70 years?”

13The LORD answered him with gracious, reassuring words.

14So the angel told me,

“Declare that the LORD of Hosts says, ‘I’m jealous for Jerusalem and Zion, 15but I’m angry with the nations that are at ease. While I was a little angry, they made the disaster worse. 16So I’ll come back to Jerusalem with mercy. My Temple will be rebuilt there, and a measuring line will be stretched out over it for reconstructing it.’”

17“Also say, ‘My towns will overflow with prosperity again. I’ll comfort Zion again and choose Jerusalem once more.’” Zech 1:7-17

Four Horns and Four Blacksmiths

18Then I looked up and saw four horns. 19I asked the angel what they represented.

“The horns of the nations that scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem.”

20Then the LORD showed me four blacksmiths.

21I asked what they were coming to do.

“The four horns scattered Judah and humbled it. But these blacksmiths have come to hammer down and destroy the nations that lifted up their horns to scatter the people of Judah.” Zech 1:18-21

A Man with a Measuring Line

2:1Then I saw a man holding a measuring line, and 2asked him where he was going.

“To measure how wide and long Jerusalem is.”

3The angel that was talking to me was leaving, and another angel met him 4and said,

“Run and tell that young man, ‘Jerusalem will be lived in like open country because of the number of people and livestock that’s in it. 5I’ll be a fire wall around it and the glory in it.

6“Flee from up north where I’ve scattered you to the four winds. 7Zion! Escape, you exiles in Babylon.’

8“‘It’s for glory that he has sent me against the nations that plundered you, because whoever touches you will be poking themselves in the eye. 9I’ll raise my fist over them so their slaves will plunder them. You’ll know the LORD of Hosts has sent me.

10“Sing and be happy, Zion, because I’m coming to live among you. 11Many nations will join the LORD then and become my people. I’ll live among you, and you’ll know the LORD of Hosts has sent me to you. 12He’ll own Judah as his portion in the holy land and choose Jerusalem again.’”

13Be silent in his presence, all you nations; he has risen up to take action from the holy place where he lives. Zech 2:1-13

The Cleansing of Joshua the High Priest

3:1Then he showed me Joshua/Jeshua the high priest standing in front of the angel of the LORD, and Satan standing to his right to accuse him. 2The LORD told Satan, “The LORD rebuke you, Satan! I who chose Jerusalem reject your accusations! Isn’t this man a brand snatched out of the fire?”

3Joshua’s clothes were dirty, 4so the angel told the ones standing there, “Change his dirty clothes.” “I’ve taken your sinfulness off so I can dress you up with festive robes.”

5I said, “Have them put a clean turban on him too.” So they dressed him up while the angel of the LORD stood by. Zech 3:1-5

6The angel charged Joshua,
