7“The LORD of Hosts says, ‘If you follow me and do your service, you’ll have charge of my Temple and courts. I’ll let you have free access along with the ones that are standing here. 8Listen, Joshua, you and your friends sitting in front of you are symbols, because I’m going to bring in my servant the Branch. 9Look at the stone I’ve put in front of Joshua, a single stone with seven facets. I’ll engrave an inscription on it and remove the sinfulness of the land in one day. 10At that time, each one of you will invite your friend to sit under your vine and fig tree.’” Zech 3:6-10

A Lampstand and Two Olive Trees

4:1The angel came back and brought me to as if I’d been asleep. 2He asked me what I saw.

“A gold lampstand with its bowl of oil on top, as well as its seven lamps with one spout apiece. 3I see an olive tree on each side of it. 4What do they mean, Sir?”

5“Don’t you know?”

“No.”

6“This is what the LORD tells Zerubbabel, ‘Not by force, not by power, but by my Spirit. 7Not even a big mountain will be able to get in your way. You’ll set the cap stone for the Temple amid shouts of “God bless it!! God bless it!”’” Zech 4:1-7

8A Message from the LORD to Me

9“Zerubbabel has laid the foundation for the Temple, and he’ll finish it. Then you’ll know the LORD of Hosts is the One that sent me to youpl. 10Whoever has been disappointed during the time of small beginnings will be happy when they see Zerubbabel holding a plumb line. These seven lamps represent the LORD’s eyes that scan back and forth over the world.”

11I asked, “What do the two olive trees beside the lampstand represent? 12What do the two olive branches represent beside the two gold tubes that drain out the golden oil?”

13“You don’t know?”

“No, Sir.”

14“They represent the two anointed ones that stand beside the Lord of the whole world.”

Zech 4:8-14

A Flying Scroll

5:1Then I looked up and saw a flying scroll.

2He said, “What do you see?”

“A flying scroll, 15 by 30ft.”

3He told me,

“It contains the words of the curse that’s over the whole world. Everyone that steals will be erased from one side. Everyone that swears falsely will be erased from the other. 4The LORD of Hosts will send the curse out to the thief’s house and to the house of the one that swears falsely by his name. The curse will remain there all night till it consumes its timbers and stones.’” Zech 5:1-4

A Woman in a Basket

5The angel came forward and said, “Look at what’s coming.”

6I said, “What is it?”

“A basket ephah for measuring grain. It’s filled with the sins of everybody in the land 7[a lead cover was lifted off of it], and that’s a woman sitting inside it 8named Wickedness!” He shoved her down into the ephah and put the lead lid back on it. 9I saw two women flying toward us with wings like a stork. They took the ephah up in the air.

10I asked the angel where they were taking it.

11“To Shinar to build a temple for it. When it’s ready, they’ll set the ephah there on its own pedestal.” Zech 5:5-11

Four Chariots

6:1I looked again and saw four chariots coming out from between two bronze mountains. 2Chestnut horses were pulling the first chariot, black horses the second, 3white horses the third, and powerful dappled-gray horses the fourth.

4I asked the angel, “What are they, Sir?”

5“They’re the four spirits of heaven going out from the Lord of the whole world. 6One chariot is going north with the black horses; after them the white horses are going west. The dappled-gray horses are going south. 7Those powerful horses went out, chomping at the bit to patrol the world.”

He said, “Go on and patrol it.” So they did.

8Then he shouted to me, “Look, the ones going north have appeased my anger there.”

Zech 6:1-8

9A Message from the LORD to Me

The Crowning of Joshua

10“Heldai, Tobijah, and Jedaiah will bring an offering of silver and gold from the exiles in Babylon. The same day, go to the house of Josiah son of Zephaniah to meet them. 11Make a crown out of the silver and gold, and put it on Joshua/Jeshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest. 12Tell him, ‘The LORD of Hosts says a man named Branch will “branch out” from where he is and build the Temple, 13bear the honor, and rule from his throne. He’ll also be a priest on his throne, and his combined roles will work together.’ 14The crown will serve as a memorial to Heldai, Tobijah, Jedaiah, and Josiah in the LORD’s Temple. 15People from a long way off will come to rebuild the Temple.”

When these things come about, they’ll assure you that the LORD of Hosts has sent me. They will all happen if you faithfully obey him. Zech 6:9-15

7:1The Fourth Day, Ninth Month (Chislev), Fourth Year of King Darius

A Message from the LORD to Zechariah

A Call for Justice and Mercy, Not Fasting

2The people in Bethel had sent Sharezer, Regem-melech, and their men to ask for the LORD’s blessing. 3They spoke to the priests in the LORD’s Temple and to the prophets,

“Should we keep mourning and fasting in the fifth month like we’ve done all these years?”

4A Message from the LORD to Me

5“Tell the priests and people in the land, ‘When you fasted and mourned in the fifth and seventh months those 70 years, were you really fasting for me? 6And now when you eat and drink, aren’t you eating and drinking for yourselves? 7Isn’t that the same message the LORD delivered by the former prophets to the people in Jerusalem when it and its towns were prospering, and people were living in the Negev and western foothills?’” Zech 7:1-7

8A Message from the LORD to Zechariah

9“The LORD of Hosts says, ‘Judge fairly, practice kindness and mercy with each other. 10Don’t oppress widows and orphans, foreigners or poor people. Don’t plot against one another.’ 11But your ancestors refused to pay attention, turned a stubborn shoulder, and covered their ears. 12They hardened their hearts like flint so they couldn’t hear the Law and what Yahveh had sent by his Spirit through the former prophets. That’s why he was so angry with them. 13Just as he called and they wouldn’t listen, so they called and he wouldn’t listen. 14With a tornado he scattered them throughout foreign nations. The land they left lay so desolate nobody traveled through it. They’d turned their pleasant land into a wasteland.” Zech 7:8-14

8:1A Message from the LORD

Promised Blessings for Jerusalem

2“The LORD of Hosts says, ‘I’m jealous for Zion. 3I’ll come back to live in Jerusalem, and it’ll be called The City of Truth. My mountain will be called The Holy Mount. 4Old men and women will sit in its streets again with staffs in hand because they’re old. 5Boys and girls will play in the streets. 6If that sounds incredible to the remnant that’s left, does that make it incredible for me? 7I’m going to save my people from lands east and west 8and bring them back to live here. They’ll be my people, and I’ll be their God, faithful and just.’ Zech 8:1-8

9“Be strong, you that are listening to this message from the prophets who spoke when the foundation of my Temple was being laid so it could be completely rebuilt. 10Before then there weren’t any jobs. Because criminals were everywhere, travelers weren’t safe; everybody was working against everybody else. 11But I won’t treat the remnant like that now. 12Their descendants will have peace, the grapevines will bear fruit, the ground will grow produce, the sky will drop dew. The remnant will inherit those things. 13Just as you were a curse among the nations, Judah and Israel, so I’ll save you to become a blessing. Don’t be afraid; be strong.

14“Just as I planned to punish you when your ancestors were so offensive to me and I didn’t hold back, 15so now I intend to treat Jerusalem and Judah well. Don’t be afraid! 16To have peace around you, tell the truth and judge honestly. 17Don’t make plots or commit perjury. I despise things like that.” Zech 8:9-17

18A Message from the LORD to Me

19“The LORD of Hosts says, ‘The fasts in the fourth, fifth, seventh, and tenth months will be a joy for Judah; so love honesty and peace. 20People from cities all around will attend. 21One city will go to another one and say, “Let’s travel together to look up to the LORD and ask for his blessing.”

“All right.”

22So, many nations and powerful countries will look up to me in Jerusalem and ask for my blessing. 23Ten men from different languages will clutch one Jew’s cloak and ask, “Can we go along? We’ve heard that God is with you.”’”

Zech 8:18-23

9:1A Message from the LORD Against the Land of Hadrach [Aram]

The message from the LORD is against Damascus—for the eyes of all people, including the tribes of Israel, are on the LORD—

2against Hamath, which borders it,

and against Tyre and Sidon, though they’re so very wise.

3Tyre built a fortress,

piled up silver like dust

and gold like dirt on the streets.

4The LORD will confiscate its possessions,

throw its wealth into the sea,

and burn it down.

5Ashkelon will see it and be afraid.

Gaza will writhe in anguish;

Ekron, too, because it’s lost hope;

Gaza won’t have a king;

Ashkelon will be empty.

6Ashdod will house a mongrel race;

I’ll destroy the Philistines’ pride.

7I’ll remove the blood from their mouths

and the disgusting things from between their teeth.

They’ll be a remnant for our God,

like a clan in Judah;

Ekron will be like Jebusites. Zech 9:1-7

8I’ll camp around my Temple to protect it

so armies can’t walk all over my people;

oppressors won’t run over them anymore

because I’m watching.

Zion’s Coming King

9Celebrate, Zion!

Shout, Jerusalem!

Your king is coming to you,

just and able to save,

humble and riding on a donkey,

on a colt, a donkey’s foal.

10I’ll get rid of chariots in Ephraim,

warhorses in Jerusalem,

and the bow used in battle.

I’ll offer peace to the nations

and rule from sea to sea,

from the Euphrates River to the ends of the earth. Zech 9:8-10

11Because of my covenant with you, sealed with blood,

I’ve freed your prisoners from the dry cistern.

12Come back to the fortress, all you prisoners that still have hope;

I promise to restore you double today.

13I’ll bend Judah like my bow;

Ephraim will be my arrow.

I’ll stir up Zion against Greece

and wield you like a sword.

14The LORD will appear above them;

his arrows will shoot like lightning.

He’ll blow the bugle

and march in the windstorm from the south. Zech 9:11-14

15The LORD of Hosts will defend his people;

they’ll trample the stone slingers.

They’ll drink their bloodlxx and be boisterous as with wine,

filled like a sacrificial basin,

drenched like the horns on the altar.

16The LORD their God will save them then

like a flock of his sheep,

like jewels in a crown,

sparkling in his land.

17How nice things will be!

Grain will make the young men thrive;

new wine will make the maidens flourish. Zech 9:15-17

The LORD Will Restore His People

10:1Ask the LORD for showers in the spring;

the One that forms the storm clouds

will give each farmer crops in his field.

2Household gods speak nonsense;

fortunetellers see false dreams

and give empty consolation.

So people wander in danger like lost sheep

because they don’t have a shepherd.

3“My anger flares at the shepherds;

I’ll punish the male goats,

because I care about my flock, the House of Judah;

I’ll make them like my majestic steed in battle.

4The cornerstone will come from Judah,

the tent peg, the bow in battle, and every ruler.

5Together they’ll become great warriors

and walk all over their enemies like dirt on a road;

they’ll fight because the LORD will be on their side;

they’ll outfight enemies that ride horses.

6He’ll strengthen Judah and save Joseph,

and bring them back.

7Ephraim will become a powerful man

and be happy as if from wine.

His children will see it and be happy too,

and celebrate in the LORD. Zech 10:1-7

8I’ll whistle for them to gather

because I’ve redeemed them;

there’ll be as many of them as before.

9Though I scattered them among the nations,

they’ll remember me in far countries,

survive with their children,

and return.

10I’ll bring them back from Egypt and Assyria

and settle them in Gilead and Lebanon

till they take up the whole area.

11I’ll escort them through the distressing Red Sea

and hold back its waves;

I’ll completely dry up the Nile,

crush Assyria’s pride,

and end Egypt’s rule.

12I’ll make my people strong,

and they’ll follow me.” Zech 10:8-12

11:1Open your doors, Lebanon,

so fire can consume your cedar forests.

2Wail, cypress trees, for the fallen cedars;

the stately trees have burned up.

Wail, oaks of Bashan;

the thick woodland has been cut down.

3The shepherds wail

because their good pasture’s gone.

The young lions roar

because the jungle by the Jordan is decimated. Zech 11:1-3

Good and Bad Shepherds

4The LORD my God says,

“Pasture the flock that’s doomed to slaughter. 5The buyers butcher them without remorse. The sellers say, ‘Praise the LORD, I’m rich!’ Their own shepherds don’t care about them! 6I won’t have mercy on people like that. I’ll let them fall into each other’s hands and the hands of their king. They’ll ruin the land, and I won’t protect it.” Zech 11:4-6

7So I began pasturing the flock that was doomed to slaughter by the ones that trafficked in sheep. I took two staffs; I called one Favor and the other Unity, and I tended the flock with them. 8I fired three worthless shepherds in one month.

I also lost patience with the sheep, and they lost interest in me. 9I told them,

“I won’t pasture you anymore.

What’s to die will die;

what’s to be destroyed will be destroyed.

The rest will eat one another.”

10The staff I called Favor I cut in pieces to demonstrate that I was breaking the covenant I’d made with all the nations. 11That day, the ones that trafficked in sheep realized the LORD was acting out a message through me. 12I told them, “If you want, pay me; if not, keep it!” So they weighed out 12 oz 30 shekels of silver to pay me. 13The LORD told me, “Throw them to the potter, that grand value they put on me!” So I threw them to the potter in the LORD’s Temple. 14Then I cut in pieces the staff I called Unity to demonstrate that I was breaking the alliance between Judah and Israel. Zech 11:7-14

15The LORD told me,

“Again, dress up like a worthless shepherd. 16I’m going to show the land a picture of a shepherd that won’t take care of the dying, look for the strays, heal the injured, or feed the healthy. He’ll eat the healthy ones and tear off their hoofs.

17“Misfortune awaits the worthless shepherd

that deserts the flock!

A sword will cut his arm

and poke out his right eye!

His arm will wither,

and his right eye will go blind.” Zech 11:15-17

12:1A Message from the LORD About Israel

Future Destruction of Jerusalem’s Enemies

This is what the LORD says who stretched out the sky, laid earth’s foundation, and formed the human spirit:

2“I’m going to make Jerusalem a cup that makes every nation stagger who lays siege to Jerusalem and Judah. 3I’ll make Jerusalem a heavy rock; any nation that tries to pick it up will rupture itself. When nations surround it, 4I’ll make their horses bolt and their riders panic, but I’ll watch over Judah as I strike those enemies’ horses blind. 5The clans in Judah will realize that the residents of Jerusalem have strong protection from the LORD of Hosts their God.’ Zech 12:1-5

6“At that time, I’ll make the clans in Judah like a fire pot in a woodpile, a torch among bundles of grain. They’ll consume the nations around them while Jerusalem stays safe. 7The LORD will save the people in Judah first so David’s royal line and Jerusalem won’t have greater glory than the rest of Judah. 8The weakest among the people in Jerusalem will be as strong as David, and his descendants will lead them out like God, like the angel of the LORD. 9I’ll destroy any nation that attacks Jerusalem. Zech 12:6-9

The One They Have Pierced

10“I’ll pour out a spirit of grace and prayer on David’s family and the people in Jerusalem so they’ll look at me that they’ve speared. They’ll mourn for me like people mourn for an only son or a firstborn son. 11There’ll be extreme mourning in Jerusalem, like the mourning for Hadad-rimmon on the Plain of Megiddo. 12Each clan in Israel will mourn by itself, husbands and wives separately: the clans of Nathan, 13Levi, the Shimeites, and 14the rest. Zech 12:10-14

The Cleansing Fountain

13:1“Then a fountain will spring up for David’s house and the people in Jerusalem, a fountain for cleansing sin and impurity. 2I’ll get rid of the idols in Israel; they’ll fade from memory. I’ll remove false prophets and unclean spirits. 3If anybody still tries to make up their own prophecy, their own parents will say, ‘You’ve lied in the LORD’s name!’ and they’ll run them through. 4People will be averse to claiming they’ve had visions; they won’t put on a prophet’s hairy robe to create impressions. 5They’ll say, ‘I’m not a prophet; I plow ground because a man sold me as a slave when I was a kid.’ 6If somebody asks him, ‘Where did those scars come from around your wrists?’ he’ll say, ‘From wounds at “a friend’s” house!’ Zech 13:1-6

The Shepherd Struck, the Sheep Scattered

7Wake up, sword, against my shepherd,

my associate;

strike the shepherd,

scatter the sheep,

and turn against the lambs.

8In the whole land, two parts will perish,

but the third will survive;

9I’ll bring that third part through the fire,

refine them like silver,

purify them like gold.

They’ll call on me, and I’ll answer.

I’ll say, ‘They’re my people’;

they’ll say, ‘The LORD’s our God.’” Zech 13:7-9

The LORD Will Rule the World

14:1The LORD will bring a time when nations will plunder you right in front of you. 2He’ll gather them against Jerusalem and capture it. The houses will be looted and the women raped; half the people will be exiled and the rest abandoned among the ruins.

3But then the LORD will go out and fight them. 4His feet will stand on the Mount of Olives east of Jerusalem. The mountain will split apart east to west, half moving north and half moving south with a wide valley between. 5You’ll escape by that valley, which will reach as far as Azal. You’ll flee like you did from the earthquake when Uzziah reigned in Judah. Then the LORD my God will come with his holy ones! 6There won’t be any cold or frost, 7a unique day known only to the LORD, without day or night; there’ll be light in the evening. 8At that time, water will pour out of Jerusalem year around, half to the Dead Sea and half to the Mediterranean.

9The LORD will become king of the whole world, the only one. 10The land from Geba to Rimmon south of Jerusalem will become a large plain. But Jerusalem will rise on its site from Benjamin’s Gate to the First Gate to the Corner Gate, from the Tower of Hananel to the king’s winepresses. 11People will live in Jerusalem safely because its curse will be gone. Zech 14:1-11

12The LORD will use a plague to strike the nations that attacked Jerusalem. Their flesh will rot while they’re standing; their eyes will decay in their sockets; their tongues will mold in their mouths. 13The LORD will throw them into a panic, and they’ll attack one another in hand-to-hand combat. 14Judah will fight at Jerusalem and gather wealth from surrounding nations—lots of gold, silver, and clothing. 15There’ll also be a plague on the horses, mules, camels, donkeys, and cattle in those enemies’ camps.

16Any nation that attacked Jerusalem and survived the plague, will go up every year to worship the King, the LORD of Hosts, and celebrate the Festival of Booths. 17-18It won’t rain for any family in Egypt or elsewhere who won’t go up to that celebration. [19] 20Even the bells on their horses will bear the inscription “Holy to the LORD.” Cooking pots in his Temple will be as sacred as bowls beside the altar. 21Every cooking pot in Jerusalem and Judah will be sacred to him, so everybody that sacrifices can boil meat in them from the sacrifices. There won’t be any Canaanites anymore in the Temple of the LORD of Hosts. Zech 14:12-21

MALACHI

1:1An Oracle from the LORD to Israel Through Malachi

Jacob Loved More Than Esau

2The LORD says, “I’ve loved you.”

But you ask, “What do you mean ‘loved us’?”

“Wasn’t Esau Jacob’s brother? Yet I’ve loved Jacob 3and set Esau aside, made his hill country desolate, and left his inheritance for desert jackals.”

4Esau’s descendants claim, “We’ve been beaten down, but we’ll come back and rebuild the ruins.”

But the LORD of Hosts says, “They may rebuild, but I’ll tear it down again. People will call them The Evil Country, The Nation the LORD Is Angry with Forever.”

5You’ll see this and say, “May the LORD be honored beyond Israel’s boundaries!”

Blemished Sacrifices

6The LORD says to priests that despise him, “A son honors his father, and a servant respects his master. Then if I’m a father, where’s my honor? If I’m a master, where’s my respect?”

“But you ask, ‘Dishonored you? How?’

7“You present defiled sacrifices on my altar.”

“But you ask, ‘Defiled sacrifices, how?’”

“By disrespecting my altar. 8When you offer the blind, lame, and sick, isn’t that disrespect? Why not offer something like that to your governor? Would he be happy with you? Would he accept you?” Mal 1:1-8

9“Will you ask me to bless you and be gracious to you? With offerings like that, why would I be gracious to anybody? 10If only there’d be one among you that would shut the Temple doors so you wouldn’t light fire on my altar for nothing! I’m not happy with you, and I won’t accept your offerings. 11From sunrise to sunset, I intend to be honored as great the world over, wherever there’s incense and pure grain offerings.

12“But you profane me by saying, ‘It won’t hurt anything to defile the LORD’s table; the sacrifices for it are no big deal. 13They’re so tiresome!’

“You blow it off and bring what you stole, something lame or sick, so you can say you brought an offering! 14A curse on the cheat that vows a male from his flock but sacrifices a blemished one. What is this?! I’m a great King to be respected the world over!” Mal 1:9-14

Warning to Priests

2:1“Priests, I’m talking to you. 2If you don’t get serious about honoring me, I’ll put a curse on you and even curse the blessings you receive. Actually, I already have, because you’re not taking me seriously. 3I’ll bring misfortune on your descendants and spatter your faces with the offal from your feasts. I’ll throw you out with it. 4You’ll find out that I’m the One that sent this commandment so my covenant with Levi can continue. 5My covenant with him gives life and peace. I gave it to him so he’d show me reverence, and he did 6and gave true instruction. He followed me in peace and goodness, and turned people back from sin. 7A priest should preserve knowledge, and people should look to him for instruction because he’s a messenger from the LORD of Hosts. 8But you’ve gone off-road and made people stumble with your instruction; you’ve corrupted my covenant with Levi. 9So people despise you because you show favoritism in how you execute the Law.” Mal 2:1-9

Judah Profaned the Covenant

10“Don’t we all have the same Father? Hasn’t the same God created us? Why are we unfaithful to one another and violate our ancestors’ covenant? 11Judah has been unfaithful and created an abomination in Israel and Jerusalem. He’s profaned the sanctuary the LORD loves and married the daughter of a foreign god. 12May the LORD cut off from Jacob anyone who does that and then tries to present him an offering.

13“Another thing you do is cover the LORD’s altar with tears, weeping, and groaning because he doesn’t accept your offerings anymore.”

14“You ask, ‘Why?’

“Because he’s seen how unfaithful you’ve been to the wife you’ve had from your youth though she’s your partner, your wife by covenant. 15Nobody does that who has even an ounce of the spirit and wants godly offspring; so pay attention to your spirit so you won’t be unfaithful to her. 16I despise divorce and the one that tries to cover up his adultery with cruelty by divorcing his wife.”

A Day of Judgment

17“You’ve worn the LORD out with your talk.

“How?”

“By saying, ‘People that sin are as good in his sight as anybody else; he delights in them’; or ‘Where’s there a just God?’” Mal 2:10-17

3:1“I’m going to send my messenger to fix the road ahead of me. Then the LORD you’re looking for will suddenly come to his Temple, the messenger of the covenant you delight in. 2But who can endure it when he comes? Who can withstand his appearing? He’ll be like a refiner’s fire and a fuller’s soap. 3He’ll sit like a refiner that smelts and purifies dross from silver. He’ll purify the Levites and refine them like gold and silver so they can present acceptable offerings. 4Then the offerings in Judah and Jerusalem will be pleasing to me like before.

5“Then I’ll put you on trial and eagerly testify against sorcerers, adulterers, people that swear falsely, cheat wage earners, abuse widows and orphans; are prejudiced against foreigners, and don’t respect me. Mal 3:1-5

Robbing God

6“I don’t change. That’s why I haven’t consumed you yet, Jacob. 7From the time of your ancestors, you’ve repeatedly turned away from my statutes. Come back to me, and I’ll come back to you.”

“What do you mean ‘come back’?’”

8“Will a mortal steal from God? Yet you’re stealing from me!

“Stealing from you?”

“Tithes and offerings. 9You’re accursed because the whole nation is stealing from me! 10Bring the whole tithe to the storehouse so there’ll be enough food for my Temple staff. Test me in that and see if I don’t open the sky and pour out blessing on you till there’s no more need. 11I’ll drive away diseases and locust plagues for you so they won’t ruin your produce and your grapevines won’t drop their grapes before they’re ripe. 12Other nations will say you’re fortunate to have such a delightful land.” Mal 3:6-12

13“You say arrogant things about me,” the LORD says.

“Like what?”

14“Like, ‘There’s no point in serving God. What good’s it do to keep his charges or mourn in front of him when we fail to do so? 15We may as well consider proud people fortunate: not only do they prosper; but when they make trial of God, they get away with it!’”

16Then the LORD heard people talking to one another who did respect and honor him. He recorded their names 17and said, “They’ll be mine when I render judgment on who is my special possession. I’ll have mercy on them like a man has on a reliable son. 18I’ll distinguish the good ones that serve me and from the bad ones that won’t. Mal 3:13-18

The Day of the LORD

4:1“The time’s coming when the arrogant people you admire will be like stubble that burns up in a furnace—root, stem, and all. 2But for you that respect me, goodness will rise up like the sun with healing in its wings. You’ll break out, jump around for joy, and run all over like calves let out of a stall. 3At the time I’m planning for, you’ll stomp on sinners like ashes under your feet.

4“Remember the Law of Moses my servant, the statutes and ordinances I commanded him at Horeb/Sinai for you. 5I’ll send you Elijah the prophet before that awesome day comes. 6He’ll turn fathers’ hearts back to their children and children’s hearts back to their fathers, so I won’t put a curse on the land.”

Mal 4:1-6

From the Conversational New Testament translation by Virgil Warren, PhD
